Income Rise Not Matched By Spending
LEAD: The savings rate of Americans rose to 5.8 percent of their disposable income in March as consumer spending failed to match an increase in personal incomes, the Commerce Department reported today.

Bush Assails Congress for Delay Of $420 Million in Aid to Panama
LEAD: As President Bush welcomed President Guillermo Endara of Panama to the White House, he used the occasion today to criticize Congress for delaying a bill that includes $420 million to help rebuild the Panamanian economy.


On Right, Signs of Discontent With Bush
LEAD: Leaders of the conservative movement, who have been placated by President Bush's relentless courting and occasional policy concessions, are for the first time threatening to break their uneasy peace with the White House.


Memorial for Actress
LEAD: A memorial service will be held this evening at 6:45 for Ruth Rome, a New York actress and singer, at the Union of American Hebrew Congregations, 838 Fifth Avenue, at 65th Street.
Ms.
Rome, who was 27 years old, died in a ferry accident in the North Sea on April 7, although her death was not confirmed until a week later.

LEAD: The new beauty magazine planned by Conde Nast Publications Inc. finally has a name: Allure.

It's Almost Too Amazin'! Cone Argues While 2 Runs Score
LEAD: It may not get any more bizarre than this on a baseball diamond.
The Mets, a team starving for runs, watched helplessly as David Cone gave away two to the Braves tonight in strange fashion.


Squeezing the Slorc
LEAD: Since the army shot down a democratic revolution in Myanmar, formerly Burma, 19 months ago, that nation's 40 million people have been helpless victims of a capricious military regime.
Washington has suspended official aid.
But Myanmar's ruling State Law and Order Restoration Council, or Slorc, has found a new way to pay for its brutal military operations.


Bridge
LEAD: Redoubled contracts are very rare, but are more likely to occur, for mathematical reasons, when the redoubler is not vulnerable.
The potential profit is the same, unless there is an overtrick, and the potential loss is smaller.
In a competitive auction the redouble is usually based on some doubt about success rather than on total confidence.


Transactions
LEAD:
Baseball


Bulgarian Bank Planned
LEAD: Business executives in Bulgaria have decided to set up the country's first private bank, the ruling Socialist Party newspaper Douma said today.
The bank would have capital of 10 million leva, or $3.3 million, and would offer low-interest loans to stimulate private enterprise, the newspaper said.
Bulgaria's private business association, the Citizens' Union for Economic Initiative, set the price of the bank's shares, which foreigners would be permitted to buy, at 1,000 leva, or $330, each.

LEAD: A special panel of House Democrats said today that the investigation into the killing of six Jesuit priests in El Salvador had come to ''a virtual standstill'' because authorities there were making little effort to determine if senior Salvadoran military officers ordered or concealed the crime.

It said Mr.
Yeltsin, who was hospitalized earlier in the day suffering from severe back pains, could not move his left foot.

LEAD: Bargain hunters and program traders lifted the market out of a slump yesterday.

Germans to Get Priceless Gospels Lost in '45
LEAD: A ninth-century illuminated and illustrated manuscript of the Four Gospels in a jewel-encrusted gold-and-silver binding, which disappeared from a mine shaft in American-occupied Germany shortly after the Nazi collapse in 1945, will be returned today to West Germany.

LEAD: J. Walter Yeagley, a former official of the Justice Department and a retired judge of the District of Columbia Court of Appeals, died Saturday at the Hospice of Palm Beach County in West Palm Beach, Fla.
He was 81 years old and had lived in Riviera Beach, Fla., since retiring in 1984.

Bankruptcy Court Clears Learjet Sale
LEAD: The sale of the Learjet Corporation, a maker of corporate jets, to Bombardier Inc. of Canada for $75 million in cash was approved by a Federal bankruptcy judge last week.
The sale by Integrated Resources Inc. also requires Bombardier to assume liabilities associated with Learjet's continuing operations, including loans outstanding under the company's $38 million line of credit.

Review/Television;   Show About Black People, With Winfrey in Charge
LEAD: Although off to a sluggish start, ''Brewster Place'' represents an Olympics-sized leap in prime-time programming.
Television has had dramas and dramatic series about black people and for black people.
Now it has one controlled by a black person.
The star of ''Brewster Place'' is Oprah Winfrey.
More important, she is one of the executive producers.

Ending Rift, U.S. Resumes Ties With Southern Yemen

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Altschiller: A Merger That Works
LEAD: THE new midtown Manhattan headquarters of the Altschiller Reitzfeld Davis/Tracy-Locke advertising agency came with several unusual features.
Consider, for example, the exposed pipes in the ceiling, a design statement usually associated with young, downtown agencies, not a 13-year-old shop.
And instead of doors with hinges and knobs, the offices feature metal doors that slide and lock like bank vaults.

Antibodies Seem to Protect Fetus From AIDS
LEAD: SCIENTISTS are reporting new evidence in a medical journal today that antibodies can apparently prevent transmission of the AIDS virus from mother to fetus and subsequent development of the disease in the baby.

Pinnacle in Deal
LEAD: The Pinnacle West Capital Corporation said it had agreed to sell its Malapai Resources Company subsidiary to the American mineral affiliate of a French energy company.
Pinnacle West said it was selling Malapai, a uranium mining company, to Electricite de France for an undisclosed price.
The proceeds of the sale will be used to pay down Pinnacle West's debt.

Renault Dividend
LEAD: The French state-owned car maker Renault said it would pay its shareholders - the French Government and its own employees - their first dividend since 1980.
The payout will be 750 million francs, or $133.4 million.
Of this, 742 million francs, or $131.9 million, will be for the state.
Renault's status as a state agency was altered last week by legislation that allows it to enter into a partnership with Volvo A.B.


Blackhawks Capture Norris Title
LEAD: Jeremy Roenick scored two first-period goals and Steve Larmer and Adam Creighton added short-handed goals tonight, leading the Chicago Blackhawks to an 8-2 victory over the St.
Louis Blues in the decisive seventh game of the Norris Division final.

Sri Lanka Growth Slows
LEAD: Sri Lanka's gross domestic product rose by 2.3 percent in 1989, down from 2.7 percent the previous year, as the economy was affected by civil conflict and bad weather, the central bank said in its 1989 report released today.
The bank described the growth rate as ''very satisfactory'' in light of the conditions.

Baby Found Dead in Garbage
LEAD: A newborn boy was found dead in a plastic garbage bag last night in Brooklyn and a 24-year-old woman who had given birth to the infant was placed under police observation at a hospital.
The baby's body was found in front of 182 East 32d Street in the East Flatbush section.
The mother, Marie Kapley Moliere, was taken to Kings County Medical Center pending the outcome of an autopsy to determine whether the infant had died after birth, the police said.

Livery-Cab Driver in Bronx Is Arrested on Gun Charges

Chronicle
LEAD: JOHN F. KENNEDY JR., an assistant district attorney in Manhattan for the last nine months, has failed the state bar examination a second time.
He will get one more opportunity to pass the grueling 12 1/2-hour, two-day test, said COLLEEN ROCHE, a spokeswoman for the district attorney's office.
If he fails, he will be asked to resign from his $30,000-a-year post.

NASA Is Confident It Can Fix Balky Antenna on Telescope
LEAD: A crucial antenna on the Hubble Space Telescope has lost 25 percent of its maneuvering range, the space agency said yesterday, but NASA engineers said they could compensate for nearly all of the problem.
They said the problem might limit the satellite's flexibility but insisted that the malfunction should not severely hamper its performance in observing the depths of the universe.

Pixar Plans Sale Of Computer Unit
LEAD: Pixar will sell its Image Computer unit to Vicom Systems Inc.

The Rebirth of New York Couture
LEAD: It hardly seemed like a growth industry a few years ago.
In Paris, the citadel of made-to-order clothes, couture designers were turning their energies to ready-to-wear.
With the retirement of Mainbocher in 1972, the only remaining couture designer of stature in New York was Arnold Scaasi.
The designation ''couture'' was being bastardized, with the word frequently used to describe expensive ready-to-wear.

LEAD: THE negligence suit over medical care for Hank Gathers, the Loyola Marymount basketball star who was stricken in a game in March and died within hours, has put the spotlight on the duties, competence and divided allegiances of an unusual group of practitioners: team physicians.

Nations and Unions
LEAD: Underneath, it is the old argument of nations: Are they for better or for worse?
They organize societies, give an expression of cultural community, and can (but don't necessarily) provide the basis for democracy.
They also fight, mobilize peoples against each other and waste their substance in rivalry.

Gerber Ends Plant Tour
LEAD: The Gerber Products Company will end tours of its baby food plant here this week after providing such visits for 78 years.
A Gerber spokesman, Steve Poole, said: ''We know our competition has been through the tour because we've spotted their sales reps.
We can't afford to take any chances.'' Some 15,000 visitors a year have taken the free tour, which covers about 10 percent of the one-million-square-foot plant.

Jackson Journal;   High-Stepping Horses: Persistent Issue of Pain
LEAD: The horse's head bobbed steadily and lightly in contrast to the heavy, muscular movements of its 1,200-pound body.
First one front leg and then the other rose high, rolled and extended far forward while the horse's rear legs seem to glissade close to the ground in a race to keep up.
And all of this to the chords of an organ rendition of ''All Shook Up'' that echoed through the fairgrounds coliseum where the Mississippi Charity Horse Show was held.

Chronicle
LEAD: A piano recital by VLADIMIR FELTSMAN ended on a sour note last Thursday at the Young Men's and Young Women's Hebrew Association of North Jersey, in Wayne.
He cut off his program of Bach, Mozart and Liszt at intermission, complaining that the piano was out of tune.

Talking Business; with Robles Ortega of Osborne;   Effects in Spain Of Liberalization
LEAD: In a program of broad economic liberalization, the Spanish Government has taken the country into the European Community and ended a tradition of protectionism that has endured virtually unchallenged since 1715.
Manuel Robles Ortega recently discussed how this has affected his company.
He is the managing director of Osborne y Cia., the large Spanish producer of Osborne sherry, Conde de Osborne brandy and gourmet ham.

Hershey Net Up 18.6%
LEAD: Buoyed by sales of chocolate and pasta products, the Hershey Foods Corporation said today that its first-quarter earnings rose 18.6 percent.
Company officials said earnings for the quarter that ended on April 1 rose to $47 million, or 52 cents a share, up from $39.6 million, or 44 cents a share, in the comparable period last year.

Move to Suburbs Spurs The Poor to Seek Work
LEAD: Poor black women who have moved from Chicago public housing projects to the suburbs are more likely to find jobs than are women who moved to another neighborhood within the city, researchers at Northwestern University say.

Bank of New York
LEAD: The Bank of New York Company notified the Northeast Bancorp that it had breached its agreement to merge with the Bank of New York by failing to maintain accurate books, records and accounts.

Repairing Ozone Layer
LEAD: THE hole in the Antarctic ozone layer can repair itself by the year 2100, but only if there is a worldwide phase-out of nearly all emissions of chlorofluorocarbons and halon gases early in the next century, NASA scientists say.

LEAD: At the age of 31, and unwanted even by the Dallas Cowboys, Everson Walls still looks good enough for the Giants to have offered him a two-year deal that could be worth $1.25 million.


Chronicle
LEAD: Their careers are widely varied, but they share one common experience: each spent at least a school year at International House, which has housed about 700 graduate students at New York-area colleges each year since its founding in 1924.
Five International House alumni will be honored Wednesday night at a dinner at the Pierre, the first such honors ever bestowed.

Rig Count Down Again
LEAD: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States dropped last week for the fourth straight week, slipping by five, to a total of 927, Baker Hughes reported today.
Despite the recent declines, the current total is well ahead of the 761 rigs counted at this time a year ago.


Bankrupt Ames Hires A Turnaround Expert
LEAD: Ames Department Stores, the discount retailer that filed for bankruptcy last Wednesday, yesterday named a retailer and turnaround expert to help solve its financial problems.


Legal Ripples of Spill Are Said to Distort Big Picture of Damage
LEAD: LIKE a migratory species, marine scientists are flocking back to Prince William Sound for a second summer of research into the effects of the Exxon Valdez oil spill.
But many of them complain that their efforts are being driven largely by legal considerations rather than scientific ones.


Supreme Court Allows Port Authority Suits
LEAD: The United States Supreme Court ruled today that the Port Authority of New York and New Jersey can be sued in Federal court.
The 9-to-0 decision, rejecting the Port Authority's argument that it is constitutionally immune from Federal lawsuits, resolved a conflict between the two Federal judicial circuits in which the agency is located.


New U.S.-Soviet Trade Pact Stirs Criticism in Congress
LEAD: The structure of a new Soviet-American trade agreement, as well as its timing in the midst of the Lithuania independence crisis, is raising opposition in Congress.


Chess
LEAD: ''Yes, it was extreme hypermodernism, but he likes that kind of stuff,'' said the Oakland grandmaster Nick De Firmian about his game with the Soviet grandmaster Zurab Azmayparashvili in the 14th Reykjavik International Open Tournament, which ended March 30 in Iceland.
The smiling De Firmian evidently enjoyed confronting it, too, and dispatched it with businesslike precision.

WORKERS IN KOREA BATTLE RIOT POLICE
LEAD: More than 2,000 riot police officers broke up a strike at the Government-run Korean Broadcasting System television network late Monday.
It was the second time in three days that the authorities have used force to control rising labor unrest.


Homes Less Affordable
LEAD: American homes were less affordable in March as rising mortgage rates and high home prices outstripped increases in average family income, the National Association of Realtors said today.
Families with annual incomes of $33,924 had 104.1 percent of the income needed in March to qualify for a conventional home loan, the trade group said.

While Laughing Gulls Flourish, Airport Officials Fret
LEAD: The laughing gull is making a comeback in the New York area - to the delight of naturalists and the dismay of officials at Kennedy International Airport.
The laughing gull's growing numbers, in a nesting colony on marshes at the end of a busy Kennedy runway, increasingly pose a hazard to planes landing and taking off, the officials say.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
HOCKEY
Soviets Top Canadians
The Soviet Union surprised Canada with four first-period goals and cruised to a 7-1 victory yesterday, setting up a gold-medal game with Czechoslovakia at the world hockey championship in Bern.
The victory by the defending champions gave them 4 points in the medal-round standing, a point ahead of Czechoslovakia.

Review/Music;   Castanets and a Quintet
LEAD: As castanet players go, Lucero Tena is a consummate virtuoso.
Of that, her concert with the Andres Segovia Quintet at Alice Tully Hall on Saturday evening left no doubt.
Effortlessly, it seems, she can play with blinding speed or evenly measured slowness, shattering intensity or delicate stillness; she can achieve any gradation between, and progress smoothly from one to another.


Dow Surprises Some by Rising 12.16 Points
LEAD: Stock prices rose yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average gaining 12.16 points, to 2,668.92.

LEAD: While the auto-industry sales slump eroded the Chrysler Corporation's overall market share and profitability, the company's Jeep line remained a trusty and profitable product.
Jeeps, along with mini-vans, now account for nearly all of the company's automotive profits, some analysts say.

Panel Warned on Banks
LEAD: A trade group representing the securities industry asked Congress today to assure more protection for bank depositors before allowing banks to further expand into the securities business.


Fed Official On Inflation
LEAD: A Federal Reserve governor, John P. LaWare, said today that the nation's high inflation rate in the first quarter might have been an aberration.


St. John's of Many Minds On Sex-Assault Case
LEAD: At a time when college students are usually preoccupied with final examinations and graduation, many at St.
John's University in Queens are also focusing on the case of three students who have been accused of sexual assault and suspended from school.


A Color Fax Machine Will Make Debut in Japan
LEAD: The Sharp Corporation of Japan says it will soon introduce a desktop machine for full-color facsimiles in that country, but has not decided whether to sell the device in the United States because of concerns that American business will find it too expensive and lack needed high-quality telephone lines.


Texas Gets More Time On School Financing
LEAD: A court-imposed deadline for revision of the way Texas finances public education passed today without action by the state, but a judge gave Gov.
William P. Clements Jr. and the Legislature 30 days more to arrive at a plan.

LEAD: THE penny-stock market has had its share of bad publicity and regulatory action of late, with the Securities and Exchange Commission seeking to bar Blinder, Robinson &amp; Company, once the largest penny-stock firm, from the securities business for 45 days.


When Cycle of Lava Flow Changed, Danger Increased
LEAD: The lava flows besieging Hawaii's coastal community of Kalapana are far more damaging than some earlier eruptions of the Kilauea volcano because the lava is moving continuously.

Corrections
LEAD: A report in the Science Watch column of Science Times yesterday about research on latex gloves misstated a finding about leakage.
Eighteen percent of 2,900 gloves leaked water, not viruses.

LEAD: A $159.4 million tax-exempt bond issue by Minneapolis and the Housing and Redevelopment Authority of St.

LEAD: Chevron U.S.A.
Inc. agreed to sell certain Gulf of Mexico oil reserves for about $150 million to a New Orleans-based partnership.

Hewlett-Actel Chip Venture
LEAD: The Hewlett-Packard Company and the Actel Corporation said today that they would cooperate in developing and manufacturing a new family of computer chips.


2 Mohawks Killed in Feud Over Reservation Gambling
LEAD: Two Mohawk Indians were killed today by snipers' bullets in separate shootings on the Canadian side of the St.
Regis Indian Reservation.
They were the first known fatalities in the bitter confrontation there over casino gambling.


The Teacher Salaries Gap
LEAD: The average salary of classroom teachers will pass the $30,000 mark for the first time this year but the gap in teachers' pay among states is still huge, according to statistics compiled by the National Education Association.
The average teacher salary rose to $31,304 for the 1989-90 school year, 5.9 percent higher in current dollars than the previous year's figure of $29,547.


Jean Marie Gee, 87, Dancer and Teacher
LEAD: Jean Marie Gee, a dance teacher and ballerina who created the title role in Sir Frederick Ashton's ''Pomona,'' died on April 18 at the M. B. Anderson Cancer Center in Houston.
She was 87 years old.


A Wright House Is Facing a New Threat
LEAD: A quarter of a century ago, a house that Frank Lloyd Wright designed in the 1940's as part of an experiment in affordable middle-class living, was moved, board by board, to a new site near here to save it from bulldozers that were clearing ground for a superhighway.
Now the house is threatened again.


A Council Panel Back Harsh Fire-Code Fines
LEAD: A New York City Council committee yesterday unanimously approved a bill to stiffen penalties for people responsible for buildings with fire-safety violations, including illegal social clubs.
The bill would also create a temporary commission to study how the city can help clubs run by legitimate community groups comply with safety laws.

In Germany: 4 + 2 - 5
LEAD: A year after Hungary opened the gates and set off an East German stampede to the West, diplomats face the reality of German unification.
But the talks that begin Saturday among the U.S., the Soviet Union, France and Britain - the four - plus the two Germanys concern the Soviet Union's future in Europe as much as the future of Germany.


British Layoffs Foreseen
LEAD: Thousands of jobs will be cut as British factories struggle to stay competitive in the face of rising costs, the Confederation of British Industry predicted today in its latest survey of industrial companies.
Profits are being squeezed by rising labor costs and high interest rates, and domestic demand has been falling, the confederation said.

At the End of The Polls
LEAD: ''There's light at the end of the tunnel,'' a New York politician said the other day upon learning that capital punishment may finally be returning to the Empire State.
What did he have in mind?
Burning at the stake?
Not likely.
Politicians receiving big news tend to grasp for the nearest cliche, and ''light at the end of the tunnel'' happened to be lying around when he heard the cheery news.

Henley said.
If someone didn't like the hamburgers, he could go and talk to Joe, who wasn't afraid of this responsibility.


National Ads Are Sought By Enquirer
LEAD: THE National Enquirer has started a new push to get more national consumer-product advertisers to follow its success with Procter &amp; Gamble.
The Enquirer's owner, the G. P. Group Inc., recently acquired the rival Star in March, which will aid the effort.
The company plans to offer a combination advertising package in the tabloids that it says will deliver more than 30 million readers a week to advertisers.

LEAD: In the hills of Geauga County, 22 miles east of Cleveland, a tiny rest home is doing research that may help the nation's four million Alzheimer's patients, and the families and nursing homes that care for them, get through the daily crises of memory loss, disorientation, wandering and incontinence that mark their decline into dementia.

LEAD: THE Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved the irradiation of poultry to control salmonella and other bacteria that are responsible for an increase in food-borne illnesses in this country.


A Pool Finds a New Life as a Wine Cellar
LEAD: IN his backyard overlooking Indian Creek, Norman Braman walks down the steps of his empty swimming pool, opens the watertight door, and descends into his kidney-shaped wine cellar.


House Backs $24 Billion in Cuts From Bush's Plans for Pentagon
LEAD: The House today narrowly approved the Democratic majority's $1.2 trillion budget for 1991, calling for $24 billion less for the military than President Bush proposed and $5.6 billion more for domestic programs.


Metropolitan Diary
LEAD:
EVOLUTION
On this beautiful spring night
Let us go,
Dear,
To the mall parking lot
To hear the cars sing.
Robins are old hat -
The same every year!
But there's a new Ford, I hear,
Whose whistle will
Knock your socks off.
So let us go to the mall parking lot,
My dear,
To hear the cars sing.

LEAD: John Emil List was sentenced today to five consecutive life terms for the murders of his wife, mother and three children 18 years ago, and as he was led away, the packed courtroom burst into applause.

LEAD: The latest campus of the City University of New York sits on a mountaintop in Japan.
The branch opened this month in Chiyoda, a suburb about 25 miles southwest of Hiroshima.

LEAD: For the 16th month in a row, the number of Soviet Jews arriving in Israel increased sharply in April and for the first time exceeded 10,000, Israeli immigration officials said today.

LEAD: A Federal district judge here is considering a novel extension of First Amendment rights to a religion based primarily on ''absolution'' through sex and ''sacrifice'' through a payment of money.

LEAD: The world's largest hospital supply company, Baxter International Inc., denied today that it had sold a plant in Israel and agreed to build one in Syria to get off the Arab League's blacklist of companies doing business with the Jewish state.

LEAD: Engineers have successfully completed tests of the Hubble Space Telescope's two high-power antennas and both are expected to provide a steady if somewhat restricted flow of communications, the space agency said yesterday.


Economic Scene;   Capital Squeeze: Guess Who Pays
LEAD: IT has never been much fun at the bottom of the third world's economic pecking order, and for millions in Latin America, Africa and the backwaters of Asia, it is grimmer than ever.
Cut off by private lenders in the 1980's, most poor countries have been forced to make ends meet without much help from the industrialized economies.


OPEC Will Meet Today
LEAD: OPEC needs to cut oil production by as much as 1.5 million barrels a day to help crude prices recover from their recent slide, OPEC's president said today as the organization's ministers arrived for an emergency meeting.

Dancer Leaves City Ballet
LEAD: Robert Hill, a principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, has left the company.
The termination of the contract was by mutual agreement, said a spokeswoman for City Ballet and Mr.
Hill, a former member of American Ballet Theater.
Mr.
Hill, who joined City Ballet last year, said he had commitments to dance with the Royal Ballet of London and the Scottish Ballet as a guest artist starting in July, and would have had to be away from New York for much of the winter.

LEAD: Construction spending fell 1.4 percent in March, the steepest decline in more than a year, the Government said today in a report that indicated renewed weakness in the building industry.

LEAD: The first volunteers in an unusual educational experiment have just landed in this tiny Appalachian town - an eager, slightly bewildered group of 183 Japanese students who represent the first full-fledged merger between an American and Japanese college.

LEAD: Jerrico Inc. agreed to sell two restaurant chains, Jerry's and Fazoli's, for undisclosed amounts so that it could concentrate on its Long John Silver's Seafood Shoppes.
Jerry's has 46 restaurants, mainly in Kentucky and Indiana, and Fazoli's has five restaurants in Kentucky.

LEAD: Responding to Democratic proposals on campaign financing, Senate Republicans today introduced an alternative that shifts the focus from limiting spending to eliminating political action committees and barring political activity by any tax-exempt organization.

LEAD: RESTAURANTS around the country are taking liberties with the traditional salade nicoise, adding anything from sun-dried tomatoes to sliced potatoes and beets.
Dishes that are called ''nicoise'' usually include Provencal products like garlic, olives, anchovies, tomatoes and green beans; salade nicoise usually contains tuna, too.

It was the fourth day of a weeklong trip through what is probably the most exciting wine region in the world right now.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
TENNIS
Chang Stunned by Korda
Third-seeded Michael Chang was upset by Peter Korda of Czechoslovakia, 6-7, 7-5, 7-6, yesterday in the first round of the BMW Open in Munich, West Germany.
Chang, playing on European clay for the first time since winning the French Open last June, was not able to come up with the winning shots on the crucial points in the 2-hour-50-minute match.

LEAD: A strong earthquake measuring 6.0 on the Richter scale struck the coast of southern Alaska this morning, the United States Geological Survey said.
Lu Page, a spokeswoman for the agency, said the temblor occurred at 8:12 A.M.
The epicenter was near King Salmon, a small community about 290 miles southwest of Anchorage.

U.S. Steel Output Falls
LEAD: Domestic steel production totaled 1,929,000 net tons for the week that ended on Saturday, down 1.3 percent from the previous week, the American Iron and Steel Institute reported on Monday.
The week's production represented 85.8 percent of the industry's domestic capacity, the steel industry group said.

LEAD: A performance of Verdi's ''Rigoletto'' on June 12 on the Great Lawn of Central Park is to open the Metropolitan Opera's 24th season of free outdoor performances.
The opera will alternate with another Verdi work, ''La Traviata,'' during the three-week series, which is sponsored by Chemical Bank.

LEAD: President Bush will meet with the Lithuanian Prime Minister on Thursday, the White House announced today.

LEAD: The Kinark Corporation, a chemical and metals company, said it had received a buyout offer of $7 a share from Steel Partners L.P.
The bid is subject to the arrangement of financing and other conditions.
One of the conditions is the completion of the previously announced sale of Kinark's hotel properties for at least $12 million.

LEAD: The United States has suspended the Peace Corps program in Liberia and told American diplomats they and their families could leave the country if they chose as fighting between the Liberian Army and rebel forces increased, the State Department said today.

LEAD: The Georgia-Pacific Corporation said that in the wake of its recent acquisition of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, it was exploring the sale of some assets that might not fit its long-term strategy.
It said no final decision had been made on the sale of the assets, which include a linerboard mill at Valdosta, Ga.; a paper mill at Tomahawk, Wis., and certain box plants.

LEAD: After an 11-month decline, the nation's manufacturing economy expanded in April, stimulated by strong levels of new orders, particularly from foreign customers, the nation's purchasing managers reported yesterday.

The Spira and Steinbrenner Relationship Is Confirmed by Their Telephone Records
LEAD: The reason for George Steinbrenner's $40,000 payment to Howard Spira in January might be in dispute, but telephone records leave no doubt that an ongoing relationship between the two existed for three years, primarily through Steinbrenner's chief aide.


Court Victory For Torchmark
LEAD: A Federal district court in Tennessee cleared the way yesterday for shareholders of the American General Corporation to vote today on the Torchmark Corporation's attempt to win a third of the 15 seats on American General's board.
At the annual meeting in


Everglades Fire Is Contained After Blackening 5,500 Acres
LEAD: A drought-fed brush fire was contained today after it burned 5,500 acres of Everglades grassland, a park spokeswoman said.


Soprano Is Recipient Of Richard Tucker Prize
LEAD: Renee Fleming, a soprano, is the recipient of this year's Richard Tucker Award.
The $25,000 cash prize is the largest cash award in United States music competitions.
There were 38 applicants.


A Guilty Plea by Emerson
LEAD: The Emerson Electric Company pleaded guilty today to making inflated cost estimates for electronic equipment it sold the Pentagon and agreed to pay a $40,000 fine and a $14 million civil settlement, the Justice Department said.


Japanese Tunes With Vigor
LEAD: Yosuke Yamashita, a pianist, devoted most of his first set on Wednesday night at Sweet Basil to adaptations of Japanese folk tunes.
But if he hadn't said so, listeners might never have guessed, because he recast the melodies with the spiky harmonies and assertive rhythms of 1960's jazz.


Munsingwear Gets Offer From Jacobs
LEAD: Munsingwear Inc. said the Minneapolis investor Irwin L. Jacobs had offered to make a ''significant cash investment'' in the clothing maker in exchange for an 80 percent equity stake.
It said the proposal was conditioned on the company's ability to redeem $34 million of 8 percent bonds at no more than 25 percent of face value.


Would-Be Payers Fight New York Sales Tax Plan
LEAD: The tentative agreement between Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo and legislative leaders to extend the New York State sales tax to magazines and a number of service industries was attacked by representatives of those industries yesterday.
They said that it would drive many businesses out of the state.

James Brown, a Social Worker With Soul
LEAD: The Godfather of Soul is glad to have a day job.
Two days away from his 57th birthday, James Brown is working here as a spokesman for the Aiken/Barnwell Counties Community Action Commission, a nonprofit agency serving the poor and elderly.
The job keeps him out of jail under a work-release program, and for the moment he is speaking more like a social worker than a rock star.

Home Improvement
LEAD: ALUMINUM siding requires no maintenance to prolong its life.
But to keep it looking its best, many manufacturers recommend washing siding twice a year, and more often in areas with severe air pollution.
Naturally, damaged siding should be promptly repaired.
For washing, a hard spray from a garden hose is usually sufficient.

Threatened Democratic Senate Seats
LEAD: RHODE ISLAND - Both parties call this a top battleground.
Representative Claudine Schneider, a Republican whose district covers half the state, , is almost as well known as Senator Claiborne Pell, who has held the seat since 1961.
His chairmanship of the Foreign Relations Committee is of less interest to Rhode Islanders than the condition of their schools and roads.


Keating Describes U.S. Seizure
LEAD: Testimony at the court hearing on the challenge by Charles H. Keating Jr. of the Government's seizure of his Lincoln Savings and Loan ended today with Mr.
Keating reasserting that his company had been unfairly put in default by the Government.


27 Hurt in Amtrak Derailment
LEAD: A three-car Amtrak train on its way from Chicago to Indianapolis derailed tonight, injuring more than 20 people, the authorities said.
The accident occurred just before 9 P.M. on the eastern edge of Crawfordsville, about 60 miles northwest of Indianapolis.
Amtrak officials said that 27 people were taken to a local hospital and that all but three were treated and released.

Wilander Holds Out
LEAD: Mats Wilander of Sweden, the former No. 1 men's singles player in the world, said yesterday at a news conference in Stockholm he would pass up this month's French Open, which he has won three times, and probably not play this summer at Wimbledon.
Wilander, who has dropped out of the top 10 ranking, has not played competitively since March and will not be in condition to compete in Paris at the end of the month.


Eyeglasses to Fit Any Need or Taste
LEAD: PEOPLE with large heads or very fine features often have trouble finding eyeglass frames that fit properly.
Some adults have bridges so small that only children's glasses will fit, said Joel Name, a Manhattan optician who has been designing frames for 18 years.

Chronicle

Futures Trader Fined
LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange said a futures trader had agreed to a $50,000 fine and a six-month suspension of floor privileges to settle charges of a significant trading offense.
The exchange said in a statement on Tuesday that the trader, Lloyd D. Gabbert, had directed the proceeds last October of certain trades of stock index futures into two accounts, improperly creating a loss in one and a profit in the other.

LEAD: Rampant theft from the New York City Transit Authority now exceeds $2 million a year, with power tools, bus engines and even a new tractor-trailer cab disappearing from warehouses, transit authorities said yesterday.

Dr. Lewis Leary Is Dead at 84; Taught English
LEAD: Dr.
Lewis Leary, a specialist in American literature who was the William Rand Kenan Jr.
Professor of English at the University of North Carolina from 1968 to 1976, died of pneumonia on Tuesday at his home in Chapel Hill, N.C.
He was 84 years old.


Indian Reservation Sealed Off After 2 Killings
LEAD: Hundreds of New York and Canadian police officers sealed off this Mohawk reservation on the St.
Lawrence River today after violence left two Mohawks dead and forced thousands of others to barricade themselves in their homes or flee.


Lee Sievan; Photographer, 82
LEAD: Lee Sievan, a photographer, died of a cerebral hemorrhage on Tuesday at Roosevelt Hospital in Manhattan.
She was 82 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Sergio Franchi, 57, An Opera Aspirant Who Won Pop Fame
LEAD: Sergio Franchi, a singer with operatic ambitions who gained fame in nightclubs and on recordings, died of a brain tumor on Tuesday at his home in Stonington.
He never publicly revealed his age, although some sources list it as 57.

Q&amp;A
LEAD: An Inside Vapor Barrier Q.Our house was built in 1921 with tongue-and-groove and clapboard siding, and with blown-in cellulose insulation in the walls.
I am having vinyl siding and an insulating barrier installed on the outside, and since there is no vapor barrier on the inside of these walls I am concerned about moisture being trapped in the hollow wall spaces.

LEAD: Canadian Pacific Ltd. said its shareholders had overwhelmingly approved a proposal to spin off 80 percent of its Marathon Realty Company into a separate company.

Bridge
LEAD: When is a tournament not a tournament?
Since a tournament is by definition a collection of players in one location, the answer is when it's a club sectional.
In this contest, played last week in New York City, the players competed in their own clubs, but were scored overall.


Robert A. Wesselmann; U.S. Official, 68
LEAD: Robert A. Wesselmann, a longtime officer of the Agency for International Development, died of lung cancer on April 19 at his home in Fort Plain, N.Y.
He was 68 years old.
He joined the State Department in 1953 and was assigned to the Point Four program, which became the A.I.D. before his retirement in 1973.


House Panel Stalls on Member's Conduct
LEAD: The House ethics committee, which has met periodically for the last seven months on the case of Representative Barney Frank, appears to have reached an impasse over how to deal with his involvement with a male prostitute.

Light Resets Body Rhythms for the Night Worker

Six, the Magic Number
LEAD: In the unlikely but not impossible event that the Democrats lose control of the Senate this year, they'd do well if they gave up only five seats, no more, no less.
That would result in a party tie at 50-50, and give the Republicans control only by virtue of Vice President Quayle's tie-breaking vote.

Close to Home
LEAD: I HAVE been reading about New York lately, A. J. Liebling's New York.
I used to read Liebling in The New Yorker, but that was a long time ago and his subjects were mostly politics and boxing.
Politics interests me, especially when the pols are rapscallions, as Liebling's usually were, but boxing not at all.

$25 Million Loan Backed for Ames
LEAD: Ames Department Stores Inc. has won approval from a bankruptcy court to borrow $25 million, sending its stock higher as investors grew more confident about the prospects for the troubled discount retailer.
The Rocky Hill, Conn., company told Federal Bankruptcy Judge Howard Buschman 3d that it needed the funds to pay suppliers and continue operating.

LEAD: Bob Engel, the National League umpire suspended indefinitely after being accused of stealing baseball cards from a Target store in Bakersfield, Calif., on April 21, faces a new charge of trying to shoplift cards from another store in Bakersfield, his hometown.

LEAD: President Lee Teng-hui picked the country's top military official today to be Prime Minister.

Corporate Relocations
LEAD: Dallas and Houston were the two top cities for corporate relocations in 1989, as cheaper costs made the Southwest an attractive destination, according to a study of 37,000 corporate moves by PHH Homequity.
New York slipped to fourth place from second last year, and Chicago slipped to fifth place from third.

Illinois Death Penalty Is Upheld
LEAD: A Federal appeals court has upheld the state's death penalty law, opening the way for Illinois's first execution in 28 years.


Afghan's Chief Vows to Stay in Office
LEAD: President Najibullah, Kabul's Soviet-backed leader, vowed today to stay in office, scorning any suggestion that he turn over power to an interim government while competing in internationally supervised elections that the United States and the Soviet Union have discussed as the centerpiece of a possible peace settlement.


Review/Art;   The Power of Whimsy: Jean Arp's Later Work
LEAD: Sculptor, collagist, poet, painter and maker of famously whimsical drawings and bas-reliefs, Jean (he also went by the name Hans) Arp had already secured a place for himself in the history of 20th-century art before his 30th birthday, in 1916.
Arp was among the pioneers of abstraction.
By 1912, he had exhibited with Henri Matisse, Paul Klee, Robert Delaunay and Wassily Kandinsky, who was one of his early enthusiasts.

LEAD: Sales of domestically produced cars and light trucks rose 2.4 percent in the last 10 days of April, compared with a year earlier, the auto makers reported today.


Children's Tours
LEAD: Free walking tours of midtown Manhattan, designed for those 8 to 14 years old, will be sponsored for the next three Saturdays by the Grand Central Partnership.

LEAD: The governing Conservative Party suffered another setback today as British voters gave strong support to the opposition Labor Party in nationwide local elections.

LEAD: The campaign headquarters of former Gov.
Evan Mecham were damaged early today by the second suspicious fire there in the last two days, the police said.
Mr.
Mecham, who is again running for governor after his removal from office by the Legislature two years ago, was not present, and no one was injured.


William Cahalan, Judge, 64
LEAD: William Cahalan, a judge who was a former Michigan Racing Commissioner and Wayne County prosecutor, died of cancer on Wednesday at his home.
He was 64 years old.


Study Says Lasix Improves a Horse's Speed but Not Its Health
LEAD: A long-awaited study of Lasix, a drug administered to many race horses across the country ostensibly to prevent bleeding from their lungs, has concluded that the medication makes horses run faster without necessarily helping the problem it is prescribed to treat.

LEAD: The Mets did not lose to the Cincinnati Reds last night because of what unfolded in a tortuous eighth inning.
But there was enough crammed into a series of errors, Reds stolen bases and Met pratfalls to give more than a good indication why the team is now in a last-place tie with the St.
Louis Cardinals in the National League East.

Rules Waived to Permit Use Of AIDS Drug by Children
LEAD: Waiving its usual rules for drug testing for the first time, the Food and Drug Administration yesterday approved AZT as a treatment for AIDS virus infections in children.


Long Island City Artists Open Studios for Tours
LEAD: Artists living and working in Long Island City, Queens, will open their work spaces to the public this weekend.
More than 70 artists are taking part in free tours and exhibitions that will run from noon to 6 P.M. today through Sunday.


European Utility Plan
LEAD: The European Community Executive Commission said on Wednesday that it planned to spend $363 million to improve and expand natural gas and electricity systems.
The projects in the three-year plan include introducing natural gas in Portugal and Greece, connecting gas networks in Ireland and Britain, and linking electricity networks in Italy and Greece.


Fuji Agrees to Buy Rest of Subaru in U.S.
LEAD: Fuji Heavy Industries Ltd., the Japanese maker of Subaru cars, said today that it had agreed to buy the half of Subaru of America Inc. it did not own in a deal valued at $412.2 million.


Millard Pleads Guilty
LEAD: Keith Millard, the Minnesota Vikings All-Pro defensive lineman, pleaded guilty yesterday to careless driving in connection with a January incident in which he was arrested on a drunken driving charge.
Hennepin County District Judge Herbert Worlner sentenced the 28-year-old Millard to 48 hours of community service and 12 months probation.


Rebuilding Neighborhoods;   Old Trenton Warehouse Will Now Hold Condos
LEAD: A 19th-century brick warehouse in one of Trenton's oldest sections has become a symbol of this city's industrial past and of its future as a contemporary urban address.


OPEC Pact Reached on Output Cut
LEAD: Members of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries agreed at an emergency meeting today to stop producing oil above their previously agreed upon quotas, hoping to end the oversupply that has driven prices down 25 percent this year.


Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 509 money market mutual funds decreased by $2.14 billion, to $385.72 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 161 institutional funds increased by $1.71 billion, to $92.32 billion.
The assets of the 246 general-purpose funds were down by $912.60 million, to $132.70 billion.


Owner of News Rejects Proposal on New Plants
LEAD: The president of the company that owns The New York Daily News today formally rejected a proposal by the newspaper's unions that The News guarantee the construction of new plants in exchange for labor concessions.

LEAD: Trustees of Mills College, one of the nation's oldest schools for women, voted today to admit male undergraduates for the first time in its 138-year history.

LEAD: Carl C. Icahn, the chairman of Trans World Airlines Inc., outlined a plan this week to union leaders under which America West Airlines Inc. would take over T.W.A.'s domestic routes, including the hub at St.
Louis.

Debut for Handel and Haydn Ensemble
LEAD: The Handel and Haydn Society Chamber Ensemble will give its first New York performace on Sunday at 4 P.M. at Corpus Christi Church, 529 West 121st Street.
The period-instrument group from Boston will play an all-Bach program featuring the harpsichordists, John Finney and James David Christie (the group's director) and John Finney in the double harpsichord concertos in C (BWV 1061) and C minor (BWV 1062).

L. Nicholas Ruwe, Ex-Ambassador, 56; Assisted Presidents
LEAD: L. Nicholas Ruwe, a former United States Ambassador to Iceland and a Republican Party stalwart, died of cancer on Wednesday at the Mayo Clinic in Rochester, Minn.
He was 56 years old and lived in Washington.


Slower Rise In Costs of Commercials
LEAD: THE days of skyrocketing commercial production costs appear to be ending, as lavish song-and-dance ads, high production-company markups and competitive bidding among producers fade from view, according to a new study by the American Association of Advertising Agencies.


News's Job Guarantees Still Valid, Panel Rules
LEAD: Lifetime job guarantees that were given to printers at The Daily News in 1973 are still valid and will remain so unless the union elects to reopen the issue, the National Labor Relations Board has ruled.


The Killing Fields
LEAD: Suppose a Nazi army had stayed intact at the end of World War II, and held out in a remote area with Hitler, Goering and Himmler.
Then imagine an American Government insisting that the Nazis must be included in arrangements for a German political settlement.

LEAD: Angami Zapu Phizo, who fought for independence for the northeastern Indian state of Nagaland and was condemned to death in absentia, died in British exile on Monday, officials at the Indian High Commission said today.

China Sees a Big Crop
LEAD: Chinese agricultural officials predict a bumper grain harvest in 1990 and foreign analysts said this could lead to a reduction in imports, especially from the United States.
China, the biggest buyer of American wheat, has purchased nearly 14 million metric tons of grain from the United States in the last two years.

Mary Lea Johnson Richards, 63, Founder of Production Company
LEAD: Mary Lea Johnson Richards, a founder and partner of the Producer Circle, a New York film and theatrical production company, died yesterday at Presbyterian University Hospital in Pittsburgh, where she had a liver transplant two weeks ago.
She was 63 years old and had homes in New York, Southampton, L.I., and Boca Raton,


Deutsch's Campaign For Ikea Furniture
LEAD: Deutsch's first major campaign for Ikea, the Swedish furniture maker, tries to show what is wrong with the other stores.
The agency constructed a series of television commercials out of bites of film shot at the other furniture retailers.
As edited by Deutsch, other stores look silly: they specialize to a fault, bore kids to death, always run ''sales'' and hire goofy salesmen and inept truckers.


Correction
LEAD: A brief Associated Press article in some copies yesterday about President Bush's Federal income taxes incorrectly described the Zapata Corporation, which Mr.
Bush once headed.
Zapata, an offshore oil drilling and commercial fishing company, is still in operation in Houston.

Joffrey and Choreographer Agree to Negotiate
LEAD: The Joffrey Ballet plans to start negotiations today with Gerald Arpino and his lawyer, Harold Messing, on whether the company can stage Mr.
Arpino's ballets.
The dances were withdrawn by Mr.
Arpino when he resigned as artistic director of the Joffrey on Tuesday.


20th Anniversary at Kent State
LEAD: Residents of Kent and the surrounding community flocked to the Kent State University campus today to see a new memorial that is to be dedicated on Friday, the 20th anniversary of the slaying of four students by Ohio National Guardsmen.
Speakers at the dedication of the abstract memorial - four granite slabs flanked by a walkway - will include Florence Schroeder, whose son was among those slain, and Dean Kahler, now an Athens County Commissioner, who was among the nine wounded by the guardsmen's gunfire.


Newark's New Image Buoys Mayor on Eve of Election
LEAD: Every city has its symbol, and Newark's may still be the 1967 riots that scorched the city and left 23 people dead.
But Sharpe James, a believer in the strength of symbols, has spent as much time over his four years as mayor trying to change that image as he has trying to solve the most serious problems.


Throwing Caution Aside, Oakley Saves the Knicks
LEAD: Early in the second period, during a timeout in Wednesday night's game, Charles Oakley tore off the plastic soft cast that protected the healing bone in his left hand and tossed it at Tim Walsh, the Knicks' assistant trainer.

Apple Bancorp Courting Suitors
LEAD: Seeking to elude a hostile $38-a-share bid by its biggest stockholder, Apple Bancorp Inc. said it had received buyout interest from several parties it did not identify.
The banking company is seeking bids of $45 to $55 a share to compete against the offer by its largest individual shareholder, the New York real estate investor Stanley Stahl.

LEAD: The Link-Miles Simulation Corporation will build control-room simulators for Soviet nuclear power plants in a joint venture to improve nuclear safety in the Soviet Union.
Link-Miles, a subsidiary of the Bicoastal Corporation of Tampa, has formed the partnership with N.P.O.
Energia, a division of the Soviet Ministry of Atomic Energy.

WEEKENDER GUIDE
LEAD:
FRIDAY
FLAMENCO AND NEWER STEPS


Evolution in Europe;   NATO ADOPTS PLAN TO REVAMP ITSELF FOR GERMAN UNITY
LEAD: NATO adopted a package of proposals today for transforming the Western military alliance into more of a political organization and making membership in NATO by a unified Germany acceptable to the Soviet Union and the German people.


Film Schedule
LEAD: The Museum of Modern Art section of the series Internal Exile: New Films and Videos From Chile runs today through Monday.
All the films have English subtitles.
Tickets to screenings are included in the price of museum admission: $6 ($3.50 for students, $3 for the elderly).
Information: 708-9490.
A free video program, featuring seven short pieces, will be shown May 11 and 12 at Exit Art, 578 Broadway, near Prince Street.


Democrats Propose Bill on Campaign Finance
LEAD: As the Senate prepares to debate the way Senate campaigns are financed and run, Democrats today proposed a package of measures that included voluntary spending limits, partial public financing and a ban on direct contributions to candidates by political action committees.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''Freedom, like a genie that's been let out of the bottle, doesn't necessarily want to listen to the dictates of the person who uncorked the bottle.''
- Prime Minister Kazimiera Prunskiene of Lithuania.
[A9:5.]


The Involuntary Heroes
LEAD: Ignore for a moment the vexed question of how best to free the 16 remaining Western hostages in Lebanon.
What sears the conscience is the drawn face and the unselfish anger of Frank Herbert Reed after three and a half years of captivity.


Ex-Nazi Is Sent to Germany In Extradition by Argentina
LEAD: Josef Schwammberger was returned to West Germany today, the first known Nazi war criminal to be extradited from Argentina.

Reviews/Music;   Flair Amid the Sobriety
LEAD: Beneath a carefully cultivated glamorous image, the West German violinist Anne-Sophie Mutter is a serious and thoughtful artist, as she demonstrated again in her recital with the pianist Lambert Orkis at Carnegie Hall on Sunday evening.


Hope Williams, 92, Actress, Dies; Starred in Philip Barry Comedies
LEAD: Hope Williams, a debutante with a carefree manner, boyishly clipped blond hair and a humorous walk, who was a leading Broadway actress in the late 1920's and 30's, died of cardiac arrest last night at her home in Manhattan.
She was 92 years old.


Review/Theater;   2 Caryl Churchill Plays Show Dark Side of 80's
LEAD: Attending a Caryl Churchill play is asking to get one's face slapped, repeatedly, frequently and with vicious force. ''Ice Cream With Hot Fudge,'' as the English writer calls her new pair of one-act comedies at the Public Theater, is short in length but bottomless in its cynicism about citizens of the Thatcher-Reagan 1980's on both sides of the Atlantic.


Congress Told of Abuses in Stock Index Futures Trading
LEAD: James Coxon, head of stock investments for the Cigna Corporation, told Congress today that some traders used advance knowledge of customer plans to make profitable trades on the stock index futures market.


Dollar Mixed, Gold Higher; British Election Is Watched
LEAD: The dollar finished mixed against other primary foreign currencies yesterday as many traders stayed on the sidelines awaiting results from British elections and today's release of employment figures.
Gold prices advanced modestly.
Britons voted in local elections in the first comprehensive test of the Conservative Party's popularity since Prime Minister Margaret

Injured Behrens Cancels Final Brunnhilde at Met
LEAD: The soprano Hildegard Behrens has withdrawn from tomorrow night's performance of Wagner's ''Gotterdammerung'' at the Metropolitan Opera.
The company said a replacement for the role of Brunnhilde would be named today.


Philadelphia Inquirer Loses Libel Suit
LEAD: A jury decided today that The Philadelphia Inquirer had recklessly defamed one of the city's most prominent lawyers and must pay him $34 million.
Experts said the award was the largest ever handed up by a jury in a libel case against an American news organization.


New President Chosen At Deprenyl of Toronto
LEAD: Deprenyl Research Ltd., a Toronto company that has received approval to market a drug to treat Parkinson's disease in Canada, has named James P. Doherty, a seasoned pharmaceutical industry executive, as its new president and chief operating officer.

Everglades Fire Leaps Canal, Imperiling a Wildlife Preserve
LEAD: A four-mile-wide brush fire raced through dry Everglades sawgrass today, jumping a canal where officials had hoped to stop it and threatening 150,000 acres of a wildlife preserve.

Stutter-Step Democracy in Korea
LEAD: Thousands of riot police storm the world's largest shipyard, at Ulsan, South Korea, to break up a strike and sit-in by workers.
Two days later, they club strikers at the Government-run Korean Broadcasting System.
Is this the new democratic South Korea?

Memories of Tyranny, in Chilean Films
LEAD: A CHILEAN photographer is called to a dangerous political rendezvous where he may find a trace of information about his brother, who disappeared a dozen years before.
If he refuses the meeting, he asks himself, ''What will save me from suicide?'' Yet how can he carry on a normal life with his wife and small son if he is obsessed with his brother's disappearance?


New Pair on N.B.A.
LEAD: Marv Albert and Bob Costas will be NBC's primary announcers on National Basketball Association telecasts, the network said yesterday.
Costas and Albert will split play-by-play and host assignments during the regular season and playoffs.

Slain Judges and Lawyers
LEAD: More than 270 lawyers, judges and other legal professionals worldwide were killed or persecuted last year, in part because of their association with unpopular causes or because they championed human rights, a legal watchdog group said Tuesday.

Topics of The Times;   Lessons From the First Lady
LEAD: What can you learn from Barbara Bush?
Not much, in the view of 150 young women graduating from Wellesley College.
They are protesting her selection as this year's commencement speaker.
Since ''Wellesley teaches that we will be rewarded on the basis of our own merit, not on that of a spouse,'' they say the First Lady is an unworthy choice.


Evolution in Europe;   Ties for Israel and Bulgaria
LEAD: Israel and Bulgaria restored diplomatic relations today after a 23-year break and signed an agreement that covers air transportation, telecommunications, tourism, agriculture, mutual protection of investments and dealings between banks.
Bulgaria and other Eastern bloc countries broke relations with Israel after the 1967 war.


Banker Guilty In Theft Case
LEAD: A former Citibank executive was convicted of stealing $25 million worth of securities, Federal prosecutors said yesterday.


Claim of Church Based on Sex Is Ruled Out
LEAD: A Federal judge today rejected a couple's claim that their Church of the Most High Goddess, a religion based on sex, was protected by the Constitution and was thus immune from the enforcement of vice laws.

Review/Film;   Of AIDS, Frustration And Fury
LEAD: At the start of ''Silence Equals Death,'' one of two new documentaries by Rosa von Praunheim about the range of responses to the AIDS plague, a man tells the camera he has tested HIV positive for the AIDS virus.
He talks briefly and angrily about his feelings, then suddenly lowers his pants and seems to shoot himself anally with a pistol at very close camera range.

The fleecing of the client, a cautionary report about the lawyer's conflict of interest.
LEAD: ''Tell me a man is dishonest, and I will answer he is no lawyer,'' Daniel Webster told the Charleston, S.C., bar in 1847. ''He cannot be, because he is careless and reckless of justice; the law is not in his heart, is not the standard and rule of his conduct.''

Bruins Use Discipline to Offset Mistakes
LEAD: Discipline, the quality that becomes such an enormous factor in the Stanley Cup playoffs, surfaces in a variety of forms.
It means knowing when not to fight and when not to panic.
And once in a while, it can mean nothing so much as taking your time when you've been given the advantage.


Avant Garde Music, The Bouquet of May
LEAD: A picture caption in Weekend last Friday, with an article about avant-garde music, misidentified the musician and instrument shown.
Adam Weisman was playing the surrogate kithara.
LEAD: AVANT-GARDE MUSIC bubbles up from the New York City pavement pretty much year round, but the flow increases each spring.
Those who savor the stuff might prefer a more benign metaphor, one that equates new music in the spring with, say, budding blossoms.


BMW-Rolls-Royce Jet-Engine Deal
LEAD: Bayerischen Motoren Werke A.G., the West German maker of luxury cars, said it would acquire an aerospace technology line from Kloeckner-Humboldt-Deutz A.G. and then merge the company into a venture with Rolls-Royce P.L.C. of Britain.
BMW said the return to the aircraft engine business after 31 years reflected the company's desire to expand into new, though related, industries.

Metro Datelines;   O.K., It's Fiction, Movie Will Note
LEAD: Warner Brothers, responding to accusations of Bronx-bashing in its film adaptation of ''The Bonfire of the Vanities,'' has agreed to tack on a standard disclaimer at the end of the movie.

LEAD: Because of a parade honoring the the New York City Fire Department, the Avenue of the Americas will be closed tomorrow from Spring Street to 14th Street from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M.


BUSH NAMES CHOICE TO SUCCEED CHIEF OF SAVINGS RESCUE
LEAD: President Bush said today that he wanted William Taylor, the Federal Reserve Board's top banking regulator, to succeed L. William Seidman as head of the Government's savings and loan bailout when Mr.
Seidman steps down.


Tribune Chief To Step Down
LEAD: Stanton Cook said today that he would step down as chief executive of the Tribune Company, which publishes The Daily News in New York, The Chicago Tribune and other newspapers.


Soviet Law May Block Estonia and Latvia
LEAD: To the Editor:


Criminal Justice, Arrested
LEAD: After a police officer arrested Robert Johnson for hustling tokens from subway passengers, it took New York City's criminal justice agencies the better part of three days to charge him with misdemeanors that carry only brief sentences.
His case typifies thousands that prompted Justice Brenda Soloff to rule in favor of a Legal Aid lawsuit asking for more prompt arraignments.

Economic Scene;   Can U.S. Recover In Electronics?
LEAD: THE Japanese Government's reported plan to organize an industrial effort to develop an advanced computer technology known as massively parallel processing, in which the United States now holds a substantial lead, heightens American anxieties.
Some Americans already believe that Japan has a master strategy for achieving dominance in all areas of electronics technology and thereby becoming the world's greatest industrial power.

LEAD: As talks between the South African Government and the African National Congress continued for a second day, a senior official of the Congress said today that other organizations should be represented at eventual negotiations on the country's future.

Washington Post's Net Off
LEAD: The Washington Post Company today reported a 6 percent decline in first-quarter earnings, attributing the weaker results to lower advertising sales at three important divisions.


Germany's K.H.D. To Spin Off Unit
LEAD: The West German machinery maker Kloeckner-Humboldt-Deutz A.G. agreed to spin off its American farm machinery subsidiary, the Deutz-Allis Corporation, to the division's management and an unidentified ''financial group.'' No other details were disclosed.
K.H.D. acquired Deutz-Allis in 1985.
The Atlanta-based farm equipment maker had sales of $307 million last year.

International
A3-10
NATO adopted a group of proposals for transforming the Western military alliance into more of a political organization and making membership in NATO by a unified Germany acceptable to the Soviet Union and the German people.

News analysis: The NATO alliance and the European Community are making their major decisions about the future in the shadow of German strength and Soviet weakness.

Cigna Net Falls by Half
LEAD: The Cigna Corporation said today that its earnings fell by half in the first quarter, partly because of large claims resulting from severe winter storms in Europe.
The big insurance company said profits fell to $42 million, or 54 cents a share, from $85 million, or $1.02 a share, in 1989.
Revenues fell slightly, to $3.8 billion, from $3.6 billion.

France Enacts Penalties for Inciting Racism
LEAD: Apparently in reponse to an increase in violence against Arab immigrants, the French National Assembly approved a bill today that would bar anyone found guilty of inciting race hatred from holding elected office or Government jobs.

Our Towns;   One Great Scorer Marks How They Play the Game
LEAD: The Army game the other day was a crucial contest for Adelphi's lacrosse squad.
It didn't start well.
After a quarter, Adelphi, a perennial top 20 team, trailed 4 to 3.
The players huddled, listening as coaches mapped strategy.
It was unseasonably hot.
Already they were drenched in sweat.
Players yanked off helmets, sucking wind.


Defense Loses Bid to Shift Killing Blame
LEAD: The judge in the Bensonhurst trial indicated yesterday that he would limit defense efforts to link the killing of Yusuf K. Hawkins to Gina Feliciano, the white girl who had invited black and Hispanic friends to the predominantly white neighborhood.

LEAD: Robert Lake was suspended for 60 days by the New York State Racing and Wagering Board because two of the horses he trains tested positive for a banned substance after races on the same day last month.

LEAD: Integrated Prayer For the first time in more than 50 years, there is a Jewish congregation in the Soviet Union where men and women can sit together during prayer.

Interest Rates Fall On Job Data
LEAD: Interest rates plunged yesterday, as prices of Treasury securities soared in response to news of an unexpectedly small increase in nonfarm employment in April.
Only 64,000 non-farm jobs were added in April, and the unemployment rate rose by two-tenths of 1 percent, to 5.4 percent, its highest level in 15 months.


Channel 4 Holds Viewers With Suicide Report
LEAD: A Channel 4 news anchor said yesterday that he and the station came close to acting irresponsibly on Thursday by heavily promoting during an episode of ''L.A.
Law'' a report about the death, apparently by suicide, of an actor who had appeared as a guest on the program.
The promotions, which never identified the actor, David Rappaport, continued throughout the news broadcast.

Record Time Rejected
LEAD: A clocking of 45.04 seconds for the 400-meter run by Danny Everett of the United States in February has been rejected as a possible indoor world record because the race had an improperly staggered start and the runners stayed in their lanes for the entire race.


Computer Intruder Is Put on Probation And Fined $10,000
LEAD: Saying the punishment of prison did not fit the crime, a Federal judge today placed a 24-year-old computer science student on three years' probation for intentionally disrupting a nationwide computer network.
The student, Robert Tappan Morris, was also fined $10,000 and ordered to perform 400 hours of community service.


Mortgage Rates Rise
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.67 percent this week, their highest rate since May 1989, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
Last week they were at 10.56 percent.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.62 percent this week, up from 8.56 percent the week before.


Chinese Envoy Seeks Asylum
LEAD: A Chinese diplomat said today that he was seeking political asylum in the United States because he supports the democracy movement in China.
The diplomat, Xu Lin, said his duties at the Chinese Embassy here had included assisting Chinese students with the renewal of their passports.

The Slow but Steady Progress In Stopping Tap-Water Burns
LEAD: Every day, safety experts say, about 300 young children are taken to emergency rooms around the country suffering from burns caused by household water that is too hot.
And annually, about 3,000 children are injured seriously enough in such accidents to require hospitalization.

Unemployment Rate Rises to 5.4 Percent
LEAD: The Labor Department reported today that the unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a point last month, to 5.4 percent, its highest level in more than a year, blunting fears of accelerated inflation and higher interest rates.


Thomas J. Bigham, 79, Priest and a Professor
LEAD: The Rev.
Dr.
Thomas James Bigham, an Episcopal priest and a professor of ethics and moral theology at the General Theological Seminary in Manhattan for more than 30 years, died of pneumonia on April 28 at his home in New Orleans.
He was 79 years old.


Sheridan Journal;   Stunned by Suicides, A Town Asks, 'Why?'
LEAD: A boy of 17 with the stolid name of Thomas Smith got up to address his 11th grade American history class at Sheridan High School shortly after 1 P.M. on Monday, told a girl in the class that he loved her, then pulled a .22-caliber pistol from a pocket, pressed it to his forehead and pulled the trigger.


Mason Hale, 61, Dies; Smithsonian Botanist
LEAD: Mason E. Hale, a botanist at the Smithsonian Institution who was known internationally, died of cancer on Monday at his home in Arlington, Va.
He was 61 years old.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on April 26 about legislation that would ban assault rifles in Connecticut described the legal status of fully automatic weapons incorrectly.
Federal law prohibits private ownership of such weapons made after May 1986.
Many states ban ownership regardless of the date of manufacture.

She was 65 years old and lived in Bayville, L.I.

Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about a Democratic proposal to change the financing of political campaigns overstated contributions that five Senators received from Charles H. Keating Jr.

Twelve Players Fined
LEAD: Horace Grant of the Chicago Bulls and Alvin Robertson of the Milwaukee Bucks have been fined $5,000 apiece for throwing punches in a playoff game, the National Basketball Association announced yesterday.
Ten other players involved in the altercation Thursday night were fined a total of $9,000.(AP)


CHRONICLE
LEAD: America's first astronauts were men in their 30's.
By the late 1960's men in their 40's were making space voyages and with the joint American-Soviet space rendezvous in 1975, the first astronaut in his 50's went into space.
Now the 60-year-old age barrier is on the verge of falling.
On Wednesday, VANCE BRAND will be 59 years old; one week later, he is to command the space shuttle Columbia for a 9- or 10-day space trip during which he and other astronauts will put into orbit telescopes to retrieve scientific data on the universe as part of the $100 million Astro program.

Evolution in Europe;   Statesman Elected in Greece
LEAD: Parliament elected Constantine Karamanlis as President today, making the 83-year-old conservative elder statesman the head of state for the next five years.
Mr.
Karamanlis mustered the support of 153 of the 300 deputies in Parliament - 2 more than the required minimum of 151.
His New Democracy Party, now led by Constantine Mitsotakis, won a thin working majority in Parliament in elections last month.

Review/Music;   Murray in Franck Marathon
LEAD: Cesar Franck will be remembered in part as the man who brought the dreams and grandeur of the Romantic movement to the organ.
Grandiloquence was always the instrument's second nature, but Franck's drifting, languid expository style and the richness of his chromatic harmony transformed ceremonial brilliance into something more personal.

LEAD: The Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation said it spent nearly $107 million in the first quarter in its failed attempt to fend off a takeover bid from the Georgia-Pacific Corporation.

CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   Investment Mixtures
LEAD: Individual investment portfolios should be reviewed regularly because market conditions and individual goals change.
In general, stocks increase immediate wealth, while debt securities like bonds, certificates of deposit and debentures, provide future income.
Now, in the second quarter of the year, many strategists still favor stocks for the lead component in portfolios.

Triumph of Spite, Retribution and a Cat
''Tales From the Darkside'' is subtitled ''The Movie'' because tales like these are so familiar in other forms: as campfire stories, horror comics, television shows (with less gruesome special effects) and novels by Stephen King, one of whose stories is the basis for an episode here.
So nothing about ''Tales From the Darkside'' is likely to give anyone much of a scare.
But thanks to casting that is savvier than the horror norm, and to direction by John Harrison that is workmanlike and sometimes even witty, at least it's fun.
Spite plays an important role here, especially for the mummy in the film's first episode (''Lot 249,'' adapted from a story by Sir Arthur Conan Doyle) who tries out certain embalming techniques on a spoiled, modern-day college boy.
Christian Slater and Steve Buscemi play fellow students engaged in a battle of wits, with the mummy as a dangerously lively pawn.
Spite also matters to the black cat in the film's middle installment, who is intent on killing the pharmaceuticals tycoon (William Hickey) who has developed a special drug with the help of 5,000 feline victims.

Volkert to Replace Behrens
LEAD: The soprano Gudrun Volkert will replace Hildegard Behrens as Brunnhilde in tonight's performance of ''Gotterdammerung'' at the Metropolitan Opera.
Miss Behrens was injured by falling scenery at the end of last Saturday night's performance of the same opera and had to withdraw from ''Die Walkure'' on Tuesday night and ''Siegfried'' on Thursday.

Israel Accused of Firing at Hussein's Yacht
LEAD: An Israeli Navy boat fired at the yacht of King Hussein of Jordan as the King was standing on deck, an Israeli newspaper reported today.
An Israeli military spokesman said the navy vessel did not fire at the King's yacht but in another direction, as part of a routine weapons check.


2d Man Held in Bronx Killing
LEAD: A second suspect was arrested yesterday in the killing of a gypsy-cab driver in the Bronx two weeks ago, the police said.
The cabby, Mian Mohammed Salim, 48 years old, was the sixth gypsy-cab driver slain in the Bronx in seven weeks.
He was shot in the head, apparently in a robbery.
The suspect, Orlando Hernandez, 22, of 1197 Grand Concourse in the High Bridge section of the Bronx, turned himself in to the police in Miami.He is charged with second-degree murder.

Alan H. Shure Dies; Manufacturer Was 59
LEAD: Alan H. Shure, co-founder, chairman and chief executive of the International Components Corporation, an electronics manufacturer based in Chicago, died Wednesday at Northwestern Memorial Hospital in Chicago, after a brief illness.
He was 59 years old and lived in Chicago and Nederland, Colo.

LEAD:
Seidman's Turn


Bridge
LEAD: Scores of over 75 percent are quite rare in tournament play, but one was achieved last week in the Greater New York Bridge Association's club sectional.
The players involved were John Scheuermann and Charles Whitney, playing at the Culbertson Club, 24 Fifth Avenue, and they were helped by the diagramed deal.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in Sports Pages yesterday about Greg LeMond, the cycling champion, described his 1987 hunting accident incorrectly in some copies.
He was shot by a brother in-law; the wound was not self-inflicted.


Power Struggle Said to Surround Redistricting of New York City
LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins's seven appointees on the commission that is to re-draw district lines next year for an expanded New York City Council are trying to wrest the chairmanship of the commission from the eight Council appointees, people involved in the struggle said yesterday.


Knick Defense Makes Celtics' Offense Wilts
LEAD: The Knicks' defense was dreadful a week ago, but it was dominant last night.
They harassed the Boston Celtics into 26 turnovers.
They made 18 steals.
And their constant pressure transformed Boston, a team that prides itself on poise, into a frazzled team that unraveled before a delirious crowd at Madison Square


Douglas Computer Bankruptcy Filing
LEAD: Douglas Computer filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection, after one of its banks decided against giving it more credit.
The Salt Lake City-based company said that it was in talks for financing with other individuals to allow it to continue operations but that there was no guarantee any arrangement would be reached.


Keep Community Safe
LEAD: To the Editor:


ST. JOHN'S STUDENTS DENY ASSAULTING WOMAN
LEAD: Three St.
John's University students charged with sexually assaulting another student told the police that they were with the woman in the house where she says she was attacked, police reports obtained yesterday said.
But they denied that any sexual assault took place, the reports said.

Traffic Alert
LEAD: Because of a parade honoring the the New York City Fire Department, the Avenue of the Americas will be closed today from Spring Street to 14th Street from 7 A.M. to 8 P.M.


Patricia Dunn, 60, A Dancer in Films And on Broadway
LEAD: Patricia Dunn, a dancer who was one of the original members of Jerome Robbins's Ballets U.S.A., died of lung cancer on Thursday at her home in Manhattan.
She was 60 years old.


Red Sox Get Brunansky
LEAD: The Boston Red Sox, badly in need of right-handed power, acquired Tom Brunansky from St.
Louis yesterday for Lee Smith, who is expected to plug a hole in the Cardinals' bullpen.

Tony Lambert, 47, Sportswear Designer
LEAD: Lionel Lambert, a clothing designer known professionally as Tony Lambert, died of complications from AIDS on Thursday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 47 years old.
Mr.
Lambert was born in Woonsocket, R.I., and began his fashion career as director of merchandising and design at Beaunit Textiles in New York City.


Mildred Webber, Talent Scout, 86
LEAD: Mildred Webber, a talent scout who helped to begin the careers of Gregory Peck, Carol Channing, Butterfly McQueen, Arthur Kennedy and many other screen and stage stars, died of heart disease on Tuesday at New York Hospital.
She was 86 years old and lived in Manhattan.
