Lawyers, Not Slaves, for the Poor
LEAD: Ideally the law is a calling, not just a business run by and for lawyers.
The ethical canons of the bar are designed in part to self-govern the profession and stave off government regulation.
As one way of doing so they call on lawyers to represent not only paying clients but also those who can't afford their fees.


Racial Graffiti Found on Walls At Wesleyan U.
LEAD: A basement dining room in the building that houses Wesleyan University's Center for Afro-American Studies was defaced today by vandals who spray-painted racial slurs on its walls, further raising tensions on a campus that has had two firebombings in the last month.


Campeau Retail Units Post Operating Profit
LEAD: Federated Department Stores and the Allied Stores Corporation, the American retailing subsidiaries of the Campeau Corporation, yesterday reported net losses for March but an operating profit for the month, the first such profit since the two chains filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy in January.

Review/Music;   Van Cliburn Medalist At Carnegie
LEAD: Winning a major competition at an early age can be a blessing for a musician who possesses enough talent to take immediate advantage of the glaring light that shines on such success.
There is also a danger, however, that too much will be expected of the young artist, too soon.
In most instances, the contest winner's chief concerns as a student and contestant have been to play the notes in the right sequence and to impress teachers and judges with a fluent technique.

Hughes Suit Withdrawn
LEAD: The Hughes Aircraft Company, a subsidiary of the General Motors Corporation, said today that a former Defense Department official had withdrawn a $360 million ''whistle blower'' lawsuit, contending that the company overcharged the Government for work done by a division that builds air military and air traffic control systems.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a brief article in some copies yesterday about the Korean War Veterans Memorial in Washington misstated the way the project's sculptor will be chosen.
The selection will be made by the architect, not the Army Corps of Engineers.

Brazil Vows To Be Firm In Debt Talks
LEAD: Presenting a tough negotiating stance on the eve of a visit to Washington, Brazil's new Economy Minister has ruled out paying overdue interest payments to smooth talks with private creditor banks.

Yankees, Regaining Some Punch, Beat Langston
LEAD: They left home without much more than a horrendous losing streak, but tonight the Yankees momentarily stopped their dive.
On the first night of a nine-game trip through the West, they beat Mark Langston and appeared to regain their power.
But how long will it last?


A $38.2 Million Award vs. Kemper
LEAD: The Kemper Corporation was ordered by an arbitration panel to pay $38.2 million to a former employee for breaching his employment contract.
Kemper, a Long Grove, Ill., insurance holding company, said it planned to appeal the ruling, which was handed down on Wednesday, but will probably take a $19.5 million charge against second-quarter earnings to cover the award.


Caught With $4 Million, Probationer Tied to Mob Gets 10-Year Term
LEAD: A former private detective who has been linked to organized crime was given a 10-year prison sentence yesterday because he violated probation by taking a mysterious trip with almost $4 million.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
CYCLING
Ludwig Wins First Trump Stages
Olaf Ludwig of East Germany won the first two stages of the Tour de Trump yesterday.
He also took the overall lead.
In the morning and afternoon, Ludwig won the 95.6-mile road race from Wilmington, Del., to Baltimore.
In the evening, he won a 28.9-mile criterium in downtown Baltimore.


SOUTH AFRICANS GET ACCORD ON EFFORTS TO END VIOLENCE AND FREE POLITICAL CAPTIVES
LEAD: The South African Government and the African National Congress reported significant progress today toward full-scale negotiations on the nation's future.

Time To Be Steady
LEAD: It is hard to account for the dramatic shifts in American moods.


Review/Music;   Rediscovered Liszt Work in Premiere
LEAD: In our musicology-minded age, Europe's libraries have been host to a benign infestation of bookworms.
For the most part, these scholars burrow through dusty stacks in quest of information about past performance styles or evidence of how acknowledged masterworks came to be.
Occasionally, the search yields an unexpected dividend in the form of a lost or unknown work by a great composer.

4 Quit Drug-Test Panel Of Athletics Congress
LEAD: Just seven months after The Athletics Congress stepped up its vigilance against drug use in track and field by initiating a year-round testing program, four members of the organization's drug-testing committee, including the chairman, Edwin Moses, have resigned.


Vote at Rorer
LEAD: Shareholders of Rorer Group Inc., fulfilling a condition of Rorer's planned merger with Rhone-Poulenc S.A. of France, voted to exempt the company from certain antitakeover provisions.
In addition, Rhone-Poulenc's $78-a-share offer, worth a total of $3.2 billion, for 50.1 percent of Rorer, based in Fort Washington, Pa., was extended until Saturday from today.

George H. Armacost, Educator, 84
LEAD: George H. Armacost, who was president of the University of Redlands in California from 1945 to 1970, died of a heart attack on Wednesday at Bay Front Medical Center in St.
Petersburg, Fla.
He was 84 years old and lived in St.
Petersburg.

5th Straight Gain Puts Dow at 2,710.36
LEAD: Stock prices advanced yesterday for the fifth consecutive day, carrying the Dow Jones industrial average ahead 14.19 points, to 2,710.36 - and a gain for the week of 65.31.


Columbia Savings Reports $293 Million Quarterly Loss
LEAD: The Columbia Savings and Loan Association today reported a large loss for the first quarter, but said it was increasingly optimistic that it could sell its portfolio of high-risk, high-yield ''junk bonds'' or find another way to avoid being seized by Federal regulators.


Milton S. Gelman, 70, A Writer of TV Shows
LEAD: Milton S. Gelman, a writer and producer for television and film, died on Wednesday after complications from heart surgery at Sherman Oaks Community Hospital in Sherman Oaks, Calif., where he lived.
He was 70 years old.


News Summary
LEAD:
International
3-6
The South African Government and the African National Congress concluded three days of talks and reported significant progress toward full-scale negotiations on the nation's future.
Page 1
The Strategic Air Command's chief expressed doubt about the feasibility of President Bush's latest proposal to reduce long-range nuclear arms.


S.E.C. Chief Concerned About Futures Debate
LEAD: Richard C. Breeden, the chairman of the Securities and Exchange Commission, said today that there were ''disturbing parallels'' between the debate about who should have regulatory jurisdiction over stock index futures and the debate before the savings and loan crisis.


Legislature Might Increase Expenses
LEAD: Hard times, which have cast a grim air of austerity over most of state government, have serendipitously spared the members of the New York State Legislature.


Signs of Easing Demand Send Sugar Prices Down
LEAD: Sugar futures prices plunged yesterday more than a penny a pound on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange amid heavy selling by frustrated speculators on signs of slack global demand.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: DONALD J. TRUMP said yesterday, adding another dispute to the clamor of contractors who say the developer has yet to pay $30 million he owes for work on his latest venture, the Taj Mahal Casino in Atlantic City.
And this on top of Forbes Magazine's re-evaluation of Mr.
Trump from billionaire to a mere half-billionaire.


Killer of 2 Police Officers Executed in Florida
LEAD: A man convicted of the murder of two police officers 14 years ago was put to death today in the Florida electric chair.


U.S. Tobacco Ads in Asia Faulted
LEAD: American cigarettes are advertised illegally in Asia, including ads on the covers of children's school notebooks, on kites and on chewing gum packages, witnesses told the Senate Labor and Human Resources Committee today.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''You have accepted millions of immigrants, but you arrest Haitians and intern them in camps where they are subjected to physical, mental and sexual abuse.
What we are now saying is, 'Enough is enough.' ''
- Gerard Jean-Juste, executive director of the Haitian Refugee Center in Miami. [1:2.


Review/City Ballet;   New From Martins: 'Symmetries'
LEAD: How can a ballet company dance so unbelievably well?

Dr. Morris Stroud, 76, Specialist in Geriatrics
LEAD: Dr.
Morris Wistar Stroud 3d, a physician who developed new ways to help elderly patients recover from illness, died of cancer on Monday at his home.
He was 76 years old.
In the 1940's Dr.
Stroud was among the first physicians to form teams of professionals, including counselors, to work with the family to improve a patient's life.

Patents;   The Illogical Process of Invention
LEAD: Perhaps one of the oldest and most wrongheaded cliches to gain popularity is that ''necessity is the mother of invention.'' Reality, more often than not, is almost exactly the reverse: Invention is the mother of necessity.

Critic's Notebook;   Smorgasbord Of a Jazzfest
LEAD: Tens of thousands of people descend on the New Orleans Fairgrounds each year for the Jazz and Heritage Festival.
The Jazzfest, as everyone here calls it, comprises two weekends of music on a dozen stages around the field.
Between the stages, stands sell the greatest fast food in America, including Creole stuffed bread (smoky with Acadian andouille sausage), alligator gumbo, crayfish etouffe and oyster po' boy sandwiches.

LEAD: George W. Latimer, a former Justice of the Utah Supreme Court who defended Lieut.

He was 89 years old.
In 1946, Mr.
Latimer was elected to the Utah Supreme Court, where he served five years until he was appointed by President Harry S.

Toddler Dies in Window Fall
LEAD: An 18-month-old boy died yesterday when he fell out of a window in Harlem, the police said.
The boy, identified as Daniel Toussaint, apparently climbed over a window guard and fell from a fifth-floor apartment at 500 W. 159th Street, said a police spokeswoman, Sgt.
Tina Mohrmann.
His mother and two other children were in the apartment when he fell about 4:50 P.M., Sergeant Mohrmann said.

Currency;   Surprise Figures Shake the Dollar
LEAD: THE employment numbers for April took the market by surprise on Friday and knocked the dollar lower.
The surprise was that the report showed a weaker economy than expected.
Rather than declining, the unemployment rate rose two-tenths of a percentage point, to 5.4 percent.
After adjusting for an influx of census workers, non-farm payroll jobs declined.

U.S. Paid Romania for Soviet Arms, Report Says
LEAD: Through a complex series of transactions involving two brothers of the deposed dictator Nicolae Ceausescu, the United States paid more than $40 million to Romania for Soviet military technology over a 10-year period, The Washington Post reported today.

Technology;   Sensing the Presence Of Potential Problems
LEAD: When people get bruised, cut or fatigued, their nervous systems send signals of pain and soreness that effectively warn them to address the problem before it leads to more serious damage.


At Planting Time, Nature Needs Help
LEAD: THE planting season is in full swing.
Everything is going into the ground: shrubs, perennials, wildflowers and annuals.
But there are important exceptions, the most tender plants like tomatoes and impatiens.
Wait another week or so before putting them in, because killing frosts may still occur in this region.

A LIFELONG QUARREL WITH GOD
LEAD: Fifteen years ago, I took part in a large conference on the ''lessons of the Holocaust.'' The meeting was held in New York but organized from Jerusalem by the Hebrew University.
The participants included almost everyone in Israel and the United States who was then engaged in research or reflection about the murder of the Jews during the Nazi years.

FIlM;   It's Back to Nigeria For Bruce Beresford
LEAD: It's midnight, after the police roadblocks designed to thwart roving bands of robbers have gone up on the national highway.
Several miles down a dirt road in the high jungle of Nigeria's northern plateau, within the snug confines of an old-fashioned general store, a raucous party is going on.
A tightly packed group of people in tribal costume dance and sway to hypnotically rhythmic music, played by a small group on strange-looking instruments.


Town In Hawaii Cut Off by Lava
LEAD: Lava from Kilauea Volcano cut the last road out of this coastal town today and nearly encircled a church and the town's store in the heart of the village.

LEAD: The stock market responded in predictable fashion to the news of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Country's latest effort to stem the flow of oil onto the world market.
It bid up the price of some major oil companies a bit, anticipating that the pact might produce stronger earnings.

Patching Concrete Steps
LEAD: CONCRETE outdoor steps are durable, and ordinarily will last the life of a house.
But concrete is inherently brittle, and so corners and sharp edges of such steps are vulnerable to chipping.


A NEW LOOK AT A MAJOR MINIMALIST
LEAD: During the heady days of psychedelia and flower power in the 1960's, Terry Riley suddenly found himself leading the life of a famous composer.
His ''In C'' (1964) garnered Minimalism its first public acclaim.
And his ''Rainbow in Curved Air'' (1968), with its brightly-colored electric keyboard arpeggios and wide-eyed hippie sentiments, attained genuine crossover status, linking classically oriented new music and progressive rock into a promising new synthesis.


A New Caribbean Generation Sets Listeners to Swaying
LEAD: Fusion - of rhythms, ethnic groups and cultures - has vitalized Caribbean music for hundreds of years.
A generation ago, the musical import-export trade proceeded at a steady but gradual pace.
A Haitian group would tour Cuba and return with Latin songs in their set.
Cuban records trickled down to Trinidad, influencing the horn arrangements of the calypsos.

PUTTING DOWN ROOTS
LEAD: FOR A WHILE NOW, I'VE been thinking about planting a tree - a real tree.
It's not that I haven't planted trees before, but all of these have been minor ones, lightweights really, the kind of trees you can justify in the short term: white pines to screen the road, dwarf fruit trees, a crab apple or two, a tree hydrangea and a pair of Salix babylonica, the Tree of Immediate Gratification, otherwise known as the weeping willow.


Study Finds 'Astonishing' Indifference to Elections
LEAD: American democracy is being undermined by citizens who are so indifferent to national elections that an ''astonishing'' number of them did not even know who the candidates for Vice President were in 1988, a commission said today after a two-year study of Presidential politics.


Crumbling Cuba Still Loves to Rumba
LEAD: RECENTLY I found myself fondling a dollar bill of such limp antiquity that it called the entire concept of cash into question.
This tattered, pale greenback had been in circulation since the late 60's, but were it not for its privileged isolation on the island of Cuba, it would long ago have been incinerated.

Review/Recital;   From Bach to Schnittke By Heinrich Schiff, a Cellist
LEAD: Heinrich Schiff is a cellist of reassuring solidity.
There is no part of his technique not firmly in place.
Intonation, color, steadiness of bow - all gave Wednesday's audience at the 92d Street Y the feeling that no matter how trying the technical problems, how exhausting the demands of concentration, the music would emerge whole and satisfying.

Salzburg
LEAD: To the Editor: Your special music festivals issue (Travel, April 29) was extremely interesting, but your readers should know that last year in Salzburg, so well known for its festival, when my husband and I attended a Palace Concert (at the Residenz) - an event billed as a chamber orchestra playing Haydn, Mozart and Dvorak - the orchestra turned out to be a group of young people (teen-agers, early 20's), who, while showing promise, were in no way professional musicians.

Elm Saplings Promise a Green Future
LEAD: CONNECTICUT communities are joining a nationwide effort to bring elm trees back to their streets and parks.
Most of the American elms that once graced the greens of the state's towns were wiped out decades ago by Dutch elm disease.
But now, a nonprofit institute, led by a former Connecticut resident, is distributing disease-resistant elm saplings that can grow to provide beauty and shade in decades to come.

LEAD: Apparently, Vivian Gornick has been living in an ivory tower for so long that she considers conversations with fellow academics to represent the public at large (''Who Says We Haven't Made a Revolution?'' April 15).
Even comments about the tribulations of welfare mothers come (secondhand) from doctoral students at Harvard.


FICTION
LEAD:
THE EVENING NEWS.
By Arthur Hailey. (Doubleday, $21.95.) Arthur Hailey's 10th novel is a literary example of an old boxing adage: if you don't have the fistic power, dazzle them with footwork. ''The Evening News'' is painstakingly researched, convolutedly plotted, peopled with poster-paint characters and written in a relentlessly breathless style.

Patching Concrete Steps
LEAD: CONCRETE outdoor steps are durable, and ordinarily will last the life of a house.
But concrete is inherently brittle, and so corners and sharp edges of such steps are vulnerable to chipping.

All About/Shipbuilding;   After a Long Slump, World Shipping Is Embarking on a Modest Recovery
LEAD: As owner of one of the world's largest fleets, P. N. Tsakos, the president of a Greek shipping line that bears his name, should be relishing his industry's recovery from a decade-long depression in shipping and shipbuilding.
Instead, he frets about whether to place large new orders for ships.
If he hesitates, prices may rise and shipyards may be booked for years, keeping him from expanding.

AROUND THE GARDEN
LEAD: For This Week: In colder regions it is still too early to plant tomatoes, eggplants, seed of any beans particularly limas, or squash, seedlings of impatiens and begonias; wait for another week or two because the soil and nights must be warm.
Snap old flowers from pansy plants to keep them blooming.

When Three Beats to a Bar Became Magic
LEAD: What makes Johann Strauss' waltzes so irresistible?
Melody?
Offenbach and Emil Waldteufel composed melodies that are often as memorable as Strauss'.
Harmony?
Strauss' vocabulary is notably rich, sometimes implied in the melodies themselves, sometimes exhibited for its own sake in piquant, Schubertian key progressions within and between the sections of a waltz set.

Question Of the Week;   Why Is The Triple Crown Won So Rarely?
LEAD: One difficult factor in winning the Triple Crown is that unlike other tournaments, new participants may enter during later rounds.
But during the Triple Crown, a fresh contender may enter the Belmont only.
That horse is in a much better position to win the final jewel than a horse that has raced and moved twice before the last leg.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption last Sunday with an article about music festivals in Europe misidentified an orchestra performing in Prague; it was the Cleveland Orchestra.

LEAD: It's apple blossom time in the Hudson Valley - more than a week earlier than usual because of a heat wave late last month.
Many of the area's apple trees are burgeoning with white blossoms, a harbinger of a good apple crop, if they are not hit by a cold spell this week or next.

LEAD: Q. Water seeps through the concrete floor of my basement.
This problem has developed near where valving was installed for an automatic sprinkling system.
The system, buried two feet deep near where the puddling occurs, does not leak.
Applying a waterproof sealer to the floor did not help.
Any suggestions?

A Greek Island That Resists Change
LEAD: COMING upon the island of Patmos in darkness, the presence of the church is merely a whisper in the traveler's ear.
There is something different about Patmos, even in the evening hours.
No loud throbbing beat of American pop greets you at the dock, no desperate hotel representatives shove photographs of their accommodations in your face.

BRIDGE
LEAD: The next world team championships for the Bermuda Bowl, scheduled in Yokohama, Japan, in September 1991 will have an enlarged format: 16 teams.
For most of its early years there were just two teams.
Eight months ago in Perth, Australia, there were 10 teams.
The Venice Trophy contest for Women's Teams will be similarly enlarged.

In This Painter's World, Everything Is Several Things
LEAD: Susan Rothenberg is back.
With her blood-red heads stuck at both ends of a jump-rope-length bone, so that the two-headed figure becomes a gigantic baby rattle; with her dancers, gymnasts and acrobats so elastic that they can curve their bodies into O's and U's and put their feet behind their heads without bending their backs, and with her horses' heads as long as snakes and as rubbery as hoses, this 45-year-old painter has re-established herself as one of the most compelling artists of her generation.

Answering The Mail
LEAD: Q. Water seeps through the concrete floor of my basement.
This problem has developed near where valving was installed for an automatic sprinkling system.
The system, buried two feet deep near where the puddling occurs, does not leak.
Applying a waterproof sealer to the floor did not help.
Any suggestions?

TALES OF HAMLETS THEN AND NOW
LEAD: Lending himself to a host of needs, generous in his willingness to do what's wanted of him, Hamlet is the supremely adaptable dramatic character.
Though the occasion of his crisis is the need to avenge his father's murder, something far less specific is involved: a universality of dilemma and anguish; a noble soul forced to act ignobly, an honest one forced to lie.

Question Of the Week;   Why Is The Triple Crown Won So Rarely?
LEAD: In May of a thoroughbred's third year, the horse has not yet fully matured physically.
With the Triple Crown races running close together, it is difficult for a young horse to run three strong races consecutively.
Also, the Triple Crown closes with the Belmont Stakes at a mile and a half.
This grueling distance often proves too much for even the best of horses.

LEAD: ''Hospitals Grapple With Ethical Issues'' (March 4) stated that Long Island Jewish and Albert Einstein Hospitals are discussing forming a regional ethics committee network to help train ethics committee members and act as a clearinghouse on hospital policies.
The Roman Catholic Diocese of Rockville Centre has already done this for its hospitals in Nassau and Suffolk Counties.

After 27 miles of the 87.7-mile road race from Fredericksburg to Richmond, three riders broke away from the 129 others.

That's a wonder - and it's no wonder.
For here is just the sort of play some people resist, misunderstand or find threatening, but its emotional pull and entertainment value besides are considerable.

Review/Jazz;   Steve Lacy, Saxophonist
LEAD: Steve Lacy, the expatriate American saxophonist, is a master of stasis.
Where most jazz musicians bull their way through tunes, leaving notes as a motorboat leaves a wake, Mr.
Lacy mulls each phrase over and over.
He will play an idea, then repeat it, bending the last note.
Or he will add a few notes, or drop some.


Potter Tackles Mystery Of a Chinese Glaze
LEAD: FOR 10 years Albert Green, one of New Jersey's best-known potters, has been trying to solve an ancient puzzle.
How did the Chinese potters of the Sung dynasty (A.D. 960-1280) create that greenish-blue celadon glaze they called Kuan?
There are no books that explain 1,000-year-old glaze formulas.

LEAD: Recent regulations restrict the sale of ivory in hopes of saving the elephants.
Wildlife biologists raise black-footed ferrets in an attempt to restore an almost extinct species.
But what of the plight of wild plants?


Ballet Theater's Challenge: To Reclaim Its Soul
LEAD: Paradise regained?
Anyone who thinks - as many do - that American Ballet Theater misplaced its soul during the decade that Mikhail Baryshnikov was its artistic director will now be closely watching a new regime determined to redefine the company's identity.
Tomorrow's opening of the troupe's 50th-anniversary season in New York at the Metropolitan Opera House begins an era in which Jane Hermann and Oliver Smith, the recently named co-directors, promise to restore certain names and policies identified with Ballet Theater's past.

Q and A
LEAD:
Cruising the Amazon
Q.
We would like to take a cruise up the Amazon River to Manaus.
What is the best season and which cruise lines make the trip? -Doris Schuller, Rego Park, Queens
A.
Several cruise ships offer itineraries to or from Manaus, about 1,000 miles up the Amazon.
Naturalists who point out the flora and fauna and lecturers in the history, anthropology and ecology of the region are often on board.

LEAD: Somehow, despite the chaos, life in Athens makes sense.
For those who can't unplug completely even when they've escaped to an island retreat, Athens is a crash course in relaxation without the deprivation of city amenities.
Here, people don't ask what you do for a living until well into the conversation, sometimes never at all.

Word Has It They'll Raise The Rent
LEAD: No one knows for sure yet, but rentals for movies at the video store - now in the $2.50 to $3 range - could take a jump in the next few months.
Rent is connected to price, both retail and wholesale.
Blaming higher costs and a soft rental market, four major studios - Warner, Paramount, MCA/Universal and RCA/Columbia - are raising the retail list prices of rental ''A titles'' (the best-known movies) from the $89.95 level prevalent since 1986 to $92.95 or thereabouts.

Achievement: The Key To Self-Esteem
LEAD: Recently two letter writers opposed giving grades in an attempt to improve pupils' self-esteem.
Do they really think children can be kept from knowing how well or poorly they are doing?
Children know.
The absence of marks, if anything, would make achievement less important in their eyes.
Also, promoting an unprepared child would quickly destroy what was left of his self-confidence.

SHADES OF WHITE
LEAD: White.
It's the most basic of colors, yet the most complex.
Indeed, the very word conjures up a host of contrasts.
White connotes purity and cleanliness, simplicity and elegance.
It also represents the harsh, crisp lines of modern architecture as well as the almost chalk-like quality of rustic rooms.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a review on April 8 about recordings of English music misstated the relationship between Ralph Vaughan Williams and Hubert Parry and misattributed the composition ''Toward the Unknown Region.'' Parry was Vaughan Williams's teacher, not the reverse.
The composition is by Vaughan Williams.

Hitler Never Really Was Schicklgruber
LEAD: To the Editor:


'Extraordinary' Flood Ravages Rural Area South of Dallas
LEAD: A rural area south of Dallas was swept today by what the National Weather Service described as ''an extraordinary, record-breaking flood.''


A FEMINIST TAKES STOCK
LEAD: I am troubled by Vivan Gornick's assumption that young women today are unwilling to be labeled ''feminist.'' This implies that they are not grateful or even aware of the sacrifices and gains made by pioneer feminists.
I am a 26-year-old professional woman and I proudly call myself a feminist.
I recognize the relative privilege of my position compared to women of the past, and I am grateful for the women's movement and the opportunities it has created for me.


At Planting Time, Nature Needs Help
LEAD: THE planting season is in full swing.
Everything is going into the ground: shrubs, perennials, wildflowers and annuals.
But there are important exceptions, the most tender plants like tomatoes and impatiens.
Wait another week or so before putting them in, because killing frosts may still occur in this region.

McCarthy Racing to the Top, Even as an Amateur Rider

Mohawks Mourn Victim Of Reservation Violence
LEAD: Hundreds of Mohawks gathered today at a Catholic parish hall to mourn Harold (J. R.) Edwards, an easygoing ironworker who happened to be standing in his grandfather's yard at the wrong time.


Egypt Butane Price Up
LEAD: Egypt said last week that it had more than doubled domestic prices for butane gas, in the latest move to meet International Monetary Fund demands for economic changes and cuts in state subsidies.
The new price of home-delivered gas cylinders is 57 cents, up from 25 cents.
Two weeks ago the price of locally manufactured cigarettes was raised as much as 20 percent.


Baker Visits Warsaw to Try To Calm Fears Over Border
LEAD: Secretary of State James A. Baker 3d visited Warsaw today in an effort to calm Polish fears that a unified Germany might try to claim former German lands that are now part of Poland.
But he appeared to have been only partly successful.


Celtics Show Their Age As Well as Their Agony
LEAD: Walking into the Boston Celtics' locker room this afternoon was like walking into a funeral parlor.
Some players, such as Robert Parish, refused to talk.
Others, such as John Bagley, spoke so softly they could hardly be heard.
But as usual, Larry Bird, the team's legend and leader, summed up the Celtics' mood best following the Knicks' memorable 121-114 victory at Boston Garden that eliminated


Paper Reveals Keating Report
LEAD: The court-appointed examiner of the bankrupt American Continental Corporation told a judge that Charles H. Keating Jr., the company's chairman, and others defrauded investors for personal gain, according to a report published today.


Critic's Notebook;   Another Chorus of Nostalgia At the new Orleans Festival
LEAD: What's a pop singer to do when the bandwagon has moved on?
The question comes to mind every year at the New Orleans Jazz and Heritage Festival, the annual two-weekend blowout that started April 27.
By celebrating the kinds of music that make Louisiana unique, from Mardi Gras chants to Cajun two-steps, the festival has helped to preserve old local styles as national treasures.

Elton H. Rule, 73, ABC President Who Led Network to Dominance
LEAD: Elton H. Rule, a former president of the American Broadcasting Companies whose management pioneered mini-series, made-for-television movies and Monday night football and led the ailing company to network dominance in the late 1970's, died of cancer Saturday at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif.
He was 73 years old.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Snapple Campaign
LEAD: ''The all-natural taste of Snapple beverages is so good,'' says its first ad campaign from Buckley/DeCerchio, ''it makes some people forget themselves.'' In one television commercial a family of five guzzles the drink as they motor across the desert singing ''Row, Row, Row Your Boat.'' But they have been drinking without thinking; a road sign notes that the next rest area - and by implication the next bathroom - is 115 miles away.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   USA Today Promotion
LEAD: USA Today's new advertising campaign, created by the New York office of Babbit &amp; Reiman Advertising, toys with the newspaper's reputation. ''The paper people love to tear apart,'' says the ad's headline.
The copy, however, explains that it refers not to any criticism of USA Today's editorial content, but simply to the claim that people often clip and save the paper's articles.

California's Ballot Industry
LEAD: Perhaps best known for hot tubs, dancing raisins and ''Governor Moonbeam,'' California is without question the most diverse state in the country - geographically, racially and culturally.
I was raised here and I'm proud to be a Californian.
But as a legislator for 16 years, I've traveled around the country talking to folks who just shake their heads in wonder at our unusual politics.

LEAD: President Jaime Paz Zamora of Bolivia arrives in Washington this week with startling information: The market for raw coca leaves in his country has collapsed.
He considers that a powerful reason for the U.S. to speed up economic aid to help Bolivia's antidrug campaign, and he's right.

LEAD: Jordan, McGrath, Case &amp; Taylor has been awarded the consumer-advertised brands of Fisons Consumer Health, a division of Fisons Pharmaceuticals.
The brands include Desenex, Cruex, Allerest and Sinarest.
Fisons' professionally promoted products go to the Sutton Healthcare Group.
The accounts had been at Levy, King &amp; White, the Buffalo agency that recently agreed to be acquired by Eric Mower &amp; Associates.

Reviews/Television;   How Do You Build a Skyscraper? With Frustration.
LEAD: What most people who watch ''Skyscraper'' are going to conclude is that the most important thing in putting up a large urban building is not esthetics, not finance and not politics, but logistics.
For this is a tale of schedules above all, of getting the steel to arrive on time, of getting the bricklayers lined up to start on the day the bricks are ready, of making sure that everything from city approvals to mortgage money to leases to tenants' move-in dates is coordinated properly.

Texas Title for Stewart: Payne Stewart turned back a bold bid by Lanny Wadkins yesterday for a front-running two-stroke victory in the Byron Nelson Classic at Irving, Tex.
Stewart had a final-round 67 for an eight-under-par 202 total.
Floods shorted the event.(AP)

LEAD: A community festival in this college town was marked by two nights of rioting by hundreds of youths who pelted officers with rocks and bottles and set two police cars on fire.
At least 93 people were arrested at the annual Rancho Chico Days, the authorities said today.
Ten police officers and an unknown number of civilians were hurt in the violence Friday and Saturday night near California State University at Chico.

One Insecticide, From Field to Table
LEAD:
1970: Aldicarb, a powerful nerve poison and the active ingredient in the insecticide Temik, is sold in the United States for the first time for use on nonfood crops.
In high doses it can kill humans on contact.
At lower doses it can cause nausea, elevated heart rates and blurred vision.

Soviets' Price On Germany
LEAD: If the opening session of the ''two plus four'' talks made one thing clear, it was that the real bargaining would be not between the victors and losers of World War II, but between a fairly unified West - now including both a prosperous West Germany and a democratized East Germany - and a battered, weakened and troubled Soviet Union using one of its last levers of power in Europe to exact the highest possible price for its final exit from the scene.

LEAD: The busiest entrepreneur dealing in unusual bridge events is certainly Kathie Wei, who shuttles between Houston and New York in the interests of the shipping business of her late husband, Charles Wei.

Business Scene;   Argentina's Zest For Privatization
LEAD: PRIVATIZATION, the process of turning a state enterprise into a private one, is all the rage in Eastern Europe.
But perhaps nowhere in the world is it more popular than in Argentina, where the rush to sell off state companies is producing bargain-basement deals to lure reluctant foreign buyers.

Ignored: A Path to Peace in Cambodia
LEAD: In the waning days of the Vietnam War, President Nixon ordered American troops into Cambodia.
He said it was necessary lest the United States be seen as ''a pitiful, helpless giant.'' That invasion 20 years ago helped bring the Khmer Rouge to power and turn Cambodia into a killing field.

Chronicle
LEAD: In 1960, EILEEN FULTON was one of about 200 young actresses trying out for the role of Lisa, a sweet, uncomplicated ingenue in the CBS television soap opera ''As the World Turns.'' She got the role and has kept it for 30 years, a perhaps unmatched tenure for an actor in one role.
Miss Fulton is 56 years old now, and as Lisa has gone through six husbands, dozens of affairs and innumerable personal crises including rape, the death of two children, a phantom pregnancy and menopause.

More Corn for Soviets
LEAD: Private exporting companies have sold an additional 600,000 metric tons of United States corn to the Soviet Union for delivery this year under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said Friday.
Orders since Oct. 1 now total 13.9 million tons of corn, 3.3 million tons of wheat, 342,300 tons of soybeans and 1.2 million tons of soybean meal.

A Place Where Fishermen Shoot Their Prey
LEAD: The canoe cut slowly through the still waters of a Lake Champlain swamp. ''Easy, easy does it,'' the hunter said. ''I see him.

He's got to be a 20-pounder.

Review/Theater;   'Once on This Island,' Fairy Tale Bringing Caribbean to 42d Street
LEAD: In ''Once on This Island,'' the stage has found its own sugar-and-cartoon-free answer to ''The Little Mermaid.'' A 90-minute Caribbean fairy tale told in rousing song and dance, this show is a joyous marriage of the slick and the folkloric, of the hard-nosed sophistication of Broadway musical theater and the indigenous culture of a tropical isle.

Protest by 500 Aimed at Chief Of Daily News
LEAD: The continuing impasse in contract negotiations led 500 pressmen and drivers from The Daily News to gather yesterday outside the Gramercy Park apartment building of the newspaper's publisher, James Hoge.


Democrats Send Connecticut Budget to Governor
LEAD: Democrats in the House gave final passage today to a revenue plan that takes money from two reserve funds and changes state tax laws to raise $339 million to erase this year's budget deficit and balance next year's budget without a tax increase.


Nina Ruffini, Lawyer, Weds
LEAD: Nina Ruffini, the daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Giovanni Ruffini of New York, was married yesterday at the Burden Mansion in New York to Robert Minkoff, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Walter Minkoff of New York.
David Fuller, the Village Justice of Tuckahoe, N.Y., officiated.
The bride, an associate at the New York law firm of Shereff, Friedman, Hoffman &amp; Goodman, graduated from Wellesley College and the University of Pennsylvania Law School.

LEAD: Many analysts are predicting a close proxy battle today between the USX Corporation and Carl C. Icahn, the company's largest shareholder, on a plan offered by Mr.

Chronicle
LEAD: BOBBY FISCHER, the American chess genius who went into seclusion 15 years ago after defeating BORIS SPASSKY of the Soviet Union for the world chess championship, spent four days in Brussels last week discussing his future.

LEAD: Frank Herbert Reed, the American hostage freed last week after more than three years in captivity, said today that he had been savagely beaten in the face, ribs and feet after he tried twice to escape.

LEAD: In the groovy 1960's, the Beatles and bell bottoms were the rage, and really cool people owned these far-out lamps that glowed with psychedelic glob and made you mellow.


F.B.I. Said to Foil Missile Smuggling to Colombia
LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation broke up a plot to smuggle 24 Stinger antiaircraft missiles to Colombian drug traffickers by arresting several Colombians in Florida on Saturday, a senior Federal law enforcement official said today.


Black Political Figures Stress Similarities
LEAD: For months, the Rev.
Jesse Jackson and Gov.
L.
Douglas Wilder of Virginia have been portrayed as combatants locked in a competition for the title of the nation's premier black political figure.
This weekend, the two got together here not only to dispel such notions but also to stress the similarities rather than the differences in their goals and approaches.


John Paul, in Mexico, Talks of Restoring Ties
LEAD: Pope John Paul II received a thunderous welcome in Mexico today as he talked of eventually restoring the Vatican's diplomatic relations with this country, where both Roman Catholic roots and anti-church feelings run deep.

Louis-Dreyfus was not an ad man.

Fewer German Jobless
LEAD: The number of people out of work in West Germany, which is riding an economic boom, fell again in April to 1.91 million, or 7.3 percent of the work force, according to Labor Office figures released Friday.


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''It had to end sometime. I'm glad it ended this way.''
-Maurice Cheeks of the New York Knicks, after their Boston losing streak ended. [C1:4.]


Death Toll Put at 17 in Crash Of Cargo Plane in Guatemala
LEAD: A Miami-bound DC-6 cargo plane crashed in a crowded residential neighborhood on Saturday, killing its 3-member American crew and at least 14 people on the ground, officials said today.
Several houses were destroyed.

LEAD: About 1,000 Mongolians demonstrated today in support of pro-democracy protesters staging a sit-in in the capital, and hunger strikers in other parts of the country fasted through an eighth day.

LEAD: More than a third of all pedestrian deaths in New York State in 1988 involved people who were 65 years old or older, the Legislature's Commission on Critical Transportation Choices reported yesterday.

Self-Help for Cleaner Streets
LEAD: New York City's budget crisis portends ugly consequences for the city's streets.
Mayor David Dinkins, beset by demands from every quarter, proposes to save money with more cutbacks in the Sanitation Department's street-sweeping forces.
Once, the sweepers numbered 1,382; now they are down to 282, and another round of cutting might eliminate them entirely.

The Message-in-the-Bottle Report
LEAD: The furor over New York State's budget problems diverted attention from a recent report on the ''Returnable Container Act.'' The bottle bill, as it is called, requires a five-cent deposit on soft drink and beer bottles or cans, to be refunded on return.


Befouled to Its Romantic Depths, Danube Reaches a Turning Point
LEAD: Swollen and pearly gray, the Danube makes a spectacular turn here, pushing into gentle woodlands as it surges south toward Budapest.
It is the river at its most seductive: winding through the valleys of Central Europe, where it has inspired poets and composers and generations of painters who still work on its banks today.

MCI Plans to Pay Dividend on Stock
LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation announced it would pay dividends on its common stock for the first time in its 27-year history.
The nation's second-largest long-distance telephone company told shareholders at its annual meeting in Washington that it would begin paying a regular semiannual dividend of 5 cents a share on its common stock on June 11.


Crisp Is Dismissed As Coach of Flames
LEAD: Terry Crisp was dismissed yesterday as coach of the defending champion Calgary Flames, who were eliminated in the first round of the National Hockey League playoffs this spring after finishing the regular season with the league's second-best record.


Grain Prices Pushed Higher By Expected Foreign Sales
LEAD: Prices of grain and soybean futures closed higher yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade, as expectation of additional export sales fueled buying interest.

LEAD: The Farmers Home Administration has written off nearly one-third of the $8.8 billion owed by delinquent borrowers and says there is an increase in foreclosures to collect the rest.

LEAD: THE health insurance industry is in disarray in California, where popular support is growing for measures that would require all employers to provide health coverage for their employees.

LEAD: A Federal judge has imposed a $115.5 million penalty on officers of the collapsed Champion Insurance Company, but the judge warned state officials that they might have difficulty collecting the money.

LEAD: EARLY findings from the most comprehensive large study ever undertaken of the relationship between diet and the risk of developing disease are challenging much of American dietary dogma.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
CYCLING
Poisson Wins Stage by 2 Feet
In the closest finish since the 11-day Tour de Trump race began last Thursday, Pascal Poisson of France beat Paul McCormack of Ireland yesterday by 2 feet.
Vyacheslav Bobrik, a 19-year-old Soviet amateur, led the overall standing for the third day in a row.


NEWS SUMMARY
LEAD:
International
A3-11


Francis X. Fay, 92, Former F.B.I. Agent And Executive, Dies
LEAD: Francis X. Fay, an F.B.I. agent active in the investigation of the kidnapping of the son of Charles A. Lindbergh in the early 30's, died of pneumonia on Saturday at the Little Company of Mary Pavilion in Torrance, Calif.
He was 92 years old and lived in Norwalk, Conn.


One Last Round for 2 Old Dominican Rivals
LEAD: For more than five decades they have been rivals, and now the two men they call the Grand Elephants of Dominican politics are squaring off for what seems to be their final battle in national elections on May 16.


Chess
LEAD: The Dortmund Chess Festival was organized in timely fashion.
For one thing, it was about time that West Germany (or either Germany, for that matter) held a first-class competition.
Not since Nuremberg 1896, or maybe Barmen 1905, has a tournament as strong as the Dortmund International ''A'' taken place on German soil.


Greyhound Views Strike As Over
LEAD: The chief executive of Greyhound Lines Inc. said today that ''from all practical points of view,'' a drivers' strike now in its 10th week ''is over'' and that the nation's largest intercity bus system was operating on routes that contributed 98 percent of its revenues a year ago.


Troubled Oil, or Troubled Waters?
LEAD: America has no rational strategy for exploring its coastal waters for oil and gas.
The Interior Department and the oil companies want to drill; the environmentalists and their allies in the coastal states and Congress do not.
Any middle ground in this paralyzing dispute disappeared with the wreck of the Exxon

LEAD: Le Mystere des Voix Bulgares is the exotic title attached to a Bulgarian women's choir that has stirred popular enthusiasm in recent world tours and recordings.
The singers brought their startling ensemble sound to Avery Fisher Hall on Friday night, joined from time to time by two intrumental quartets.

LEAD: Playboy Enterprises Inc. announced a recapitalization plan today aimed at helping the company finance acquisitions and other activities without diluting the controlling stake of its founder, Hugh Hefner.


Foote, Cone Earnings Drop by 41.5% in Period
LEAD: Foote, Cone &amp; Belding Communications reported a 41.5 percent drop in net income for the quarter ended March 31 to $1.34 million, or 13 cents a share, from $2.29 million, or 23 cents a share, in the 1989 first quarter.
Revenues were down 6.7 percent, to $72.19 million from $77.34 million.


Banc One Texas
LEAD: Bank One Texas, a subsidiary of the Banc One Corporation of Columbus, Ohio, assumed the deposits and certain other liabilities of the former First State Federal Savings Association in San Antonio.
Terms of the transaction were not disclosed.
Bank One assumed $287 million in deposits of First State Federal, which was closed on Friday by the Office of Thrift Supervision.

Housing Off in Canada
LEAD: In a fresh sign that seven years of economic growth may be easing in Canada, the Government reported today that new-home construction had fallen 12 percent in April to its lowest level in two and a half years.

LEAD: Pace University has awarded its advertising account, formerly at AC&amp;R Advertising, to Great Scott Advertising.
The account has a budget of $4 million.

LEAD: The King of Nepal has been warned by the country's leading political party that if he does not turn over substantial powers to the interim Government, the party will call crowds back into the streets to force the issue.


Soviet Union Buys Corn
LEAD: Private exporting companies have sold the Soviet Union an additional 1.75 million metric tons of United States corn for delivery this year under a long-term supply agreement, the Agriculture Department said today.
Officials said that 1.15 million tons were new sales, while 600,000 tons were previously reported but were shifted from ''unknown'' destinations to the Soviet Union.

LEAD: The worst floods in decades, caused by storms nearly a week ago, are still plaguing large areas of Texas, Oklahoma and Arkansas.

LEAD: Suffering from a steep decline in its share of the United States vehicle market, the Chrysler Corporation is intensifying a two-month-old media blitz with new advertising based on a surprising finding that new-car buyers prefer Chrysler cars over those of the highly rated Honda Motor Company.

LEAD: Penicillin-resistant gonorrhea more than doubled from 1988 to 1989 and its treatment will require more expensive drugs, Federal researchers say.

Muammar el-Qaddafi, said today that after the American air raid on Libya in 1986 he planned a missile attack on the two United States bases on the Greek island of Crete.

LEAD: Two Colombian drug traffickers arrested last weekend had agreed to hand over $1 million in cocaine profits as a down payment for a ''substantial number'' of Stinger anti-aircraft missiles, F.B.I. officials said today.


Bush Will Veto Bill Requiring Job Leave for Care of Family
LEAD: President Bush will veto any legislation requiring employers to give parents time off to care for their newborn babies or ill family members, the White House chief of staff, John H, Sununu, said today.
It is the second time this spring that Congress and the White House have clashed over a measure aimed at helping families torn between the demands of work and home.

LEAD: Long skilled at playing the role of elder statesman who stands above the fray of daily politics, President Francois Mitterrand has seen his popularity tumble sharply as he prepares to begin his 10th year in office on Thursday.

Gulf Air Orders CFM Jet Engines
LEAD: Gulf Air, the airline of four Middle Eastern countries, has ordered CFM International jet engines worth $225 million to power Airbus Industrie A320 jetliners, the engine maker said.
CFM said the CFM56-5 engines would power 12 Airbus jetliners, with an option for six more.
Delivery is to begin in 1992 and continue through 1994.


Grand Slam Changes?
LEAD: The Australian Open, the least prestigious of the four major titles, could lose its Grand Slam status unless prize money is increased, the tournament's general manager said yesterday in Melbourne.


President Named Chief Of Dime Savings Bank
LEAD: The Dime Savings Bank, one of the strongest of New York's large savings banks, yesterday named Richard D. Parsons, a 42-year-old lawyer, as its new chief executive, effective July 1.
He will succeed Harry W. Albright Jr., 65, who has headed the bank for 15 years and will continue as chairman.


Topics of The Times;   Left High and Dry
LEAD: It turned out to be a lovely weekend in New York, much to the astonishment of the weathermen.
There was barely a trace of the three inches of rain that some thought would deluge the metropolitan area.
For all the ostensible science (''barometric pressure,'' ''relative humidity''), forecasting the weather seems approximately as accurate as forecasting the economy.


U.S. AND IRAN MOVE ON SMALLER CLAIMS
LEAD: The United States and Iran have made substantial progress toward a settlement of more than 2,000 small claims against Iran by Americans who contend that their property was improperly seized by Teheran, Administration officials said today.

Topics of The Times;   Hacker's License
LEAD: Robert Tappan Morris is the Oliver North of computer abuse.
The graduate student whiz committed a felony punishable by prison: tying up 6,000 computers with an electronic ''worm'' that spread wildly through interconnected machines.
Yet Federal Judge Howard Munson in Syracuse sentenced him only to 400 hours of community service and a $10,000 fine.


Minority Journalists Want Newsday to Suspend Breslin
LEAD: Two groups of minority journalists yesterday called for the suspension of Jimmy Breslin, a columnist for New York Newsday, because of racial slurs Mr.
Breslin used about a Korean-American colleague.


Remains of Apollo Spacecraft Will Be Buried
LEAD: The Apollo capsule in which three astronauts died 23 years ago will be buried later this month in the abandoned missile silo that contains the debris of the space shuttle Challenger, the space agency said.


Saudis Laud OPEC Pact
LEAD: Saudi Arabia, the world's largest oil exporter, said today that last week's OPEC agreement to cut oil output was an essential move to keep prices from collapsing.


Researchers Use Robot For Hip Surgery on Dog
LEAD: Researchers have used a robotic arm similar to those that assemble automobiles and television sets to help implant an artifical joint in a dog.


Bigger Fluor Stake In Lead Producer
LEAD: The Fluor Corporation agreed to buy the 42.5 percent stake of the Doe Run Company, North America's largest lead producer, that it does not already own from the Homestake Mining Company for $125 million.
Completion of the transaction is subject to Government approval.
Fluor said it planned to expand its activities in the secondary or recycled lead market.

LEAD: The news that Lasix makes horses run faster is no news to horseplayers.
Now, however, that longstanding assumption has been certified in a prestigious medical journal and the continued use of the drug has become the sport's hottest issue.

LEAD: The Bass family of Fort Worth, Tex., gave Yale University $20 million today to establish an Institute of Biospheric Studies that will greatly expand the university's research into environmental issues.


Driver Survives 30-Foot Fall
LEAD: An 80-year-old man suffered only minor cuts and bruises today when his car plunged off a bridge, narrowly missing two 60,000-volt electrical lines and landing upside down on train tracks 30 feet below.
The police said the car driven by Andrew Amato of New Haven, who was wearing his seat belt, crashed through a fence after being rammed by a car that had gone through a stop sign.

He was 79 years old and had been a longtime resident of Westfield, N.J., until 1985.

Review/Music;   Foss Ends Final Season With the Brooklyn
LEAD: When the final chord of the Verdi Requiem faded away at the Brooklyn Academy of Music on Sunday afternoon, Lukas Foss's 20th and final season as music director of the Brooklyn Philharmonic came to an end.
He will continue as conductor laureate - a post he also holds with the Milwaukee Symphony Orchestra - and will work with the Brooklyn ensemble at least through 1992, a year after Dennis Russell Davies succeeds him as director.

Soviets Lift Grain Price
LEAD: The Soviet Government today nearly doubled the price paid to grain farmers in hopes of stimulating this year's harvest at the risk of a substantial increase in its budget deficit.
The price paid for top-quality soft grain will rise to 500 rubles a ton from 260 rubles under today's order from the Council of Ministers, the Soviet press agency Tass reported.

LEAD: THE job of vice president or top manager in charge of human resources, or personnel departments, has become much more important in the last few years.
Two recent surveys by leading management recruiters confirm the trend.

LEAD: Bjorn Borg, the five-time Wimbledon champion from Sweden, appeared in court in Stockholm yesterday to open a $58,000 libel action stemming from allegations that he abused drugs.

LEAD: A broken window at the black cultural center at Trinity College sparked a student protest today as well as an investigation by campus authorities into the weekend incident.

LEAD: The Gay Men's Health Crisis, a large private AIDS service agency, announced yesterday that it had joined a boycott of the annual international AIDS conference in San Francisco to protest a Federal immigration ban on foreign travelers infected with the virus.

LEAD: A motorist was shot in the head and killed early today by someone in a passing car, and the authorities closed down the Harbor Freeway, about five miles south of downtown, for nearly an hour to search for clues.
The police said two motorists reporting from car phones told them that the shots had come from a car occupied by two men.

Washington Bank Plans Revamping
LEAD: The Washington Bancorporation agreed to tighten management practices and procedures after defaulting on about $26 million in short-term debt.
The agreement with Federal regulators includes a special review of the company's real estate loans, the bank said on Monday.
The company's stock plunged $5.50, or 61.1 percent, on Monday in over-the-counter trading, but it recovered $1.25 a share, or 35.7 percent, to $4.75 today.

LEAD: The Salvadoran Government vowed today to cooperate with a judge's investigation into the killing of six Jesuit priests and two women in November and to take action if any obstacles are put in the judge's way.

El Al Net Up by 28.7%
LEAD: The state-owned El Al Israel Airlines today reported a net income of $24.2 million for 1989, its fourth consecutive profitable year.
The profit marked a 28.7 percent jump from El Al's 1988 net income of $18.8 million.
Revenues rose by 7.2 percent, to $713.6 million, from $665.3 million in 1988.
El Al said it carried more than 1.7 million passengers last year.

For American Caviar
LEAD: PADDLEFISH caviar, most often sold under the title American sturgeon caviar, is similar in color and size to Russian sevruga, but costs about half as much.
A caviar pound is typically 14 ounces.
Quality can vary considerably.
Caviar can usually be kept in the refrigerator for several weeks.
Here are some places where the roe can be obtained: MACY'S CELLAR, 151 West 34th Street, Manhattan, 212-695-4400, extension 2002.


92d St. Y, Running a Deficit, Delays Year of Schubertiade
LEAD: After a decade of growth, the 92d Street Y - the adventurous educational and cultural center on Lexington Avenue - is trimming its programs in an effort to reduce a projected 1991 deficit of $1.5 million.

LEAD: If the December issue of Sassy looks a bit ragged in spots, do not blame the editors.
They will have had very little to do with it.
Sassy, continuing its reputation for trailblazing, plans to publish what it calls the ''first-ever reader-produced issue of a consumer magazine.''


U.S. WILL OPPOSE AID IN OZONE PLAN
LEAD: The Bush Administration has decided to oppose an international plan that would grant $100 million to developing nations to drastically reduce the use of chemicals that are depleting the earth's protective ozone layer, officials said today.

LEAD: A variety of companies are making progress toward ways to put to good use the hundreds of millions of tires Americans throw out each year.
But environmentalists say the new technology still falls short of conquering on its own a problem that has become one of the nation's most notorious.


Sales Below Estimate at a 2d Auction
LEAD: Willem de Kooning's ''Palisade,'' an abstract parkway landscape from 1957 in bold, colorful strokes, was sold for $7.2 million at Sotheby's in New York last night.
The price was the highest paid in an auction at which the selectivity of the market became clear.
Although 10 records for the works of artists were rewritten, several major paintings did not sell, and others brought prices at or below their estimates.


Workers Disrupt Pan Am Meeting
LEAD: More than 150 union employees, angry over continuing losses at the Pan Am Corporation and the lack of a contract, jeered at the airline company's annual meeting and threatened to strike.
Pan Am's 6,500 union reservation agents, cargo agents and clerical workers have worked without a contract for two years.

Allied, Federated Report '89 Losses
LEAD: The Allied Stores Corporation, a unit of the Campeau Corporation, which is protected from creditors under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code, had a $925.2 million loss in 1989, according to a Securities and Exchange Commission filing.
Allied sales rose 5.2 percent in 1989, to $2.71 billion, up from $2.57 billion in 1988.

LEAD: Mayor James L. Usry, who has been indicted, and City Councilman Jim Whelan were the two top vote-getters in today's nonpartisan mayoral election, setting up a June 12 runoff in this casino city.

LEAD: Recent cases of racial harassment on the nation's campuses and a general atmosphere of racial tension have become increasingly important factors in the decisions made by many black families about where to send their children to college, according to high school counselors and black students and their families.

Economic Scene;   Small Business, Large Mirage
LEAD: THESE are disillusioning times.
Evangelists steal, athletes cheat and even old Bossy the cow has been caught wreaking death and destruction.
But at least one culture hero remains untarnished: the small business, America's engine of employment and prosperity.


Toshiba Shows Faster Laptop
LEAD: The Toshiba Corporation today introduced the first laptop computer built with Sun Microsystems Inc.'s Sparc microprocessor.
The Toshiba Sparc LT, AS1000/L10 weighs 17.7 pounds and is priced in Japan at the equivalent of about $13,200.
The company plans to start shipping the computer in Japan in mid-July.


Savings Bond Sales Up
LEAD: Sales of United States savings bonds rose 11 percent in April over the month last year, increasing the total value of bonds held by Americans to a record $120.49 billion, the Treasury Department reported today.
The Treasury said sales last month totaled $703 million, up from $634 million sold in April 1989.


At Wesleyan, a Day to Reflect on Racial Tension
LEAD: Hundreds of Wesleyan University students gathered this afternoon on the broad campus green to sit and tell stories of hate and fear.


A Printer Translates Into Braille
LEAD: A new computer printer can translate letters and numbers into Braille characters and reproduce graphic images in relief, using standard office paper.
The first graphics printer for the blind was introduced recently by Howtek Inc., a Hudson, N.H., company that developed the machine in cooperation with the National Federation of the Blind.

Review/Piano;   A Recitalist to Undermine a Critic
LEAD: About halfway through Mordecai Shehori's piano recital on Monday evening at Weill Recital Hall, it occurred to me that I was enjoying myself much too much.
Part of a reviewer's duty is to pay unwavering attention to the mechanical details that form the base of any proficient performance.
That, however, proved difficult to do because the techniques of playing the instrument were continually being upstaged by the music itself.


High Salaries At Columbia
LEAD: Columbia Savings and Loan Association's top executives received $4 million in bonuses in 1989, even as the association's holdings of high-yield ''junk bonds'' led to a $591.1 million loss for the year.


Chronicle
LEAD: Archbishop EUGENE A. MARINO, the highest ranking black in the nation's Roman Catholic hierarchy, has temporarily relinquished his duties as the head of the archdiocese of Atlanta after physicians found him at risk of a heart attack, a spokesman said yesterday.


British Jet Down Off Sardinia
LEAD: A British military jet taking part in a NATO exercise crashed 20 miles southwest of Sardinia shortly before dawn today.
Searchers found the wreckage of the plane, an AV-8 Harrier, but the pilot was missing and presumed dead, a British Defense Ministry official said.
The cause of the crash was not known.


Dallas Times Herald Loses Its Suit Over Features Deal
LEAD: A jury said today that The Dallas Times Herald was not harmed by the loss last fall of 26 comics and features to its larger rival, The Dallas Morning News, and voted, 10 to 2, to decline a damage award.

Roberto Kelly said he simply forgot to take his sunglasses with him to the outfield.

LEAD: Prices of cocoa futures declined sharply yesterday on New York's Coffee, Sugar and Cocoa Exchange as rain forecasts improved crop prospects in Africa and South America.

He was 53 years old and lived in Washington.

Legislators Plan Bottle Tax To Help Reduce Budget Gap
LEAD: Legislative leaders have tentatively agreed to place a 2-cent tax on nonrefillable bottles, a move that could raise at least $90 million a year and help close New York State's $4 billion budget gap, legislative officials said today.


Texas Oil's Sales
LEAD: The USX Corporation said its Texas Oil and Gas Corporation unit had agreed to sell oil and gas properties and related assets for $193 million to ARCO Oil and Gas Company, a unit of the Atlantic Richfield Company, and the Sonat Exploration Company.
USX said talks were continuing with bidders on other oil and gas assets.


Racketeering Charge Against Judge Dropped
LEAD: The Justice Department has decided not to try a Federal district judge for the second time on a charge of racketeering brought under an act intended to fight organized crime.
But it will bring the judge, Robert P. Aguilar, to trial again on five other charges.


Failure Found in Generic Drug for Cystic Fibrosis
LEAD: A generic drug prescribed for cystic fibrosis patients was found to be ineffective and not equivalent to a brand-name compound in a small study.
The researchers said the findings showed that the type of drugs involved should be regulated by the Government.


Peru to Resist Suits by Banks
LEAD: A lawyer representing the Government of Peru said yesterday that the nation would seek the dismissal of 11 lawsuits filed by international banks trying to recover at least $2 billion in debts.

Reviews/Music;   Mozart to Cage at Chamber Society
LEAD: The Chamber Music Society of Lincoln Center concluded its 21st season last night at Alice Tully Hall with a program that, in its stark juxtaposition of traditional and modern fare and its heavy concentration of guest performers, epitomized a year of transition.
Fred Sherry, in his first season as artistic director, profoundly shook up an organization that many felt had grown complacent over the two decades since its founding by Charles Wadsworth.

The real estate and investment management company said it had cut back on employees who work on direct offerings of real estate to concentrate on raising money from institutional and investment banking sources.

LEAD: Stephen J. Borell, a piano tuner and technician for some of the world's best-known musicians, died of colon cancer on Monday at his daughter's home in Cumberland, R.I.
He was 66 years old and lived in Astoria, Queens.


Arch Moore Pleads Guilty
LEAD: Former Gov.
Arch A. Moore Jr. today fulfilled an agreement with Federal prosecutors by pleading guilty to an indictment charging extortion, mail fraud, tax fraud and obstruction of justice.
Mr.
Moore, a 67-year-old Republican, struck the plea bargain with the Government last month.
He faces imprisonment of up to 36 years and fines of as much as $1.2 million when he is sentenced July 10.

Lotte Jacobi, 93; Photographer Made Portraits of Artists
LEAD: Lotte Jacobi, a fourth-generation photographer who fled Nazi Germany in 1935 and won fame with her sensitive portraits of scientists, statesmen and luminaries in the arts, died of pneumonia on Sunday in the Havenwood Nursing Home in Concord, N.H.
She was 93 years old and lived in Deering, N.H.


150 Jews Visit a House Where Genocide Was Born
LEAD: Proclaiming that ''memory is stronger than its enemies,'' about 150 representatives of Jews from around the world gathered today at Wannsee Villa, the lakeside mansion where officials of the Third Reich met 48 years ago to outline the policy of Nazi genocide.

Home Resale Drop Is 1.6%
LEAD: Ex-isting house sales declined 1.6 percent in the first quarter, a real estate trade group said today, as mortgage rates anchored themselves in double digits and prices in many areas continued to rise.


China to Sell Companies
LEAD: China plans to sell four small state-owned companies in the Shenzhen special economic zone near Hong Kong to foreign or domestic interests, The People's Daily said today.
The newspaper said all of the concerns were poorly managed and losing money.


Survey Cites Problems At Black Companies
LEAD: The nation's largest black-owned companies, hurt by weakness in the economy last year, had virtually flat sales and a sharp decline in employment, according to a survey by Black Enterprise magazine.


Nissan Prospers Despite Errors
LEAD: Making mistakes in the United States is nothing new to the Nissan Motor Company.
The third-largest Japanese auto maker in the market tried three times unsuccessfully to introduce a mini-van, failed to anticipate changes in American taste and underwent a name change that alienated some dealers and confused consumers.

LEAD: Responding to disclosures that Israeli weapons shipped to a Caribbean island ended up with a Colombian drug trafficker, the Israeli authorities said today that they had followed all procedures meant to prevent such diversions.

LEAD: An Immigration and Naturalization Service employee was charged yesterday with taking more than $100,000 in bribes in return for helping to provide Colombian drug smugglers with cards identifying them as permanent residents, the authorities said.

Swiss Consider Joining I.M.F.
LEAD: Switzerland, whose aversion to joining world organizations is legendary, is considering becoming a member of the International Monetary Fund.

Grandiose Central Terminal
LEAD: ''Grand Central Prepares for the 21st Century,'' reads the headline on a Metro-North news release about its plan to renovate the great landmark.
The commuter railroad proposes to restore the terminal esthetically and structurally, and add an array of retail stores.
But delve past the exciting prospectus and it's clear that Metro-North knows more about what it wants to do than how to do it.

Caviar: Black Gold In America
LEAD: IT was at the exclusive Broadmoor Hotel in Colorado Springs that Frank Hale had his first taste of caviar.
The year was 1964 and he was working as a busboy.
He was standing in the kitchen when the chef came over with a cracker. ''I spit it out,'' recalled Mr.
Hale, the 50-year-old son of a Baptist minister, unashamed to say in his Southern twang that he could not understand why anyone would pay through the nose for fish eggs.


Brooklyn IND Train Kills 2 Signal Workers
LEAD: An IND subway train bound for Coney Island struck and killed two transit workers on an elevated stetch of track in Brooklyn during the evening rush yesterday.

LEAD: The dollar closed mixed in United States trading yesterday after strengthening slightly in Europe, but money brokers said the underlying direction of the American currency remained unclear.
Gold prices fell.

About Education;   Instead of being a crucible for scientists, introductory courses tend to distill them out.
LEAD: Every year, almost 2,500 students at the University of Arizona take introductory chemistry.
But only about 20 graduate as chemistry majors.
This sends a message: introductory science courses, instead of attracting students to science, may scare them away.

Toyota Is Buying More Delco Parts
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation's Delco Products division will export suspension struts later this year to the Toyota Motor Corporation in Japan.
G.M. said it expected to supply about 500,000 struts a year from its factory in Kettering, Ohio, for use in Toyota Corollas.


Christopher Chodoff, Antiques Dealer, 81
LEAD: Christopher Chodoff, a New York antiques dealer and furniture designer, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 81 years old.


Shortfall In Pension Funds Cited
LEAD: The pension funds of 50 large companies are each $40 million or more short of the funds they would need to meet all their obligations, should they close, and together those corporations are potentially short $14 billion, the Pension Benefit Guaranty Corporporation, a Government agency, said yesterday.


A. Plunket Greene, 57, A Fashion Executive
LEAD: Alexander Plunket Greene, a fashion executive who with his wife, Mary Quant, helped revolutionize the British fashion scene in the 1960's, has died, his family said.


In a Switch, Bush Offers to Stop Producing Chemical Weapons
LEAD: In a policy switch, President Bush has offered to end the production of chemical weapons if the Soviet Union agrees to American proposals, including one to bring about deep cuts in the two nations' poison gas supplies, Administration officials say.


Chronicle
LEAD: At age 79, MARY G. ROEBLING decided it was time to step down as the chairman of the National State Bank, one of New Jersey's largest independent banks.
That was six years ago.
Since then, ''I've never been so busy,'' she said.
At 30, she was the first woman to head a major bank, the Trenton Trust.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
CYCLING
Bishop Is Winner of Seventh Stage
In a bravado performance, Andy Bishop of Tucson, Ariz., rode far in front for the last 70 miles yesterday and won the seventh stage of the Tour de Trump race.
The 11-day race will end Sunday in Boston.
For the fourth consecutive day, Vycheslav Bobrik, a 19-year-old Soviet amateur, was the overall leader.


Corrections
LEAD: An article on Friday about Sharpe James's first term as Mayor of Newark misstated the infant mortality rates for Newark and New Jersey.
In 1988, the last year for which figures are available, the city's rate was 19.3 per 1,000 births, and the state's was 9.8 per 1,000.

F.D.A. Quashes Claims for a Cookie
LEAD: It was a treat that was just too good to be true.
The Phoenix Fiber Cookie, said to have just 124 calories, 2.2 grams of fat and 10 grams of fiber, promised to help dieters lose 14 pounds in 14 days.
It was also supposed to be useful in treating cardiovascular disease, colon cancer, diabetes and diverticulitis, according to promotional literature.


'Gasohol' May Cut Monoxide but Raise Smog, Study Asserts
LEAD: A study prepared for the oil industry and released yesterday has cast doubt on a much-discussed method of fighting air pollution, concluding that requiring grain alcohol in gasoline will produce a minor reduction in carbon monoxide, but a large increase in smog.
An amendment to the Clean Air Act approved by the Senate would mandate such a change.

Parent &amp; Child
LEAD: PERHAPS more than any other sign of adulthood, the marriage of a child redefines the relationship between the generations.
Psychologists and others who study families say these changes are often predictable and usually start when the couple announces its engagement.

Cambodia: Don't Look Away
LEAD: With each passing day of political stalemate, the human toll in Cambodia escalates.
After surviving mass murder and slave labor under Pol Pot and the Khmer Rouge, Cambodians both within the country and in encampments along the Thai border continue to suffer in silence.

LEAD: Under pressure from service industries, lawmakers are looking for alternatives to the sales taxes on services that they had agreed to earlier.


Evolution in Europe;   ALBANIA DROPPING CURBS ON WORSHIP AND BAN ON TRAVEL
LEAD: Albania today announced a series of laws that may bring about far-reaching liberalization in this most restrictive of European Communist countries.
They include a measure providing for freedom to travel abroad and, apparently, restoration of the right to practice religion.


Mattel Declares 3/-a-Share Payout
LEAD: Mattel Inc. said its board had declared a quarterly dividend of 3 cents a share.
It will be the company's first dividend since June 1983.
The toy maker, based in Hawthorne, Calif., faced several years of large losses and operating difficulties but has returned to profitability.

Florida Paper's Demise
LEAD: The Clearwater Sun ended publication last Friday after 76 years in business. ''We were unable to make an effective business,'' Bruce E. Coury, publisher of Clearwater Newspapers Inc., said in a statement.
Last summer, the newspaper, which was owned by the Hearst Corporation, switched from daily publication to a tabloid-size weekly focusing exclusively on news in Clearwater.

Fokker Sees Big Profits This Year
LEAD: The Dutch aircraft maker Fokker N.V., which was saved from bankruptcy less than three years ago, said its profits could double this year after trebling in 1989.
Last month, the company said its 1989 net profits rose threefold, to 42.4 million guilders, or about $23 million.


Pull Up a Chair and Pass the Handcuffs
LEAD: THE northwest corner of the Fashion Institute of Technology has never been so busy.
From morning to night, people stop and stare through the windows at ''Flat Tops,'' four table-top designs by five designers.


WIDE PERIL IS SEEN IN PASSIVE SMOKING
LEAD: After the first major Government study of the risks of secondhand cigarette smoke, the Environmental Protection Agency has tentatively concluded that it causes 3,000 or more lung-cancer deaths annually and a substantial number of respiratory illnesses and deaths among the children of smokers, Federal officials said today.

Computers and Other Targets;   How Japan Learns, and Wins, Even by Losing
LEAD: Japan's Fifth Generation Computer project, now in its ninth year, has met so few of its vaunted goals that Japanese officials are now plotting another course toward achieving superiority in advanced computers.
Observers who scoff at industrial policy can cite this as another failure of government attempts to pick winning technologies.


U.S. Talks to Banks About Easing Poland's Debt
LEAD: The Bush Administration told Congress today that it opposed writing off American Government debt in Eastern Europe, but raised the possibility that commercial banks could forgive a portion of their debts and provide Poland with additional loans through special provisions of the Brady debt reduction plan.


Old Error Stalls Focusing of Space Telescope
LEAD: An error made years ago in planning has set back efforts to focus the Hubble Space Telescope and delayed by at least another week an attempt to take the first picture of the heavens with the $1.5 billion instrument.

Study Set on Future of the Concorde
LEAD: The British and French aircraft makers that built the Concorde formally announced today a two-to-three-year study on the feasibility of building a successor to the supersonic airliner.
The plane that is envisioned would fly much farther, carry at least twice as many passengers and offer ''normal fares,'' including economy prices.


U.S. to Press Japan Goals
LEAD: The United States will continue to press Japan to open its semiconductor markets to American and foreign competition, the assistant United States trade representative, Donald Phillips, said today.


Toro to Close Plant
LEAD: The Toro Company said this week that it planned to close its Lawn-Boy plant in Plymouth, Wis., and shift Lawn-Boy riding products and space heater manufacturing operations to an existing Lawn-Boy plant in Sardis, Miss.
Toro said it also planned to stop producing snow throwers and tillers as part of the move.

Net Rises at Grey
LEAD: Grey Advertising reported net income of $2.8 million, or $2.03 a share, for the quarter ended March 31, up 12 percent from the corresponding period of 1989, when net income was $2.5 million, or $1.77 a share.
Revenues for the most recent quarter were $104.3 million, up from $94 million in the period in 1989.
