LEAD: To the Editor:


Thomas Nervous but Well
LEAD: Before every playoff game, Isiah Thomas is nervous.
His stomach is jittery.
His heart is pounding.
Thomas compares it with the feeling a college student gets before a final exam.
But through the years, Thomas has learned to make that nervousness work for him.

LEAD: A National Collegiate Athletic Association committee has recommended that underclassmen who make themselves eligible for professional drafts be allowed to resume their college careers if they change their minds about becoming professionals, whether or not they have been drafted.


Experimental AIDS Drug Has Mixed Results

Close to Home
LEAD: WHAT I did was this: Left the house in the early morning, took a bus up Eighth Avenue to 40th Street, debarked, entered Port Authority, hung a left past the orange juice stand and pulled $23 for a ticket on New Jersey Transit off my roll.
This big spender was going to Atlantic City.

Arch Moore Pleads Guilty
LEAD: Former Gov.
Arch A. Moore Jr. fulfilled an agreement with Federal prosecutors on Tuesday by pleading guilty to an indictment charging extortion, mail fraud, tax fraud and obstruction of justice.
Mr.
Moore, a 67-year-old Republican, struck the plea bargain with the Government last month.
He faces imprisonment of up to 36 years and fines of as much as $1.2 million when he is sentenced July 10.

LEAD: Enno Poersch, a co-founder of the Gay Men's Health Crisis, died of AIDS on Sunday at his home in Manhattan.
He was 45 years old.
Mr.
Poersch, a graduate of Yale, was a set designer for the stage and films and had also worked as a graphic designer.

The Pearl's Back-Door Induction
LEAD: In sports, a Hall of Fame is more than a gallery of bronze busts or plaques.
Of all the subjects in sports, a Hall of Fame is the most subjective.
Whether an elector or a fan, everybody has different standards as to who should be in, who should not, and why.
Since it is so subjective, one person's standards are as valid as anyone else's.

Man Held in Death of Son, 2
LEAD: A Bronx man was arrested yesterday and charged with killing his 2-year-old son, the police said.
The police said the father, Daniel Singleton, 24, of 180 Brook Avenue in the Mott Haven section, beat his son, Daniel Jr., to death on Tuesday morning.
The boy's mother, Josephine St.
John, 26, took him to Lincoln Hospital, where she claimed that he had injured himself the day before in a fall, the police said.


Fight at Seton Hall
LEAD: A fight among members of Seton Hall University's basketball team last week, in a dormitory that houses many of the players, resulted in a broken jaw for Joe Remimbas, a senior guard, and an investigation that may take several weeks.


Darling and Ojeda Squirming in Limbo
LEAD: Ron Darling sat in the dugout last night even though he probably should have been in the bullpen.
Davey Johnson had told him to be ready as a reliever.
Bob Ojeda started even though he became a resident of the bullpen before the season began.
Johnson told him six starters was too many and one had to go.

LEAD: Girls as young as 12 are more prone to depression than boys, new studies show, and a prime factor is their preoccupation with their appearance.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said it would consolidate its typewriter business by moving certain operations to Kentucky, in a streamlining step that would not involve layoffs.

Using Satellites To Navigate Cars
LEAD: A new car navigation system that uses satellites to plot a vehicle's location and displays it to the driver on a computer map will go on sale next month in Japan, the Pioneer Electronic Corporation said.
The device is the first such system available on the retail market, said Toru Yokomizo, a Pioneer spokesman.


Stocks Recover From Selloff; Dow Off 0.68
LEAD: Stocks rebounded late yesterday after a strong selloff, but still failed to manage a gain for the day.
The Dow Jones industrial average slipped 0.68 point at the close, to 2,732.88, thus breaking a string of seven gains in a row.


Corrections
LEAD: An article yesterday about the Israeli response to a proposal by Senator Daniel Patrick Moynihan misstated the reason he gave for his proposal.
Calling on Israel to release hostages, the Senator said they were being held in violation of international law, but he did not ask for the move as a good-will gesture to Iran.


South Pacific Trade Pact
LEAD: New Zealand and Australia said this week that they would achieve free trade starting July 1 -five years ahead of schedule.


Next's Machine With Fast Chip
LEAD: Next Inc. said today that it would offer a version of its computer based on Motorola Inc.'s 68040 microprocessor later this year.

Tax cuts versus tax hikes.
And I am not going to raise taxes, period.'' - George Bush, discussing differences between him and Gov.
Michael S. Dukakis.

Nasturtiums, An Old Friend
LEAD: IT IS impossible to visit the Isabella Stewart Gardner Museum here now without thinking about what is missing since the night of March 19, when thieves disguised as policemen removed three Rembrandts, a Vermeer and several other works of art that were of incalculable value to the museum's collection.


Senate Ethics Panel Votes To Investigate Durenberger
LEAD: The Senate Ethics Committee voted today to conduct a full investigation of Senator Dave Durenberger's handling of a Minneapolis condominium apartment, asserting there was strong evidence that the Senator ''may have abused his United States Senate Office and misused United States Senate funds.''

LEAD: ''I'm so optimistic.'' That's the significance of the mysterious acronym in the name of the ISO Dance Theater, which bounded through a gala performance Tuesday night at the Joyce Theater.
It is easy to be optimistic about ISO; its shows are goofy fun.
But the apparently casual silliness derives from great theatrical shrewdness.

Behind Thai Boom: The Japanese
LEAD: Asia is replete with economic miracle stories, so it is little surprise that Thailand has joined the list as having one of the world's fastest-growing economies.
As evidence, the number of cars have tripled, choking traffic, and cement is in short supply as prosperous-looking houses and industrial parks rise almost at once.


N.H.L. Agrees to Expansion in California
LEAD: The National Hockey League's expansion of the 1990's got off to a bumpy start today when the league's board of governors awarded the Gund brothers a franchise in northern California as part of a deal in which they sold the Minnesota North Stars to a group that will keep the team in the Twin Cities.

LEAD: Luxembourg's envoy to the North Atlantic Treaty Organization has resigned after he committed a minor security infraction, Foreign Minister Jacques Poos told Parliament today.

LEAD: Conditions attached to loans from the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund are depriving third world nations of the ''freedom of action to order our economic policy priorities,'' Venezuelan Foreign Affairs Minister Reinaldo Figueredo said today at a meeting of the United Nations' Economic Commission for Latin America and the Carribean.

Review/Music;   A Harp Commands The Spotlight
LEAD: Last Thursday evening, at the same time the Van Cliburn Piano Competition was showing off last year's winner in Carnegie Hall, the International Harp Contest in Israel presented its most recent winner, Isabelle Moretti of France, in Alice Tully Hall.
While the former event more effectively captured the public's imagination, the latter may have been at least as rewarding musically, and this despite the harp's more limited repertory.

Mr.
Muller made his home in Pompano Beach, Fla., for the last 27 years.
He was 96 years old.

Waiting in Texas: Will Floods Take Everything?
LEAD: Benny DeWitt rounded up his cows on Tuesday and moved them to higher ground.

LEAD: After being held for 11 weeks in a Vermont jail for failing to identify themselves after being arrested, 95 protesters against abortion did so and were released today.


Evolution in Europe;   NATO Splits on Removing Nuclear Artillery From West Germany
LEAD: West German and Dutch officials said today that NATO should move quickly to withdraw nuclear-tipped artillery shells from German soil.

I.B.M.-Prentiss Venture
LEAD: The NCNB Corporation has lent more than $100 million to the International Business Machines Corporation and Prentiss Properties to build offices in Austin.
The agreement provides financing for a 1.1-million-square-foot office complex to be occupied by I.B.M.
Prentiss Properties is the developer and Austin Industries is expected to be named the contractor.


Review/Theater;   Musical From a Virginia Woolf Novel
LEAD: Virginia Woolf wrote the last pages of ''The Waves'' with ''such intensity and intoxication'' as to remind her of the times she was overcome by madness.
With its torrential language and metaphorical interludes, the novel completely reflects the author's obsessive self-concern.
Chronicling the interlocked relationships of six friends in Edwardian England, it is, to borrow the words of one of the characters, ''a mysterious illumination'' of life unto death.


Another Student Faces Indictment In St. John's Case
LEAD: At least one more St.
John's University student was indicted yesterday in a case in which three students have been charged with sexually assaulting another student in an off-campus house, law-enforcement officials said.

Joffrey Board Tries to Decide the Fate of Its Troupe
LEAD: The board of the troubled Joffrey Ballet spoke by telephone hookup yesterday in New York and Los Angeles to try to decide on the direction of the company.
The meeting came after four days of lengthy negotiations between representatives of the Joffrey and Gerald Arpino, the former artistic director and resident choreographer of the company.


Westinghouse Contract
LEAD: The Westinghouse Electric Corporation said on Tuesday that it had signed a $10.8 million contract to equip the Warsaw airport with an air traffic control system featuring the most advanced technology.
The contract, to be completed in 15 months, is the biggest by a United States company in Poland since the Solidarity-led Government took over last September, the company said.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Monday about a news conference protesting remarks by the columnist Jimmy Breslin misstated the circumstances under which an editor left New York Newsday in 1987.
The editor, John Cotter, left after he was reported to have made racial remarks about a black Newsday editor; Mr.
Cotter has denied making the remarks.


BORDER SCREENING AGAINST CRIMINALS IS SEEN AS FLAWED
LEAD: The computerized information system used by customs agents to screen visitors to the United States is so flawed that major drug traffickers and other criminals may be able to enter the country without detection, Federal investigators have concluded.


Cuomo Plan: Protect Jobs, Raise Taxes
LEAD: New York's state government, which is struggling to close a $4 billion budget gap, employs more workers in relation to its population than any of the other nine largest states.
But this year, as in most years, the budget will almost certainly not be balanced by laying off employees.

LEAD: Yields of money market funds monitored by IBC/Donoghue's Money Fund Report were down for tax-exempts and unchanged for taxables for the week ended yesterday.

LEAD: An electronics distributor pleaded guilty on Tuesday to paying $113,000 in kickbacks to a senior buyer at Norden Systems Inc.


Currents;   Get Milk; Sharpen Pencils
LEAD: LORRAINE SHIRKUS, a product designer and painter, imagined what a napkin might look like if an architect began doodling after being stood up at lunch. ''Faux Lunch,'' a cotton place mat and complementary napkin, is the result.


Dollar Off Sharply on Fears Of Softening U.S. Economy
LEAD: The dollar fell sharply yesterday against most major currencies as the foreign exchange market grew increasingly concerned about indications that the United States economy is softening.

LEAD: A jury today found a man guilty in the poisoning of the Treaty Oak, a centuries-old tree that was severely damaged by a powerful herbicide.

Connecticut Assembly Approves 14-Day Delay for Gun Purchases
LEAD: The General Assembly today narrowly approved a bill that would require a 14-day ''cooling off'' period between the initiation of most gun transactions and the final delivery of the weapon.


Author Updates Ovid Impertinently
LEAD: It came as no suprise to the Austrian writer Christoph Ransmayr last year that the censorship bureau of the Romanian dictator Nicolae Ceausescu objected to a passage from his novel ''The Last World.'' Despite the fact that the chapter is an account of an imaginary speech by the Roman poet Ovid to the Emperor Augustus, its meaning was all too clear to Romanian officials.

LEAD: Housebuster, the fastest 3-year-old this side of the Triple Crown, won his seventh consecutive stakes race yesterday when he led all the way in the $118,400 Withers Stakes on opening day at Belmont Park.

LEAD: After barely a month in office, New York City's new Health Commissioner has upset some of his prime supporters as well as critics by abolishing an AIDS-prevention program for drug abusers, who are now the main source of AIDS cases.

LEAD: The dean of students at a junior high school in Washington Heights has been indicted on charges of sexually abusing a 13-year-old seventh grader, the Manhattan District Attorney, Robert M. Morgenthau, said yesterday.

U.S. Opens Case Against 3 Futures Traders
LEAD: In its opening argument today before a packed Federal courtroom here, the Government laid out details of its case against three futures traders charged with routinely defrauding customers.
The trial is the first stemming from the extensive undercover inquiry of trading fraud in Chicago's futures markets.

LEAD: SmithKline Beecham P.L.C., the merged health, household products and pharmaceuticals company, said today that its first-quarter profit jumped 42.1 percent because of the sale of some businesses.


Home Improvement
LEAD: METAL porch railings need proper care to preserve their appearance and sturdiness.
Many newer railings are made of aluminum, which needs little maintenance.
But steel and wrought-iron railings are prone to rust and require close attention.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Riney's First Spot For Carvel Ice Cream
LEAD: Hal Riney has a gravelly voice that is occasionally heard narrating commercials.
Tom Carvel, the ice cream man, had a mumbly voice that often narrated his company's spots.
In February, when Hal Riney &amp; Partners won the Carvel Corporation account, many wondered whether the ad man would replace the marble-mouthed entrepreneur.


Judge Critical Of Dinkins Over Boycott
LEAD: A Brooklyn judge issued an order yesterday barring demonstrators from picketing within 50 feet of two Korean-American food stores.
In doing so, he criticized Mayor David N. Dinkins, expressing regret that the Mayor had not intervened personally to help end the four-month-old boycott that began over a dispute with a black customer.


Wellcome Dropping Its T.P.A. Heart Drug
LEAD: The Wellcome Foundation Ltd. has dropped its plans to develop and sell a drug for heart attack victims in the wake of a jury decision that the drug infringes patents held by Genentech Inc.


Bond Sale's Yields Defy Predictions
LEAD: The Treasury wrapped up its quarterly refunding auctions yesterday by selling $10 billion worth of 30-year bonds at yield levels well below what most credit market analysts had thought possible little more than a week ago.


Apparel Stores Lead in Retail Gains
LEAD: Helped by sales of Easter and spring merchandise, apparel stores continued to outperform the rest of the retailing industry in April, according to figures released yesterday by several big store chains.

College Aid Form Is a Model of Confoundedness
LEAD: To the Editor:


The Law and Marion Barry Jr.
LEAD:
1974: Marion S. Barry Jr. is elected to the District of Columia City Council and re-elected in 1976.
Nov. 7, 1978: Mr. Barry is elected mayor. He is re-elected in 1982 and 1986.
May 22, 1987: United States Attorney Joseph deGenova announces an investigation into allegations of fraud in city government.


Reviews/Film;   Life, Sex, Death and Chaos
LEAD: At the start of ''The Big Bang,'' the film's director, James Toback, sits in an elegant restaurant with his eventual producer, Joseph H. Kanter.
As Mr.
Toback argues that he has a good if unlikely idea - a movie in which ordinary and quasi-famous people talk about life, sex, death and chaos - the scene nods at ''My Dinner With Andre,'' the classic model of a raconteur's film.

Review/Art;   'Marsden Hartley in Bavaria' Traces A Painter's Retreat and Renewal
LEAD: ''Marsden Hartley in Bavaria'' is an intelligent, highly focused exhibition that zeroes in on a pivotal but little-known period in the career of a major American artist.
The more than 80 works at the Baruch College Gallery do not show Hartley at his best, but they are consistently engaging, and they illuminate his personality, his thinking and the great art he subsequently made.

Thomas's 3-Pointers Bad News To Knicks
LEAD: Magic Johnson of the Los Angeles Lakers has a nickname for his best friend when a game is on the line.
He calls Isiah Thomas of the Detroit Pistons Money Time.


Worthy in Command As Lakers Rout Suns
LEAD: James Worthy, who seems to save his most spectacular games for the National Basketball Association playoffs, lived up to his reputation tonight.


Hills Defends White House Move on Japan Trade
LEAD: The United States trade representative, Carla A. Hills, told Congress today that despite recent moves by the Japanese to open their markets, the animosity toward Japan in this country had become ''a tidal wave and you have to run very fast to be in front of it.''


Israel to Hold Bank Inquiry
LEAD: Israel's Supreme Court today ordered the Attorney General to reopen an investigation into whether criminal charges should be lodged against the nation's leading banks and former directors for a stock market crash in 1983.


Pogorelich Recital
LEAD: The pianist Ivo Pogorelich is to play Haydn's Sonata in D (Hob. XVI:19), Brahms's Three Intermezzi (Op. 117), Scriabin's Sonata No. 4 (Op. 30) and Balakirev's ''Islamey'' at Avery Fisher Hall on Sunday at 8:30 P.M.
The program also includes six Scarlatti sonatas, three Chopin mazurkas and three of Liszt's ''Transcendental Etudes.


Review/Art;   So Big and So Dressed Up, New Galleries Bloom in SoHo
LEAD: NEW galleries in SoHo are a sign of business as usual, to put it mildly.
They come along nearly every week, it sometimes seems.
Still, a dozen recent arrivals to the downtown gallery scene stand out, as much for the scale and poshness of their layouts as for the art on view.


Senate Report Warns Of Surging Cocaine Use
LEAD: Nearly 2.2 million Americans use cocaine each week, more than double the number in previous Federal estimates, according to a Senate report today that offered a bleak portrait of cocaine use in the United States.


Why Not Watergate?
LEAD: The publication of Oliver North's notebooks should make us think about an awkward question.
Why have the institutions that worked so well in Watergate, correcting the wrongs of Richard Nixon, failed to deal with the constitutional dangers of the Iran-contra affair?


Walker Percy, Is Dead at 74; A Novelist of the New South
LEAD: Walker Percy, a Southern author who wrote about modern man's search for faith and love in a chaotic world in ''The Moviegoer'' and other novels, died yesterday at his home across Lake Pontchartrain from New Orleans.
He would have been 75 years old on Monday.


U.S. Chip Index Is Unchanged
LEAD: Sales of computer chips to the United States market declined in April, but the semiconductor industry's leading indicator remained constant, an industry group said today.

LEAD: Defying a veto threat, the House of Representatives today passed a measure that would require companies to grant workers up to three months of unpaid leave for the birth or adoption of children or to tend to ill family members.


Korea Boils as Economy Cools
LEAD: The tensions that fueled the big anti-Government demonstrations in South Korea Wednesday have been building for months.
And the main causes of the rising discontent have been the troubles of this nation's economy and what is seen to be the Government's inept, heavy-handed response.

LEAD: The nobles of Russia gathered tonight in a small converted church off Red Square to collectively come out of the shadows of long-enforced oblivion.


Bliss Quits Joffrey Board And Says Others Will Go
LEAD: Anthony A. Bliss, co-chairman of the troubled Joffrey Ballet, said yesterday that he had resigned from the Joffrey board.
He said he understood that David H. Murdock, the other co-chairman, had also resigned, and that Frank W. Lynch, vice chairman of the board, had either resigned or was about to.

Sheffield in Commotion
LEAD: A police spokesman in Tampa, Fla., has confirmed a report in The St.
Petersburg Times yesterday of a commotion in Tampa almost two months ago involving Gary Sheffield of the Milwaukee Brewers and almost involving his more famous uncle, Dwight Gooden of the Mets.
The spokesman, Willie Howell, said the confrontation was based on a case of mistaken identity and no one was arrested.


Trump Is Reportedly Selling Yacht
LEAD: Donald J. Trump has arranged to sell his 282-foot yacht in Japan for about $110 million, Wall Street executives and a lawyer close to the deal said yesterday.


Albania Reforms, Sort Of
LEAD: A crack is opening in the fastness of Albania, Europe's last bastion of Communist absolutism.
New laws will permit Albanians to travel abroad and to worship deities other than Marx, Stalin and Enver Hoxha, Albania's tyrant from 1944 until his death five years ago.
The laws were adopted unanimously, as is always the case in the People's Assembly, and just in time to provide copy for visiting Soviet and


Grace F. Salvatori, 80, Philanthropist, Is Dead
LEAD: Grace Ford Salvatori, a philanthropist who was a leading fund-raiser for the Los Angeles Music Center, died on Saturday at her home in Los Angeles.
She was 80 years old.


Hearing Planned in Research Dispute
LEAD: A Congressional subcommittee investigating a disputed scientific paper said today that it would hold a hearing to present new evidence, obtained by the Secret Service, of irregularities in the data reported by a researcher involved in the study.


NATO Plans More Cuts in Short-Range A-Arms
LEAD: The NATO Defense Ministers agreed today that the alliance could safely make further cuts in short-range nuclear weapons in response to the dramatic changes in Eastern Europe in the last year.

Reviews/Film;   A Heroes-and-Villains Tale From the Myths of Lapland
LEAD: Set in desolate, snow-covered stretches of the Arctic, ''Pathfinder'' is based on a 1,000-year-old legend passed from one generation of Laplanders to the next: a 16-year-old hero named Aigin saves a village from a roving band of thugs.
If Aigin were as familiar as Davy Crockett, American viewers would be able to enliven this bare-bones adventure with their own memories of a well-known story.


Traffic Alert
LEAD: Because of the Salute to Israel Parade, Fifth Avenue from 57th to 86th Streets will be closed on Sunday from 11 A.M. to 5 P.M.


U.N. Agency Rejects P.L.O. Role
LEAD: The World Health Organization voted today to defer indefinitely the Palestine Liberation Organization's application for full membership.


Police Colonel Slain in Chile
LEAD: Two gunmen today shot to death a former Chilean police intelligence chief, Col.
Luis Fontaine, the police and witnesses said.
Colonel Fontaine was shot seven times in the head.


Critic's Notebook;   Once Again Cannes, the Magical and the Mad
LEAD: When the carry-on baggage for the New York-to-Nice flight includes film cans, it's a sure sign of the season.
Two days ago the Croisette, the sweeping oceanfront promenade that is this city's most majestic sight, was dotted with peaceable tourists, but that changed literally overnight.
Like the glorious banks of snapdragons that line the boulevard, different in variety but crammed together in the tightest imaginable fashion, thousands of journalists, wheeler-dealers, celebrities, fans and wishful thinkers have now descended upon this formerly quiet scene.

Sales Tax on Services Is Scrapped by Albany
LEAD: Bowing to heavy pressure from businesses, New York's legislative leaders said today that they had agreed to scrap a plan that would have imposed sales taxes on services like management consulting, public relations and custom computer programming.
The leaders also eliminated a planned sales tax on magazines.

U.S. Is Reviewing Maalox Agreement
LEAD: Rhone-Poulenc Rorer said the Justice Department was reviewing its marketing agreement for its Maalox antacid treatment with the Procter &amp; Gamble Company for possible antitrust violations.
Rhone-Poulenc Rorer, the result of a merger in March between France's Rhone-Poulenc and Rorer Group Inc., based in Fort Washington, Pa., has said the pact will be a key source of earnings growth for the new company.


India Rejects U.S. Talks
LEAD: India today rejected talks with the United States over removing India from the American list of countries singled out for unfair trading practices.


How Representatives Voted On Bill to Give Workers Leave
LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 237 to 187 by which the House of Representatives today approved the family and medical leave bill.
A ''yes'' vote is a vote to approve the bill.
Voting''yes'' were 198 Democrats and 39 Republicans.
Voting ''no'' were 54 Democrats and 133 Republicans.
Y is a ''yes'' vote.

LEAD: An aerospace company and two of its managers have been charged with fraud in the Government's industry-wide investigation into falsified test reports on essential aircraft components.

LEAD: Cray Research Inc., trying to capture the low-end of the supercomputer market, will introduce a less expensive version of its high-powered Cray Y-MP supercomputer on Monday, an industry analyst said.
Rick Martin at Prudential-Bache Securities said in a report that Minneapolis-based Cray had confirmed it would introduce the system.

Panel Backs Move to Limit 'Junk Bond' Use by Insurers
LEAD: Representatives of state insurance regulatory agencies approved recommendations yesterday that are aimed at limiting insurance company ownership of high-yield, high-risk ''junk bonds.'' The restrictions are expected to be approved by all 50 regulators next month and would be binding on insurers.


Celtic Conference
LEAD: Celtic music, poetry and traditions will be featured at an all-day conference tomorrow at the Alexander Robertson School, 3 West 95th Street.
Celtic mythology and Welsh culture will be covered during the conference, which will also feature fiddle and bagpipe music and poetry readings.
It is sponsored by the Celtic League.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said it had introduced a new Model 25 personal computer that offers more functions, faster processing, 50 percent more fixed disk drive capacity and higher resolution color graphics than existing machines.

From Goldberg v. Kelly
LEAD: For qualified recipients, welfare provides the means to obtain essential food, clothing, housing, and medical care. . . .
Termination of aid pending resolution of a controversy over eligibility may deprive an eligible recipient of the very means by which to live while he waits.
Since he lacks independent resources, his situation becomes immediately desperate.

Foreign Landowners
LEAD: Foreigners continue to own just under 1 percent of the nation's agricultural land, a level that has varied little over the years, the Agriculture Department said today.

Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 508 money market mutual funds declined by $2.22 billion, to $383.5 billion, in the week that ended last Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 160 institutional funds decreased by $831.2 million, to $91.48 billion.
The assets of the 246 general-purpose funds were down by $531.6 million, to $132.17 billion.

LEAD: *
ARCO,Los Angeles, and Texaco Inc., White Plains, plan to drill exploratory wells in the Beaufort and Chukchi seas.
Texaco plans to drill 51 sites on 13 geological prospects, with exploration to start next year, said a spokesman for the Interior Department.
ARCO plans to drill two wells in an area known as the Fireweed prospect.

Review/Music;   Ashkenazy With the Berlin Radio Symphony
LEAD: Virtuoso pianists who take up conducting, as Vladimir Ashkenazy did a decade ago, begin with a theoretical advantage over most other fledgling maestros.
Their instrument's range is similar to that of the orchestra and its literature is unmatched anywhere in Western music for quantity and quality.
The pianist's outlook on music tends to be wider, if not necessarily deeper, than a violinist's, say, or a percussionist's.

Review/Film;   Manhattan's Privileged and the Plague of AIDS
LEAD: Possibly because it is the first mainstream American film about AIDS, ''Longtime Companion'' is a lot gentler and even more upbeat than it need be.

It's as if it didn't want to offend people who don't want to think about the plague (but who probably won't go to see the movie anyway).

LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany said today that the East German Government must agree to major economic changes contained in the proposed state treaty on monetary, economic and social union before the Deutsche mark can become the sole legal tender in both nations.

LEAD: A random survey sponsored by the Federal Centers for Disease Control has found far fewer people infected with the AIDS virus in Dallas County than expected, agency officials said here today.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Thursday about the tension surrounding the Bensonhurst murder trial misstated a defendant's name in some copies.
It is Keith Mondello.


BUSINESS DIGEST: SATURDAY, MAY 12, 1990
LEAD:
The Economy


Attacks on Jewish Graves Jolt France
LEAD: More than 50 graves in two Jewish cemeteries in France have been found desecrated in the last two days, bringing ominous warnings from French political and religious leaders today that a racist mood is spreading across the country.

Candy Plant Plea Denied
LEAD: A United States Government panel today turned down a request by the Swiss candy maker Jacobs Suchard Ltd. to establish a special foreign trade zone for its Chicago plant so that the plant could save money by importing sugar at world prices.

Corrections
LEAD: A front-page article yesterday about the release of 211 Chinese political prisoners carried an incorrect byline in some editions.
The article was by Nicholas D. Kristof, not Sheryl WuDunn.


Mae Sien Hong, Press Agent, 75
LEAD: Mae Sien Hong, a former press agent for the Ringling Brothers and Barnum &amp; Bailey Circus and the Harlem Globe Trotters, died of cancer on May 4 at Memorial Sloan-Kettering Cancer Center.
She was 75 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Daily News and Gannett Win Writing Prize
LEAD: Reporters for The Daily News and Gannett Westchester-Rockland Newspapers have won the 1990 Meyer Berger Award for their writings about New York City, Columbia University announced yesterday.


A Tug-of-War Over Treating Divers
LEAD: Drivers taking the lazy curve on York Street in this borough on the Delaware River must wonder what to make of the 19-foot-long cylinder that recently appeared at the headquarters of the Garden State Underwater Recovery Unit.


Keating Home In Foreclosure
LEAD: A California bank has begun to foreclose on the home of Charles H. Keating Jr., the financier whose scandal-ridden Lincoln Savings and Loan Association was taken over by the Government.
A notice filed by the Security


CHRONICLE
LEAD: The New York City Council's Committee on Parks, Recreation and Cultural Affairs was swamped yesterday by laudatory speeches for the man who help changed American ballet, the Russian immigrant who founded the School of American Ballet and the New York City Ballet.
And at the end, the committee responded with a chorus of ayes to a motion to rename West 63d Street from Broadway to Columbus Avenue GEORGE BALANCHINE


Review/Film;   Hippie Daye Here Again
LEAD: Unless fate and Hollywood take some very peculiar turns, a Judd Nelson cameo should never be the highlight of any movie.
But Mr.
Nelson, who plays himself and is ecstatically greeted as Nicholas Cage and Charlie Sheen, provides the only half-funny moment in ''Far Out Man.'' Tommy Chong - the taller, more zonked-out half of Cheech and Chong - is the writer, director and star of this pathetic story about a leftover hippie.


College to Reconsider Decision to Admit Men
LEAD: The trustees of Mills College will reconsider their decision to admit male undergraduates, the school's president said Thursday, but will reverse their vote only if another way to improve the school's finances can be devised.


Lithuania's Leaders Know What They're Doing
LEAD: To the Editor:


Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''We will never allow any group or any person to turn to violence or the threat of violence to intimidate others, no matter how legitimate their anger or frustration may be.''
- Mayor David N. Dinkins. [1:1]

Some Police Skeptical of Any Plans to Roust Beggars
LEAD: New York transit officials yesterday promised an aggressive effort to enforce a ban on subway panhandling, but some transit officers suggested that it won't be that easy.

A.T.&amp; T. Network
LEAD: The American Telephone and Telegraph Company said it was introducing a learning network combining classroom curriculum with electronic mail messaging for the education market.
The A.T.&amp; T. Learning Network matches geographically diverse classrooms by curriculum interest and grade level to form a learning circle in which students share ideas and information via A.T.&amp;T.

Bush, Trying to Quell Tax Debate, Insists Budget Talks Will Be Open
LEAD: Trying to quell the storm caused by the remarks of his chief of staff, President Bush insisted today that he was willing to discuss everything, including taxes, in the upcoming budget negotiations.


Students End Sit-In at Rutgers After 11 Days
LEAD: An 11-day student sit-in at an administration building at Rutgers University ended peacefully this morning without arrests.


Gustav H. Koven, 80; Led a Tank Company
LEAD: Gustav H. Koven, chairman of L. O. Koven and Brothers Inc., manufacturer of steel tanks in Dover, N.J., died on Thursday at Morristown (N.J.) Memorial Hospital.
He was 80 years old and lived in Green Village, N.J., and Bequia, St.
Vincent.


Charles Farrell, Actor, Dies at 88; Made Debut in 'Seventh Heaven'
LEAD: Charles Farrell, the gentle-mannered actor whose career spanned four decades, ranging from silent films to talkies to the 1950's television series ''My Little Margie,'' died on Sunday at his home in Palm Springs, Calif.
He was 88 years old.


Rickey Lee Jones to Open Riverstage Concerts
LEAD: Reebok Riverstage, an outdoor series of rock and pop concerts, is to begin on June 13 with a show by the singers Rickey Lee Jones and Lyle Lovett.
The series, which runs through Sept 9, is to include appearances by B.B.
King, Ziggy Marley and the Melody Makers, Tears for Fears, Barry White and others.


2d Lithuanian Sets Himself Ablaze, Near Soviet Border
LEAD: A Lithuanian doused his body with alcohol and set himself on fire at a border crossing between the Soviet Union and Hungary, suffering serious injuries, the police said today.

Minnesota Widens Rights Act To Counter High Court Move
LEAD: In a direct countermove to the United States Supreme Court, Minnesota has expanded its human rights law to broaden the rights of employees and subcontractors who want to take job discrimination complaints to the state's courts.

Dinkins Asks for Racial Unity And Offers to Mediate Boycott
LEAD: In a rare live television speech from a packed City Council chamber last night, Mayor David N. Dinkins appealed to New Yorkers for racial unity and said he would do ''whatever is necessary'' to maintain public order and safety.

Evolution in Europe;   Dubcek in Washington: Slovak With a Message
LEAD: Alexander Dubcek, the father of the Prague Spring, came to Washington today, not as the leader of a free Czechoslovakia, as he had thought likely for a fleeting moment last fall, but to remind Americans that Slovaks as well as Czechs carried out the revolution of 1989.


Retail Sales Show Plunge of 0.6% for April
LEAD: Retail sales, held back by another big drop in auto demand, fell by six-tenths of 1 percent in April, the biggest setback in six months, the Commerce Department reported today.


Plane Is Blown Off a Runway
LEAD: A two-engine commuter airplane was blown off a runway at Kennedy International Airport yesterday by a combination of jet blast and high winds, the Port Authority said.
No passengers were aboard the plane, an American Eagle commuter, which was caught by the blast as it crossed behind a Northwest Airlines 747 jumbo jet.


Man Sentenced to Die for Murder of Ex-Wife
LEAD: A man who used the hours of a brief prison furlough to murder his former wife was sentenced today to die in the electric chair after he told a judge that his ex-wife was to blame for her death.


BUSH SETS TARGET FOR MARS LANDING
LEAD: President Bush declared yesterday that the United States should send astronauts to Mars in the next 30 years as the long-term goal of a ''new age of exploration.''


Chairman Quits Great Northern
LEAD: The chairman of the Great Northern Nekoosa Corporation, William R. Laidig, who led the paper company's unsuccessful effort to fend off the Georgia-Pacific Corporation, left the company today with a lucrative severance package.
A company spokesman said


Businesses Offering Variant on H.M.O.'s
LEAD: Already beset by a confusing system of health care, consumers are now being offered yet another medical plan - a re-invented health maintenance organization.


Maker of Aerospace Fasteners Pleads Guilty
LEAD: The largest maker of aerospace fasteners pleaded guilty today to conspiracy and agreed to pay $18 million in fines and costs to settle Federal charges that it had schemed for 15 years to falsify test reports on parts.


New Producer for NBC 'Nightly News'
LEAD: NBC announced the appointment of a new executive producer of the ''Nightly News'' yesterday, a move that a network executive said signaled that Jane Pauley would soon become co-anchor with Tom Brokaw of the evening newscast.

Albany: Better, but Still Ducking
LEAD: Budget-making this season in Albany continues to give New Yorkers a most discomfiting insight into the failings of their political leaders.
With the budget already more than a month late, the state's top elected officials are still ducking the chance to do things right.


Irving Kobrin, Executive, 87
LEAD: Irving Kobrin, a retired business executive, died of pneumonia yesterday at Lenox Hill Hospital.
He was 87 years old and lived in Manhattan.


Cubs Hit 3 Homers in First But Stumble to Reds by 7-5
LEAD: Chris Sabo's three-run double off Mitch Williams with two out in the eighth inning tonight rallied the Cincinnati Reds past the Chicago Cubs, 7-5.


Perpetual Pollution
LEAD: To the Editor:


PRODUCER PRICES FALL 0.3% IN SIGN INFLATION IS EASING
LEAD: The wintertime jump in the nation's inflation rate appears to be wearing off, and inflation seems to be settling back to the moderate level that has prevailed over the last two years, a Government report indicated yesterday.


Review/Music;   From Folky Purity to Imprecation
LEAD: Sinead O'Connor's songs probe emotions that most pop tidies up.
Instead of romance, she sings about obsessive desire; after a breakup, she snarls her anger or bewails unbearable loneliness.
When a lover has died, she keens over his tomb (and she has more songs about dead lovers than any other woman in rock).


Sixers Hold Off Late Rally
LEAD: Charles Barkley scored 34 points and Philadelphia withstood a furious fourth-quarter rally to beat Chicago, 118-112, tonight and cut the Bulls' lead to 2-1 in their Eastern Conference semifinal series.


Corrections
LEAD: The Auctions column in Weekend yesterday misstated the total receipts at a contemporary art sale at Christie's on Monday and Tuesday.
The total for 352 lots was $53.8 million, not $71.1 million.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Justice Aide Quits Amid Tensions Over Thornburgh's Stewardship
LEAD: The second highest official at the Justice Department, Deputy Attorney General Donald B. Ayer, abruptly announced his resignation today, two weeks after he was forced to withdraw a letter of support for stringent sentencing guidelines for corporations convicted of crimes.


69,000 Toys Are Recalled
LEAD: Two manufacturers are recalling more than 69,000 toys because they contain parts that present choking hazards to small children, the Consumer Product Safety Commission said today.
Goldwell International, Inc., is recalling 13,583 Public Telephone toys that have been sold nationally since March 1989, the agency said, and Target Stores has recalled 27,000 My First Buddy Wrecker trucks, 27,000 My First Buddy Pumper fire trucks and 1,497 Potpourri Baby Dolls.

Interior Secretary Questions Law on Endangered Species
LEAD: Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr. says Congress should consider modifying the Endangered Species Act so that protection of animals and plants is balanced against benefits to society from certain kinds of development.

LEAD: For the last five months, Joel Schiavone, a wealthy New Haven developer best known for his banjo playing and off-beat publicity stunts, has waged a relentless long-shot campaign for the Republican nomination for governor.

LEAD: The prices of grain and soybean futures closed mostly lower yesterday on the Chicago Board of Trade as traders reacted negatively to the latest Agriculture Department crop reports.

LEAD: One year after attacks on the National Endowment for the Arts began, the members of the National Council on the Arts - Presidentially appointed advisers to the agency -gathered here this weekend to determine how to respond to their opponents.

Daniel Behrman, 66, An Author and Editor
LEAD: Daniel S. Behrman, an author of books on science and a former editor for Unesco, died of cancer on Wednesday at his home in Rangeley, Me.
He was 66 years old.


Corrections
LEAD: A picture caption yesterday about the House of Representatives' passage of a bill on parental leave misidentified the woman shown with Representative Patricia Schroeder.


MILITARY SERVICES PROPOSING SLASHES IN EXISTING FORCES
LEAD: Responding to instructions from Defense Secretary Dick Cheney, the military services have prepared new long-term spending plans that call for a major contraction of the armed forces by the end of the decade.


Soviets Buy More Wheat
LEAD: The Soviet Union has bought an additional 250,000 metric tons of United States wheat at subsidized prices for delivery next month, the Agriculture Department said today.
F.
Paul Dickerson, general sales manager for the department's Foreign Agricultural Service, said the wheat had been sold by two companies, which would receive subsidies under the Export Enhancement Program.


Jews Urge Washington To Oppose U.N. Move
LEAD: Leading American Jewish organizations urged the Bush Administration today to oppose any United Nations Security Council resolution criticizing Israel for settling Soviet Jews in the territories it occupied after the 1967 war.


American Stores May Sell Buttrey
LEAD: The American Stores Company said it was considering the sale of its Buttrey Food and Drug unit, which operates 44 supermarkets and combination food and drug stores in the West.
The company said its litigation with the California Attorney General prohibiting its merger with Lucky Stores and Alpha Beta supermarket chains had forced it to review all its ''marginal performing assets'' for possible sale.


CHRONICLE
LEAD: SAMMY DAVIS JR.'s health has deteriorated steadily since the cancer-stricken entertainer left a hospital eight weeks ago to recuperate at his home in Beverly Hills, Calif., friends said yesterday.
His weight was reported to have dropped to about 60 pounds.
His publicity agent, Susan Reynolds, would not comment except to say that Mr.


Sale of PTL Network May Be Near
LEAD: A court-appointed trustee says he will sell Jim Bakker's PTL satellite network to Oral Roberts University for $6 million at the end of the month unless he finds a buyer for the television ministry's entire complex.


Panel Is Told of Backlog of Savings-Fraud Cases
LEAD: The Federal Bureau of Investigation has a backlog of 234 referrals and complaints of large-scale fraud involving the nation's financial institutions, according to data released today at a Congressional hearing.

Paper Says Pretoria Put Germs in Namibian Water
LEAD: As part of an international sabotage campaign that stretched as far as Europe, a secret unit of the South African Defense Ministry put cholera germs in drinking water in Namibia, a newspaper said today.
But a health official said extensive tests turned up no traces of the germ.


Bridge
LEAD: Two unusual events ended Thursday on the East Coast.
In Atlantic City, the first Omar Sharif World Individual was won by Zia Mahmood, the globe-trotting Pakistani star, winning the record-setting first prize of $40,000.
And in Washington, a team representing Corporate America pinned a second defeat on a Congressional team, winning by 77 imps.


SEOUL'S TWO SIDES SEEM FRUSTRATED
LEAD: As life returned to normal on Seoul's scarred downtown streets, several dissident leaders conceded today that the Korean public seemed to distrust the demonstrators as much as they distrusted the Government.


United Pilots' Unit Ratifies Accord
LEAD: The United Airlines pilots' union said its executive council had ratified a tentative collective bargaining agreement, completing organized labor's formal commitment to create the nation's largest employee-owned company.
United Airlines, the nation's second-largest airline, is a subsidiary of the Chicago-based UAL Corporation.


Corrections
LEAD: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday about the stocks of cellular telephone companies misstated the value of the plant, property and equipment included in a recent acquisition by the GTE Corporation.


Court Imposes Limit on Indian Rights to Resources
LEAD: In a decision with far-reaching consequences, a Federal judge has ruled that northern Wisconsin's ''harvestable natural resources'' should be split 50-50 between the state's Chippewa Indians and non-Indians.


COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Aztar Corp., Phoenix, a casino gaming company, said it would make discretionary purchases of up to two million shares of its common stock, or about 5 percent of the shares outstanding.

Review/Music;   On One Bill, Two Firsts By Brahms
LEAD: Zubin Mehta's current program with the New York Philharmonic, presented first on Thursday evening in Avery Fisher Hall, is elegantly simple and, though it breaks no new ground, makes uncommonly good sense: Brahms's Piano Concerto No. 1 in D minor (Op. 15) and Symphony No. 1 in C minor (Op. 68).


Pope, in Mexico, Faces Rising Protestant Tide
LEAD: All week long, the Government and the Roman Catholic faithful of southeastern Mexico prepared for the arrival of Pope John Paul II today.
But at the Complete Evangelical Church of God here, the visit was greeted with an indifference bordering on hostility.

An Anti-Insect Sunscreen
LEAD: A new sunscreen that promises to take the bite out of enjoying the outdoors is now on the market.
Called Treo, it was introduced last month by Primavera Products Inc., of Northvale, N.J., and is a combination moisturizer, sunscreen and insect repellent.

Reports Spur Treasury Price Rise
LEAD: Interest rates plunged yesterday as prices of Treasury securities soared, largely on new evidence that the economy was softening and inflation fears subsiding.

But life with the Yankees goes on.

Patents;   Are Disputes Too Complex For Juries?
LEAD: The failure of a jury to agree this week on damages for Robert W. Kearns, the inventor of the intermittent windshield wiper, has lent new vigor to the debate about the role of juries in deciding complex patent disputes.


FLYING SPRING VISITORS
LEAD:
About the only place bees ads wasps are not found is Antarctica.
In this country the honeybee is so venerated that a joint resolution has been introduced in the House of Representatives to make it the national insect.
Here are the most frequent insect vistors at this time of year and what, if anything, should be done about them.


Misha Raitzin, a Tenor With Met, Is Dead at 59
LEAD: Misha Raitzin, a tenor who sang with the Metropolitan Opera, died of a lung aneurysm at his Manhattan home on Wednesday.
He was 59 years old.

Laimbeer Questionable
LEAD: While the Detroit Pistons were practicing yesterday morning in Auburn Hills, Mich., Bill Laimbeer, the starting center, was at a local hospital having his sore left knee examined and treated.


Your Money;   The 'Kiddie Tax' And Summer Jobs
LEAD: With summer approaching, many students would like to find summer jobs.
Some parents, on the other hand, being vaguely aware of the ''kiddie tax,'' are concerned about the effect that might have on the family's finances.


Kodak Raising Prices
LEAD: The Eastman Kodak Company said today that it had increased prices for rental, service and supplies for most of its copier and electronic publishing system lines.
List prices for the equipment itself will remain the same, the company said.
Kodak said it would increase copier equipment rental and service rates by 5 percent.


Manager Out at G.M. Plant
LEAD: Patricia Carrigan, who at one time was the only woman running a General Motors Corporation assembly plant, abruptly retired two weeks ago from a G.M. parts plant in Bay City, Mich., and news reports have swirled in recent days about misadministration of a benefit plan for workers at the plant.


Stephens Has Surgery
LEAD: Woody Stephens, who has trained winners of two Kentucky Derbies and is the only trainer to win five consecutive Belmont Stakes, was in critical condition last night after open-heart surgery.


Catholic Diocese Drops Speech by a Kennedy
LEAD: The Roman Catholic Diocese of Providence ordered a church high school to cancel a speech last Sunday by State Representative Patrick Kennedy, son of Senator Edward M. Kennedy, because he supports a woman's right to abortion.


Mexico Opens Bank Debate
LEAD: The Mexican Congress opened debate today on a bill that would end the Government's full control of the nation's banking industry.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: One of the most famous of all picture-postcard vistas, the Parc du Champ de Mars with the Eiffel Tower, is in for some alterations.
It will be the site of the latest, and some hope the last, of President FRANCOIS MITTERRAND's grand architectural works, the International Conference Center of Paris.


Inflation Spurt in Britain
LEAD: Britain's annualized inflation rate leaped sharply to an eight-year high of 9.4 percent in April from 8.1 percent in March.
Inflation last reached 9.4 percent in April 1982 and has climbed to its current level from a low of 3.3 percent in January 1988.
The main components in the latest rise were the introduction of a poll tax to finance local government and the increase in duties on alcohol, tobacco and gasoline.

READ MY SUPERTITLES? WHY NOT, IF IT'S APPROPRIATE?
LEAD: Opera attracts people with strong opinions.
No argument so far?
We might also agree that for some reason the art form fosters among its followers a kind of Maginot Line mentality that encourages smug rigidity.
An either/or dualism, I find, dominates a frustrating debate about projected titles in the May issue of Opera News, the monthly voice of the Metropolitan Opera Guild.

The Mortal Sphinx
LEAD: THE RIDDLE OF THE SPHINX, UPDATED: is it falling down or not?
During the replacement of masonry on the paws and flanks in the last decade, speculation has been ongoing about the ultimate fate of the monumental man-lion hybrid at Giza, Egypt.
Dating from approximately 2550 B.C., the 66-foot-high Sphinx was fashioned from low-grade limestone that historians believe was the inferior remains of the area quarried for the first pyramid.

What more glorious sight could spring have?

Review/Music;   Firkusny Is Guest for Y Chamber Finale
LEAD: The final concerts of the season's Chamber Music at the Y (meaning the 92d Street Y, of course), on Tuesday and Wednesday nights, were of uncommon interest for three reasons.
One, excellent performances.
Two, excellent and sometimes unusual music.
Three, final proof, if proof were needed, that a wildly international assemblage of musicians can be forged into idiomatic exponents of a national style.

The way the part is written, it allows no letdown.
Especially on two-performance days - we call them double-headers - that tends to feel more like an athletic event than an artistic experience.


Currency;   A Bad Week for the Dollar
LEAD: It was a bad week for the dollar.
First, on Wednesday, it dropped sharply against the West German mark, the Swiss franc and other European currencies.
Then on Friday, the other shoe fell, as the dollar plummeted against the Japanese yen.
The dollar has been weak against the mark and most Europen currencies all year but strong against the yen.

Ginger in Western Cooking
LEAD: THE Chinese use fresh ginger in their cooking the way Westerners use salt and pepper.
But in recent years it has been showing up more and more in dishes that are not in the least Chinese.
Ginger adds a refreshing tartness to fish and chicken, perks up marinades, and is also good with vegetables such as mustard greens or broccoli rabe, adding a slightly sharp spicy taste that counteracts their bitterness.

Corrections
LEAD: A brief article by The Associated Press in some editions last Sunday about anti-Semitic graffiti at Bertolt Brecht's grave in Berlin misstated the playwright's religion.
He was reared as a Lutheran; he was not Jewish.
The article also misidentified a country where Brecht lived in exile before settling in East Germany.

LEAD: As the early-morning mist comes in from the harbor in Salem, Mass., the most pleasant place to be is on the Common.

LEAD: SCAFFOLDING HAS BECOME an integral part of Spain's urban landscape.
So have construction crews, churning up clouds of dust and dirt.
On almost every major street in cities like Madrid and Barcelona, buildings shrouded in green plastic resemble giant packages waiting to be unwrapped.


WHAT WOMEN WANT FROM FEMINISM
LEAD: Vivian Gornick compares feminism to psychoanalysis, and is saddened that women seem stuck at the level at which insight does not seem to produce real change (''Who Says We Haven't Made A Revolution?'' April 15).
I think feminism has achieved more successes, is more popular and has changed women's outlooks more than Gornick recognizes, but in any case her metaphor is misleading.


Pastimes;   Bridge
LEAD: It is not uncommon for a club to arrange a Pro-Am event in which invited experts play with members.
But that requires the cooperation of many stars who may not be willing to spare the time.
Few clubs appreciate that a special evening can be built around one or two experts who play each board with a different partner.

LEAD: LAW-ENFORCEMENT officials say New Jersey's gun-control laws, which are among the strictest in the nation, are not tough enough to protect police officers and innocent bystanders from the lethal crossfire of drug-related shootings.

LEAD: While punk-era bands like the Sex Pistols, the Ramones and Talking Heads were re-energizing rock-and-roll in the United Kingdom and the United States, a group called the Clean, active in New Zealand from 1978 until 1982, was responsible for reshaping the sound of rock music in that country.

Tech Notes;   Zapping Safety Into Toxic Waste
LEAD: Researchers at Battelle Memorial Institute's Pacific Northwest Laboratories have come up with what they call a ''promising'' approach to dealing with radioactive and toxic materials contaminating ground at the Hanford nuclear reservation in Washington state: they electrocute it.
Last month, they drove four 30-foot-long graphite and molybdenum electrodes into the ground at the edges of a site, 40 feet in diameter, contaminated with cesium and strontium and hazardous chemicals.

Bush; it has to do with the role we have been led to believe she plays in the life of her husband.

CORPORTE DESIGN THAT STAYS ONTHE SAFE SIDE
LEAD: It may be easy to knock I.B.M. if you're in the computer business, but it's tougher if you're in the architecture business.
For nearly 40 years the I.B.M.
Corporation has been the business world's most consistently serious architectural patron, producing an array of buildings by the likes of Eero Saarinen, Marcel Breuer, Mies van der Rohe, Edward Larrabee Barnes and Mitchell/Giurgola that seem intended not only to serve the company's needs, but to prove beyond any doubt that a mega-corporation can engage in high-quality building on an international scale.

Ginger in Western Cooking
LEAD: THE Chinese use fresh ginger in their cooking the way Westerners use salt and pepper.
But in recent years it has been showing up more and more in dishes that are not in the least Chinese.
Ginger adds a refreshing tartness to fish and chicken, perks up marinades, and is also good with vegetables such as mustard greens or broccoli rabe, adding a slightly sharp spicy taste that counteracts their bitterness.

Communities Are Recycling Tires in Clean-Energy Program
LEAD: SEVERAL times a month, trucks laden with waste tires leave the Yonkers compacting station on Saw Mill River Road bound for Port Newark, N.J.
There, at Integrated Tire, a recycler licensed by the New Jersey Environmental Protection Department, the tires are shredded into two-inch strips and shipped to be used as a supplemental fuel in making cement.

Pastimes;   Camera
LEAD: Those whose memories of the 1970's have not faded may remember Henry Wilhelm of Grinnell, Iowa.
An early advocate of archival processing, Mr.
Wilhelm forsook a thriving business in black-and-white print washers to investigate the fading characteristics of color films.
He promised to gather independent data on all available color films and papers and to report on his results in a book.


Some Computer Conversation Is Changing Human Contact
LEAD: Patricia Gemmell met Brian Dear by replying to a friendly note that appeared on her computer screen one day, a message sent on a computer network linking her machine with many others.
She responded with a computer quip of her own and the two, who were programmers at different campuses of the University of Maryland, struck up a friendship that went on electronically for weeks before they finally met.


Honecker May Escape Trial
LEAD: The East German authorities have decided not to prosecute Erich Honecker, the ousted Communist leader, citing his failing health, the Interior Minister, Peter-Michael Diestel, said in an interview published today.


Stone Symbols Of Shaker Permanence
LEAD: As I approached the Shaker village in Canterbury, N.H., from the south, I became aware of its stone walls at the same moment I spotted the white clapboard buildings.
They vie for your attention: the simple buildings surrounded by shade trees and perched on top of a high hill, and the lichen-encrusted, gray-green walls built with stones the size of which I had never seen before in a wall.


HOME ENTERTAINMENT/RECORDINGS: RECENT RELEASES
LEAD:
CLASSICAL
Perotin: Choral Works (Plus Anonymous Works)
Hilliard Ensemble directed by Paul Hillier. ECM 1385; CD only.
In 1977, David Munrow's album ''Music of the Gothic Era'' opened many an ear with its apparent contemporaneity.
In lilting, hypnotic (and necessarily somewhat conjectural) performances, the great composers of the Notre Dame school, Perotin and Leonin, seemed to have anticipated not only minimalism, but even jazz.

Review/Theater;   'The Tower of Evil,' Dumas Revenge Tale
LEAD: Though Alexandre Dumas pere is best known for his romantic novels ''The Three Musketeers'' and ''The Count of Monte Cristo,'' he also left a legacy of plays, including ''La Tour de Nesle,'' a bloodthirsty historical melodrama written in 1832.
Despite that play's continuing popularity in France, it turns out to be creaky and contrived, not the well-oiled mechanism one would have expected.

Corrections
LEAD: An article in the Campus Life pages on April 29 incorrectly described a tenure revision proposal defeated by the faculty senate of the University of Connecticut at Storrs.
It would have given graduate students, once hired, two years to finish their Ph.D. work before the faculty began to evaluate them for tenure, a process that can last up to seven years.

WHAT WOMEN WANT FROM FEMINISM
LEAD: The author theorizes proficiently with many philosophical models.
But where are strong political models such as Golda Meir and Margaret Thatcher mentioned?
For a serious student of feminism, Gornick might serve us better with a discussion of women who use power well, or even those who have abused it, such as Indira Ghandi.

LEAD: The new Government of Chile agreed in principle today to pay compensation for the killing of Orlando Letelier, a Chilean exile leader assassinated in Washington 14 years ago.

Write Off Castro? The Odds Change
LEAD: AS Communist dictatorships tottered and fell in Eastern Europe last year, a natural question was whether the 31-year-old Cuban regime of Fidel Castro would soon be next.


If You're Thinking of Living in: Palisades
LEAD: THERE is a magical quality about Palisades, a three-square-mile heavily wooded hamlet just 12 miles north of the George Washington Bridge.
Many of the houses have no numbers, just storybook names like Pirate's Lair, Captain John, Chateau Hash, Laundry, Ding Dong.
The telltale signs of modern development - condominiums, supermarkets, shopping centers and fast-food outlets - are conspicuous by their absence.


Released Harmed
LEAD: However bad the living conditions for most foreign hostages in Lebanon, Frank Herbert Reed said they were worse for him.
Mr.
Reed, one of two recently released American hostages, said at news conference last week that he was singled out for harsh treatment by his Shiite fundamentalist abductors and that his 43 months in captivity were punctuated by beatings that at various times left his feet, ribs and nose broken.


Dogwood Trees Are in Trouble
LEAD: THE dogwood trees are in full bloom.
What more glorious sight could spring have?
These native trees, which carry their displays in layers, appear as clouds in the woods or as spectacular specimens on home lawns.
Travelers drive for miles to see favorite spots where dogwoods grow.

Spain: Hot to Be the New Spot

There, to the staccato of hammering, Pina's logo is being wreathed in a tangle of roses and barbed wire.

POSTINGS: Nuns Selling Land;   L.I. Synagogue
LEAD: A new congregation of 150 Jewish families in Woodbury, L.I., has contracted to buy six acres from Roman Catholic nuns as the site for what may be the first Conservative synagogue to be built in Nassau County in many years.
The Woodbury Jewish Center will be built on South Woods Road across the street from Our Lady of Mercy Academy, operated by the Order of the Sisters of Mercy.

LEAD: UNTIL HE DISAPPEARED LAST JUNE, Reino Gikman, the K.G.B. man who met with Felix Bloch, lived with Helga Hobart in Vienna in a gingerbread cottage surrounded by a metal fence topped with barbed wire.
Frau Hobart lives there still, protected by a fierce dog and a sign that reads ''Pflichtgetreuer Hund'' (Dutiful Dog).

LEAD: THE surveys of the cooperative market produced by a few major borkerages are theo only statistical data available on apartment sales.
They light up a few corners of an otherwise dark picture, but they cover only Manhattan, only the upper end of the market and only a small fraction of the thousands of sales that are believed to be made in New York City each year.

Good Cards, Good Crowds

A Guide to Cape Cod's Auctions
LEAD: Auctions on Cape Cod, a year-round phenomenon, are a cross between shopping, work and dinner theater.
In fact, they combine the best of all three: you can shop sitting down, play the commodities market with real commodities that you carry home in the trunk of your car, catch a comedy act without paying a cover charge and eat for under $5.


WHEN WILL THE BOOK BE DONE?
LEAD: The difficulties Susan Sheehan spoke of were not related to the actual craft of making a book.
She spoke only of externals in the author's life - a car accident and a lawsuit, in particular, that kept him from his writing table and delayed the process of completion.

On a hill 10 miles away is Monticello, the exquisite home that Thomas Jefferson built for himself, with its slave quarters still visible (even more limited in space and comfort than Poe's), and another touching memorial, a stone obelisk at Jefferson's grave recalling his role as author of the Declaration of Independence and the

Corrections
LEAD: The Practical Traveler column on April 29 misstated United Airlines' policy on exchanging a ticket when a lower fare for the same destination is advertised, based on information provided by the airline.
A ticket may be exchanged if the difference between fares is more than $25, the airline says, but all conditions for the new fare, including advance-purchase restrictions, must be met, and space must be available in the new booking class on the same flight.


From Comic Artist And Caricaturist, A Painter Evolves
LEAD: If there were a list of the top 10 artists on college dormitory walls, Lyonel Feininger would surely be on it.
His quietly dynamic paintings of new skyscrapers and old churches, old boats and new streets, composed of cubistic planes no thicker than glass or more solid than light but as hard as diamonds and fixed as keystones, have made him a dormitory star.


Fashion;   Half a Yard or So of Nylon and Spandex, and Voila!
LEAD: A swimsuit takes maybe half a yard of fabric, yet designers come up with a staggering array of new styles every year.
They cut them high or low, drape them and wrap them, try new fabrics and colors.
They want to appeal to different tastes, yes, but they must also take into account the variations in women's bodies.

Researching the Research
LEAD: The 1986 study was about immunology, but there has been no immunity from questioning the research that went into it.
A Congressional subcomittee, which has been looking into the integrity of federally financed research, has scheduled a hearing tomorrow to present what is said to be new evidence, obtained by the Secret Service, of irregularities in the data reported by a researcher involved in the study.

PORTABLE PLAYERS REWARD THEIR FANS
LEAD: For 10 years, since Sony's first Walkman, it has been possible to put music in your pocket.
The artistic consequences of this magician's trick are uncertain for the long run, and one wonders what Beethoven would have thought of traipsing about with the ''Eroica.'' As an inveterate hiker, he might even have liked the idea.

LEAD: RESTAURANT name-droppers pepper their conversations with big-deal places sporting foreign names that begin with La, Le and Chez.

The Executive Computer;   Where the Libraries Are Leading the Way
LEAD: Companies that are trying to figure out how they will manage the flow of information in the 1990's and beyond might begin their research with a trip to the library - not to take out a book but to study the ways in which libraries are preparing for the 21st century.
In the vanguard of information technology, today's librarians are as likely to be experts in work stations, networking, communications protocols, electronic imaging and fiber optics as they are in books and manuscripts.

LEAD: The Boston Ballet's new ''Swan Lake,'' staged by Konstantin Sergeyev and Natalya Dudinskaya of the Kirov Ballet and led for three weeks this month by mixed casts that pair Soviet stars with dancers from the Boston company, has inevitably attracted much attention.

NATURE WRITERS: A SPECIES UNTO THEMSELVES
LEAD: If extraterrestrials have ever visited our planet and decide to return, one of the best gifts they could bring is a home movie showing us in our infancy, as well as now-extinct animals and pristine landscapes.
Until that day, the best we can do is turn to nature writers to provide us with visions of bygone creatures, civilizations lost to history and unsullied landscapes.

Pastimes;   Stamps

Ginger in Western Cooking
LEAD: THE Chinese use fresh ginger in their cooking the way Westerners use salt and pepper.
But in recent years it has been showing up more and more in dishes that are not in the least Chinese.
Ginger adds a refreshing tartness to fish and chicken, perks up marinades, and is also good with vegetables such as mustard greens or broccoli rabe, adding a slightly sharp spicy taste that counteracts their bitterness.

Savannah's Leafy Green Squares
LEAD: When the first European settlers arrived at the site of Savannah in 1733, they saw a muddy river often littered with dead animals, a marsh populated with such inhospitable creatures as mosquitoes and alligators, and a dense forest that seemed to stretch forever.

REFERENCE
LEAD:
THE BFI COMPANION TO THE WESTERN.
Edited by Edward Buscombe. (Atheneum, $50.) Remember the western?
Edward Buscombe of the British Film Institute does, and he and a legion of contributors have produced a magnificent, lavishly packaged compendium of facts, figures, maps, thumbnail biographies and capsule reviews for the enjoyment and edification of fans of this fast disappearing cultural product.

New Yorkers, etc.

LEAD: It's everywhere - or getting there.
Canned music has escaped the home stereo to blare from concert stages.
Blame it on musicians' love of convenience, fear of mistakes or urge to modernize; blame it on the fact that audiences hear recorded music far more often than live music, and educate our ears accordingly.

THE FELIX BLOCH AFFAIR
LEAD: PARIS IN THE SPRING.
IT IS EARLY EVENING ON MAY 14, 1989 , and Felix Bloch is strolling down the Rue Faubourg St.-Honore, one of the world's most expensive shopping streets, carrying a black airline-type bag with a shoulder strap.
He pauses to look in the shop windows.
He is being watched, and the watchers think he is studying the reflections in the glass to see if he is being followed.


Q and A
LEAD:
Subletting in a Co-op
Question: I bought my co-op in July 1987 at the peak of the market.
At the time, subletting was allowed by the board of directors.
It was my plan when I bought the apartment to live in it until I needed more room.
Now, I cannot sell without taking a loss, so I want to rent my apartment.

Correction
LEAD: A table listing some sources of methane, published last Sunday with an article about cattle, omitted data on methane emissions related to coal mining.
These emissions are estimated at 38.6 million tons a year worldwide, according to the studies on which the table was based.

That is, things that people can't eat.

CORRECTION
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in the Business Forum last Sunday about merger regulations in the European Community misstated the Community's rules about when notification of a merger and certain joint ventures must occur.
Notification is required when the aggregate worldwide turnover of the companies involved is greater than $6 billion - and two or more of the parties involved have aggregate Community-wide turnover of more than $300 million each.

Bible Tax Exemption Voided
LEAD: A Federal appeals court has unanimously struck down a 1939 North Carolina law that exempted Bibles from the state sales tax.
The United States Circuit Court of Appeals for the Fourth Circuit, in Richmond, ruled Thursday that exempting the Bible, but not other literature, ''forces the state to discriminate on the basis of the contents of a book, text, or other published work, which is intolerable under the First Amendment.

WHEN LEGAL TITANS CLASH
LEAD: Your article suggests to me that the Harvard Law School may take itself a bit too seriously.
The chief architect of the law in the last decade is a man who never attended Harvard or any other law school, i.e.
Ronald Reagan.
It is temperament, not intellect, that largely determines legal decisions - a fact well illustrated by the schisms at Harvard itself.

Similarities?
Hearts in the right place and recognition of a need for change.


New &amp; Noteworthy
LEAD: PARSONS' MILL, by Timothy Lewontin. (Plume, $8.95.) Seeking the ennobling virtues of hard work, an overeducated New Englander takes a job at a Vermont sawmill. ''A delightful, surprisingly absorbing account'' of his year as an apprentice sawyer, this book ''approaches the gung-ho participatory journalism that George Plimpton performed in his athletic days,'' Bill Kent said here last year.

A Rough-Hewn Maine Seaport
LEAD: Portlanders have a homing instinct.
Stay at a bed-and-breakfast and your host regales you with the tale of the descendant who came back to see how time had transformed the old family place into the Pomegranate Inn.
Stand at the top of the plunging staircase at the Morse-Libby House, known today as Victoria Mansion, and its director recalls the Libby granddaughter's return to tell how ''Grandpa Libby'' struck fear in the hearts of youngsters who might venture down its historic slide.

Nantucket on My Mind
LEAD: The house my family has rented and lived in on Nantucket every summer since I was 3 years old was at one time, before the advent of the Coast Guard, a lifesaving station.
Weather-beaten, gray-shingled, it sits on a slight rise in the land at the eastern end of the island, the beach and the Atlantic everywhere behind it.

Pastimes;   Coins
LEAD: Christie, Manson and Woods Ltd. of London will auction a portion of a hoard of coins from the reigns of Henry I, Stephen and Henry II.
The 482 coins were discovered in a ditch in Wicklewood, a town near Norwich, Britain in 1989.
The hoard consists mainly of pennies, but a third of them are cut farthings and half-pennies.

Leave the Stock Index Futures Alone
LEAD: In New York and Washington these days, there is a lot of grumbling about stock index futures.

LEAD: Tim Wallach drove in eight runs, including six on two three-run homers, and Oil Can Boyd pitched his first shutout in five years as Montreal routed San Diego, 15-0, today.

Taunted, Woman Quits Academy
LEAD: A female midshipman has resigned from the Naval Academy four months after two male midshipmen handcuffed her to a urinal and taunted her as others snapped pictures, a newspaper here reported today.

How Gorbachev Rejected Plan To 'Shock Treat' the Economy
LEAD: In the middle of March, about 60 economists and lawyers began convening each day at a Government country house in the pine woods outside Moscow.
Their assignment was to draft laws and decrees that would transform the lethargic, state-planned Soviet economy into a free market, and do it quickly.

Correction
LEAD: Two photographs were transposed yesterday in the Headliners column in The Week in Review.
A picture of Frank Herbert Reed, the recently released hostage, was at the top of the column.
Senator Dave Durenberger of Minnesota was pictured at the bottom.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Publishing;   Too Many Books Are Coming Back Unsold
LEAD: ''GONE today, here tomorrow.'' That was how Alfred A. Knopf summed up a publisher's difficulty in selling books.
Six years after the great publisher's death, the problem is growing.

Bush's 2 Top Budget Aides Avoid Discussion of Taxes
LEAD: With budget negotiations with Congress set to begin Tuesday, two of the Bush Administration's top economic policy makers carefully avoided any statements today that might rile Congress or disclose President Bush's position on raising taxes.


Norman Wins Memorial
LEAD: Greg Norman is famous for firing ridiculously low final rounds on Sunday that nearly always fall tragically short.
But today at the Memorial he found the ultimate way to get over the hump.
He shot nothing.


Ouster at Uganda Bank
LEAD: Uganda's central bank governor, his deputy and the managing director of the country's biggest state commercial bank have been dismissed in a surprise shake-up of the banking industry here.
A statement issued on Thursday by President Yoweri Museveni's office gave no reason for the dismissal of the governor of the Bank of Uganda, Suleiman Kiggundu, and the deputy governor, Perez Bukumunhe.


Census Knocks, but Few Want to Answer
LEAD: It took Eddie Quiles exactly half an hour on a recent Saturday to knock on nine apartment doors in the South Bronx and compile one of the sorriest records in the annals of door-to-door canvassing - three households did not answer, four asked him to come back later and two told him to get lost.


Alcala Winner In Tour
LEAD: Greg LeMond came alive today, Michael Zanoli won the day's battle and Vladislav Bobrik faded into the dust.
Through it all, Raul Alcala of Mexico, as expected, won the 11-day, 1,107-mile Tour de Trump, America's premier bicycle race.

LEAD: Speculating about a possible deal involving Donald J. Trump's three casinos has almost replaced slot machines as the most popular game in Atlantic City.

Rates Expected to Drop Further
LEAD: Many participants in the credit markets say they expect a further decline in interest rates this week, as more investors in fixed-income securities become convinced that the Bush Administration and Congress are moving to confront the nation's budget deficit.


Florio Shifts Policy From School Testing To More Aid to Poor
LEAD: Gov.
Jim Florio this spring is reversing many of the nationally praised education policies of his predecessor, Thomas H. Kean, moving away from reforms that were part of the ''back to basics'' movement of the 1980's and redirecting New Jersey's resources toward overcoming the effects of poverty on children.


In South Korea, Another Spring Is Torn by Anger
LEAD: A rally to express solidarity among anti-government workers and students was disrupted this weekend when scuffling broke out on stage. ''We demand to be heard!'' a group of students shouted, trying to seize the microphone.
After heated words, the protesters were allowed to denounce the shutting down of their militant campus newspaper, and the rally ended peacefully.


Knicks Tumble To Pistons
LEAD: The Knicks were forced to try to win with a foul-plagued Patrick Ewing yesterday, but they weren't successful.
The Detroit Pistons, the National Basketball Association's defending champions and best defensive team, didn't allow it to happen.


Review/Television;   'Saturday Night Live,' With Andrew Dice Clay
LEAD: ''I want to say Happy Mother's Day to my mother and every other mother out there,'' said Andrew Dice Clay at the end of his appearance as host of NBC's ''Saturday Night Live.'' Making mothers and other women happy has never been one of his priorities before, of course.
It was the unrelenting misogyny of the comedian's enormously popular stand-up routine that led Nora Dunn, a regular cast member, and Sinead O'Connor, the scheduled musical guest, to boycott Saturday's show.

LEAD: ''This victim of hate and ignorance has a Vietnamese name.
