LEAD: East and West German economic experts set the stage over the weekend for their political leaders to negotiate a treaty that would merge the two countries' monetary, economic and social policies by midsummer.

LEAD: A livery-cab driver was shot in the face last night in Harlem by one of two men who attempted to rob him, the police said.

LEAD: With the first elections after four decades of Communist domination approaching, people here in the cradle of Romania's revolution, like many other Romanians elsewhere, are expressing not hope, but anger somewhat reminiscent of the outrage that swept President Nicolae Ceausescu from power last December.

Market Place;   The Dubious View of the Rally
LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average is within a few points of setting a high, but many money managers remain dubious that the rally will continue.
They note, for instance, that many stocks have not risen nearly as much as the Dow.


Subway Overkill
LEAD: In refusing to recognize a constitutional ''right to beg'' in New York subways, the U.S.
Court of Appeals for the Second Circuit reached the right result in the wrong way.
The court recognized interests of riders but intemperately denied any validity in the beggars' free-speech claims.


Review/Art;   After a Much-Debated Cleaning, A Richly Hued Sistine Emerges
LEAD: The project by a team of Vatican restorers to clean Michelangelo's frescoes on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel, and in the lunettes just below, has finally concluded, triumphantly, after a decade of sometimes angry debate and widespread concern over the fate of this great work.
The newly revealed ceiling looks overwhelmingly beautiful.

LEAD: The jury considering the charges against Joseph Fama in the Bensonhurst murder case asked yesterday for a legal explanation of the most serious charge against the 19-year old defendant.


Winner: Coney Island
LEAD: A MAJOR new study by an award-winning Brooklyn research group has concluded that a domed sports stadium should be built in Coney Island and financed by a novel combination of bank loans and public donations.

LEAD: Emerson Fittipaldi outdid his teammate Rick Mears with a record-shattering qualifying run today, but the defending Indianapolis 500 champion will have to wait six days to find out if he will start from the pole in the 74th Indy classic, on May 27.


U.S. Company Loses Bolivian Mining Deal
LEAD: Faced with public opposition that underscores Bolivians' deep-seated distrust of big capitalism and foreign business, the Government has backed away from a proposed mining accord with an American company.


British Deal For Kaolin
LEAD: The ECC Group P.L.C., formerly known as English China Clays, said last week that it had agreed to buy Georgia Kaolin from Combustion Engineering Inc., a unit of ABB Asea Brown Boveri, for $520 million.


TV Program for Doctors' Offices
LEAD: Whittle Communications is to announce today that it will provide an hourlong television program for doctors offices, starting in October.
The program will enable advertisers to reach a select group of consumers, especially mothers.


Ford to Idle Plant
LEAD: The Ford Motor Company said it would idle its Chicago assembly plant this week because of a shortage of orders from dealers.
The factory, which produces about 5,000 Ford Taurus and Mercury Sable models weekly, employs about 2,500 hourly workers on two shifts.

Main Builder In Stamford Is Faltering
LEAD: This is the town that the F. D. Rich Company built.
It was F. D. Rich that bulldozed virtually all of Stamford's decrepit downtown 25 years ago.
And it was F. D. Rich that erected many of the high-rise office buildings that came to symbolize Stamford's rebirth as a corporate capital.


Chronicle
LEAD: The theater world will be rallying on two fronts tomorrow to support the National Endowment for the Arts in a battle with Congress over the renewal appropriations bill for the endowment, a major dispenser of grants to the arts.
The artists oppose provisions that would require grant recipients to sign a pledge that the funds will not be used to produce obscene works of art.


Chronicle
LEAD: Forbes is going Chinese, says MALCOLM S. FORBES JR.
Starting in November, the American business magazine will be published in Chinese in Hong Kong in what Mr.
Forbes said would be ''the first worldwide Chinese-language business magazine.'' The Chinese Forbes, to be published in conjunction with the Capital Communication Corporation Ltd.


Mexico Vote On Banks
LEAD: Mexico's Chamber of Deputies has approved a constitutional amendment to allow private ownership of banks, eight years after they were nationalized.

Two Picassos Stolen From Bank in Miami
LEAD: Two paintings by Picasso valued at nearly $600,000 were stolen from the headquarters of Republic National Bank of Miami, the police have said.
Bank employees noticed that the paintings - ''Musical Instrument Cello'' and ''Bull Skull on a Draped Table'' - were missing early on Thursday, the police said.


Panel Calls for More Spending on Advanced TV &lt;
LEAD: At a time when the Defense Department appears intent on cutting back support for research on high-definition television technology, a Pentagon advisory panel is urging that support for such research be increased tenfold to at least $100 million a year for the next five years.

Dodgers Trade Randolph for A's Javier
LEAD: The Los Angeles Dodgers finally found a way to get Juan Samuel and his high-risk glove out of center field yesterday.

Question Box
LEAD:
Talented First Basemen
Q.
Does the first baseman with the highest career batting average in major league history also have the highest career fielding average?
A.
No, and it probably will not happen in this century, but let's wait until Don Mattingly puts away his bat, glove, spikes and uniform for good.

LEAD: Despite repeated disappointments, many of the nation's top corporate executives say they think there is at least an even-money chance for a breakthrough in budget negotiations that begin on Tuesday in Washington, with a sizable number supporting such an agreement even if it includes an increase in personal income taxes.

LEAD: The show at the Palladium on Thursday night underscored the sort of cultural ricocheting that can take place in the Caribbean.
Azuquita, a Panamanian singer who has lived in New York and Paris, played a set of salsa, a Cuban and Puerto Rican music; Azuquita learned the music by listening to shows beamed on the radio from Cuba.

East German Fuel Sales
LEAD: East Germany's state-owned Minol oil company almost tripled gasoline sales in the first four months of 1990, reflecting a rise in car ownership in East Germany.
The head of Minol's retail division, Leonhard Kneler, told the state news agency last week that at least 100 new gasoline stations a year would be needed to meet demand from East German drivers and the greatly increased number of West German cars visiting the East.


Closing of Sepulcher Wasn't Israel's Doing
LEAD: To the Editor:


Graves Defaced in Haifa; Deranged Jew Questioned
LEAD: About 250 graves at two Jewish cemeteries here were defaced over the weekend with black spray-painted markings calling for the destruction of the Jews, the Israeli police reported today.


No Winnebago Payout
LEAD: The struggling Winnebago Industries has chosen not to declare a semiannual cash dividend on its stock, the first time it has omitted a dividend in five years.
The company's chairman, John K. Hanson, said the decision had been based on the current slump in the sales of motor homes, the company's main product.


Big Role Model, Barren Stage
LEAD: GOLF may be sport's ultimate test of self-reliance, and perhaps no golfer has ever relied on himself as doggedly as Calvin Peete.
A product of the streets of Detroit and the citrus groves of Florida who was one of 19 siblings, Peete never hit a golf ball until the age of 23.
He has never had a formal lesson.

Tote bags have become imaginative and popular, and we should take them shopping (except for obviously heavy burdens), as Europeans use their string bags.

Ortega Was Kept On Because of the Contras
LEAD: To the Editor:


Chemical Weapons: 2 Percent Shy
LEAD: President Bush proposes that the United States and the Soviet Union end production of chemical weapons and begin destroying their existing stocks.
That raises hopes for a multinational treaty to rid the globe of chemical weapons.
But those hopes may be premature because Mr.
Bush insists the U.S. must hold onto 2 percent of its weapons even after it signs a treaty.


Louis M. Weber, Lawyer, 85
LEAD: Louis M. Weber, a former counsel for the Skouras Theaters Corporation, died Saturday while visiting relatives in Vienna, Va.
He was 85 years old.

Chronicle
LEAD: WALLACE LOH was born in Chongquing, China, 45 years ago, went with his parents to Peru when he was 2 years old and came to the United States by himself when he was 15.
During the political activism of the 1960's, Mr.
Loh said, he was determined to become a lawyer.
But unable to gain acceptance into law school, he chose psychology and received a Ph.D.


Reviews/Music;   A Recitalist's Nostalgic Bent
LEAD: Both the pleasures and the problems of Pedro Firpo's piano playing were evident in the first work on his Saturday afternoon program at Weill Recital Hall.
The piece was Scarlatti's compact, outgoing Sonata in E (K. 380), and Mr.
Firpo gave it a bright, crisp harpsichordlike sound that kept its rhythms dancing.


Reporter's Notebook;   Pope Is Awed By the cheers Of Mexicans
LEAD: After 47 of them, papal voyages outside Italy would seem to hold few surprises.
Yet no one who travels with Pope John Paul II fails to be amazed by his sense of mission, not to mention his stamina as he approaches his 70th birthday next Friday.


Shellfish Is Tiny, but Problems It Could Cause Are Huge
LEAD: The zebra mussel, an aquatic invader from Europe, is rapidly advancing into New York State, threatening to become a major pest in the Hudson, Delaware and Susquehanna Rivers, marine biologists say.


Thornburgh Shuffles 2 Top Aides, Giving Loyalists Less Visible Jobs
LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh today reassigned two of his closest aides in response to criticism that he had isolated himself from top deputies.

Medical Emergencies for Addicts Are Said to Have Dropped by 20%
LEAD: Medical emergencies related to cocaine in the United States dropped 20 percent in the fourth quarter of 1989, the Secretary of Health and Human Services told state and local officials at a conference called by the Office of National Drug Control Policy.


Rhode Island Housing Bonds
LEAD: The Rhode Island Housing and Mortgage Corporation is tentatively offering $70 million in bonds that will be used to make low-cost home mortgages available with a maximum yield of 7.85 percent for an issue due 2022 through underwriters led by Goldman, Sachs &amp; Company.


Bridge
LEAD: Foreign invaders carried off most of the prize money on Sunday in Manhattan in the Cavendish Invitational Charity Pairs.
The winners, who collected more than $30,000, were Eliakim Shoufel of Israel and Piotr Gawrys of Poland.
Second place went to Jon Baldursson and Adalsteinn Jorgensen of Iceland.


Philips Ouster Tied to Loose Management
LEAD: The forced resignation of Cornelis J. van der Klugt, the chairman of Philips N.V., announced today as expected, represents a dramatic fall from grace for a man regarded as one of the statesmen of European business and a highly visible supporter of the economic integration of Europe.

Little Anger At Sex Case At St. John's

St.
John's University in Queens does not have dormitories or campus pets, and the only place music blares is the parking lot, from the cars of students going home or to their jobs.

Aid Officials in Zambia
LEAD: Experts from the International Monetary Fund and World Bank have arrived here to review Zambia's economic recovery plans.
Sources close to the Ministry of Finance said today that the two teams would help Zambia use an aid package of $450 million worked out by donors at a Paris meeting in April.
Faced with a $7.2 billion debt and a declining standard of living, Zambia was promised fresh aid at the Paris meeting after the approval of its 1990-94 economic recovery plan by the I.M.F.

They feel sure there will be a next year, but it may be different.

Symantec to Acquire Peter Norton
LEAD: The Symantec Corporation, a software company in Cupertino, Calif., said today that it had agreed to acquire Peter Norton Computing Inc. of Santa Monica, Calif. for Symantec common stock valued at about $70 million.


Sallie Mae Chief Takes A Post at Dartmouth
LEAD: Edward A. Fox, who built the Student Loan Marketing Association into a major financial enterprise, is leaving as its president and chief executive to become dean of the Amos Tuck School of Business at Dartmouth University.


Apple Says Xerox Claim Is Dismissed
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said the Xerox Corporation's one remaining claim in a copyright suit filed in December had been dismissed.
In March, a Federal judge dismissed five of six claims in the suit, which contended that the screen display of Apple's Macintosh had unlawfully used copyrighted technology developed by Xerox for its Star computer.

Bank Executive Stepping Down
LEAD: The chief financial officer of the Bank of New England Corporation, one of the few senior executives who remained with the bank after it reported huge losses last winter, said today that he will retire in July after 32 years with the bank.
The executive, David B. Payne, who is 54 years old, was named to the top financial post last year.

UNR Holdings' Offer Rejected
LEAD: UNR Holdings Inc., an investment group in Tulsa, Okla., disclosed today that it had offered to acquire UNR Industries for at least $5 a share in cash, a total of $229.4 million.
But the bid was quickly rejected by a trust that controls 64 percent of the shares of the Chicago-based metal products concern.


Malcolm A. Love; Educator, 86
LEAD: Malcolm A. Love, who was president of San Diego State College for 19 years and oversaw its growth into a university, died on Saturday at Hillside Hospital after a long illness.
He was 86 years old.

LEAD: The Market Place column in Business Day yesterday misstated the performance of United Technologies stock from Jan. 2 through May 11.


New Delta Service
LEAD: Delta Air Lines Inc. said it would begin hourly service between Los Angeles and San Francisco on June 1, offering a special one-way fare of $99 and double frequent-flier bonus miles.
Delta said it would also offer a special $199 one-way fare for travel between Los Angeles and New York, with double frequent-flier bonus miles from June 1 to July 31.

LEAD: President Bush has changed his stance on higher taxes in advance of his budget negotiations today with Congressional leaders. ''Read my lips'' has softened to ''no preconditions.'' The change is welcome.

Macintosh's Prices Cut for Schools
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. said it had cut prices on its Macintosh computers for schools.
The company would not elaborate on the amount of the discounts, which are to take effect on Tuesday, but schools already get reductions of as much as 40 percent from the list prices for the computers.
Apple will probably extend its price cuts to more than 60 percent, company sources said.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Insect Migration
Q. Why do some insects migrate?
A.
The migratory pattern in insects is not well understood in many cases, according to the Xerces Society in Portland, Ore., which is dedicated to the conservation of invertebrates (and is named after an extinct butterfly). ''In a few cases, interesting theories relate to climate, food availability and predation,'' said a spokeswoman, who asked that her name be withheld.

Motorola Chip
LEAD: Motorola Inc. introduced a specialized processing chip that the company said was optimized for a new class of multimedia computing applications that combine graphics and sound.
The 96002 is a floating-point mathematical co-processor that approaches supercomputer speeds on certain operations and will permit the development of desktop work stations that have full-motion video and stereo digital sound capabilities.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article in SportsMonday on the Baltimore Orioles' victory over the Oakland A's misstated the results of the weekend series between the teams.
The Orioles won two of the three games in the series, not all three.
The headline repeated the error.

4 Die in Navy Copter Crash
LEAD: A Navy helicopter crashed into the Atlantic Ocean off this resort a few miles south of Jacksonville today and all four people aboard were killed, the Navy said.
Divers found the bodies in the fuselage of the SH-2 Sea Sprite helicopter, said a spokesman at the Jacksonville Naval Air Station.
It was on its way from the Atlantic Underwater Test and Evaluation Center in the Bahamas to its home base at Willow Grove, Pa.

Calvin Black; Development Advocate, 61
LEAD: Calvin Black, an advocate of development and a leader of the ''Sagebrush Rebellion,'' which challenged the Federal Government over control of public land, died of cancer Friday at San Juan County Hospital in Blanding.
He was 61 years old.
Mr.
Black, former chairman of the League for the Advancement of States Equal Rights, was a Commissioner of San Juan County, Utah, since 1967, except for two years when he was a member of the Utah Legislature.

LEAD:
TENNIS
Gilbert Rallies to Defeat Pugh
Already missing the world's top four players -Ivan Lendl, Boris Becker, Stefan Edberg and Andre Agassi - the Italian Open men's championships in Rome almost lost its top-seeded player in the first round yesterday.
Brad Gilbert of the United States survived a disastrous first set and an eye problem, then benefited from a rain delay to survive against an American, Jim Pugh, 1-6, 6-4, 6-4, at the Foro Italico.

He was 73 years old.
Mr.
Davis retired in 1978 as president of Grey &amp; Davis Inc., an advertising agency in Manhattan.

Methane and Climate
LEAD: French and Soviet scientists studying the Vostok ice core in East Antarctica have fine-tuned the link between methane levels and climate shifts over the past 160,000 years.
They argue that fluctuations in carbon dioxide and methane concentrations were probably responsible for 50 percent of the cases of dramatic warming and cooling of the earth during the last two ice ages.

Peter R. Knauss, 52, A Political Scientist
LEAD: Peter R. Knauss, an expert on Africa who was an associate professor of political science at the University of Illinois at Chicago, died of AIDS on Sunday at St.
Francis Hospital in Evanston, Ill.
He was 52 years old and lived in Evanston.
Dr.
Knauss's area of expertise was African politics.
He joined the faculty in 1968; in 1988 he was promoted to associate professor.

HIGH CANCER RISKS FOR SOME AT MILLS
LEAD: Flour mill employees who have worked with grain pesticides for many years face a risk of cancer that can be nine times the risk faced by other workers in the grain industry, a new study has found.


Critic's Notebook;   Visual Beauty Is Transcendent In Two Films at Cannes Festival
LEAD: This year's Cannes International Film Festival has entered its pretty phase, with two outstandingly lovely-looking major selections.
Both ''Night Sun,'' which brings the visual style of the brothers Paolo and Vittorio Taviani to bear upon a story by Tolstoy, and ''Daddy Nostalgie,'' Bertrand Tavernier's loving look at the last days spent together by a daughter and her dying father, are elegant and supremely romantic visual achievements.


News Corp. Profit Plunges
LEAD: The News Corporation, Rupert Murdoch's media empire, reported today that net profit dropped 74 percent, to $93 million for the first nine months of the current fiscal year from $384.8 million in the period a year earlier.


Industrial Production Down 0.4%
LEAD: Industrial production fell in April for the first time since January, with a sharp drop in the output of motor vehicles and parts, the Federal Reserve Board reported today.


Harland C. Forbes Is Dead at 92; Ex-Chief Executive of Con Edison
LEAD: Harland Clement Forbes, a retired chief executive of the Consolidated Edison Company of New York, died of pneumonia yesterday at Memorial Hospital in Sarasota, Fla.
He was 92 years old and had lived in Sarasota since moving there from Manhasset, L.I., in 1965.


Hubble Telescope Able to Focus
LEAD: After three troubled weeks trying to steady a wiggling spacecraft and fix its sights on the heavens, ground controllers said yesterday that the Hubble Space Telescope was responding reliably to commands and was for the first time focusing on guide stars.
This apparently clears the way for the telescope to take its first picture on Sunday.

LEAD: The International Business Machines Corporation said yesterday that it would enhance its Callpath software, which links corporate phone systems with computer data bases, so that the software would work with many brands of phone systems, beginning next March.

LEAD: Sikh militants impersonating Government security troops shot and killed seven Hindus after luring them out of their homes in the northern state of Punjab, the police said today.
The killings occurred late Monday in Darrowali, 42 miles north of the Sikh holy city of Amritsar.

LEAD: A Federal district judge in Washington has ordered Price Waterhouse, one of the nation's largest accounting firms, to give a partnership to a woman who said she was denied the promotion in 1983 because of negative sexual stereotypes.

As the World Turns
LEAD:  May 11: The Yankees, in Seattle for a series against the Mariners, announce that Dave Winfield, their 38-year-old outfielder, has been traded to the California Angels for a pitcher, Mike Witt.
Winfield, citing a clause in baseball's basic labor agreement that says he can veto the trade, says he won't go.

LEAD: President Bush is sending three senior officials to India and Pakistan in an effort to ease tensions between the two countries over the disputed territory of Kashmir, the White House said today.

LEAD: The Vatican and Romania today re-established diplomatic relations that were broken by the former hard-line Communist Government 40 years ago.


K. C. Jones Is Named Coach of SuperSonics
LEAD: K. C. Jones, who played on eight Boston Celtics teams that won National Basketball Association championships and coached two others that captured titles, yesterday was named head coach of the Seattle SuperSonics.
Jones, 58 years old, succeeds Bernie Bickerstaff, who will become the team's vice president in charge of operations.

LEAD: KEVIN GREENE hates jokes about airline food.

A Portable 'Book' Player From Sony
LEAD: The Sony Corporation introduced a palm-sized electronic ''book'' player that stores 100,000 pages of text on a compact disk.
The ''Data Discman'' uses a read-only compact disk, or CD-ROM, to store information.
The data on the three-inch disk can be shown on a small liquid crystal display mounted on the 1.2-pound machine.


Fleet/Norstar
LEAD: The Fleet/Norstar Financial Group Inc. is offering $150 million in notes due in 1993 through underwriters led by Merrill Lynch Capital Markets.
The 9.95 percent three-year notes are priced at 100, to yield 135 basis points more than Treasuries with a similar maturity.
Noncallable by the company, the notes are rated Baa-1 by Moody's and A- by Standart &amp; Poor's.


John Jay's Chief to Accede To Some Student Demands
LEAD: Under pressure from students occupying a campus building, the president of John Jay College of Criminal Justice said yesterday that he would accede to some of their demands, including granting tenure to a popular Hispanic professor.

COMPANIES

They know that a one-act should never overstay the audience's interest.

LEAD: In a surprise vote five minutes before a midnight deadline, the New York City Board of Estimate unanimously agreed last night to issue a preliminary denial of Time Warner's applications to renew the two cable television franchises it controls in Manhattan.

Ketchum replaces LevLane Advertising, Bala-Cynwyd, Pa.
Lee Media will continue to do the media buying for the accounts, which have a broadcast budget of $6 million to $8 million.

Review/Music;   Amsterdam's Calm Reflection On the Baroque
LEAD: Perhaps the most authentic thing about Sunday afternoon's concert by the Amsterdam Baroque Orchestra was its pervasive calmness.
Conducted by Ton Koopman and offering a program largely familiar to friends of early-18th-century style, these 16 period-instrument players were able to couch both high energy and reflection in terms of quiet confidence.

LEAD: Chancellor Helmut Kohl's new interest in moving up German unification seems based largely on the perception that his election chances could be hurt if he waits too long.


Is Botswana a Model for Democracies in Africa?
LEAD: In the African context, an unusual event occurred in Botswana last October: national elections were held among eight competing political parties.
When some of the results were disputed, the judiciary, not the politicians, interceded.


Reviews/Theater;   3 Widows With Unseemly Behavior
LEAD: If you believe that one good reason for going to the theater is to escape television sitcoms, you may not be tickled to end up at ''The Cemetery Club,'' the new attraction at the Brooks Atkinson.
From its peppy canned theme music to its final-scene sermonizing, this comedy about three Jewish widows in Forest Hills, Queens, is ''Golden Girls'' at four times the length but with at most one-fourth the star wattage.

LEAD: The co-chairmen of the Knight Foundation Commission on Intercollegiate Athletics said today that the 22-member panel would likely press for more liberal allowances for recruits, the abolition of athletic dormitories and an end to off-season tournaments for prep basketball players.

LEAD: Faced with slack sales and competition against its most successful vehicles, the Chrysler Corporation will announce this week that it plans to offer a powerful two-seat sports car late next year.
The plans for the car, to be called the Dodge Viper, were confirmed by Chrysler managers today in response to a press report.

LEAD: Gerald Arpino has agreed that the Joffrey Ballet may perform ballets he choreographed during its Los Angeles season at the Dorothy Chandler Pavilion of the Music Center, the Joffrey's board of directors announced yesterday.


Fed Nominee Endorsed
LEAD: The nomination of Assistant Treasury Secretary David W. Mullins Jr. to a vacant seat on the seven-member Federal Reserve Board was endorsed today by the Senate Banking Committee.
The committee voted, 18 to 0, to forward the nomination to the full Senate, which is expected to approve it.
Mr.
Mullins, who is 44 years old, is an architect of President Bush's savings and loan industry bailout.

LEAD: Several obstacles remain before wireless telephone systems now in development can replace cellular and wired services.

LEAD: Rejecting complaints by Interior Secretary Manuel Lujan Jr., the White House says President Bush does not want to weaken the nation's primary law protecting endangered animals and plants.


Fighting Hate With Decency
LEAD: New Yorkers, their racial sensitivities already heightened, were quick to see the violent clash between black youths and Vietnamese men in Brooklyn early Sunday as an alarming example of bigotry run amok.
Too quick, it appears.
The police, retreating from earlier accounts, conclude that the melee, though brutal, did not begin as a racially motivated assault.

LEAD: The Air Force said today that it had suspended a missile research and development unit of the Hughes Aircraft Company from receiving new contracts and might bar it for three years for its role in a scandal involving stolen budget documents.

LEAD: The Philippine Government formally told the United States today that the 1947 agreement allowing American military bases here would not be extended when it expires in September 1991.

Peter C. Stocker, 47, California Developer
LEAD: Peter C. Stocker, a Northern California real estate developer, was killed Saturday in a helicopter crash in Monterey County, Calif.
He was 47 years old and lived in Sausalito, Calif.


Mr. Bush, the Wagon's Leaving
LEAD: During the march from Selma to Montgomery, the Rev.
Martin Luther King Jr. quoted an old Georgia preacher as saying, ''Them that's going, git on the wagon.
Them that ain't, git out of the way.'' Those words from 1965 send a powerful message to President Bush today.


Evolution in Europe;   Anti-Independence Crowds Storm Parliaments in Estonia and Latvia
LEAD: Crowds of anti-independence protesters stormed the Parliament buildings in Latvia and neighboring Estonia today in the largest display of physical force since the Baltic republics began their formal withdrawal from the Soviet Union.


People
LEAD: *
W.
Dillaway Ayres Jr. has joined the investment banking firm of Veronis, Suhler &amp; Associates Inc. as senior vice president concentrating on the broadcasting field.


Equivalency Degrees Down
LEAD: The number of dropouts who receive high school equivalency degrees has significantly declined, the American Council on Education said today.


Fair Play for College Athletes
LEAD: In the recent National Football League draft of college players, 18 were juniors taking advantage of the pros' new openness to underclassmen.
But 20 other juniors went unchosen.
They ended up without contracts and, thanks to an antiquated notion of amateurism, without the option to resume their collegiate playing careers.


Walter Thornton, Agent for Models, Dies of Stroke at 88
LEAD: Walter Thornton, retired head of the Walter Thornton Agency in Manhattan, once one of the nation's largest modeling agencies, died of a stroke on Monday at the Veterans Administration Medical Center in Long Beach, Calif.
He was 88 years old and lived in Jalisco, Mexico.


Plea for Peace at Irish Prelate's Burial
LEAD: Tomas Cardinal O Fiaich, Roman Catholic Primate of All Ireland, was buried today after a Requiem Mass at St.
Patrick's Cathedral in Armagh, Northern Ireland, with a call by the senior Bishop of that province for an end to violence between its Protestants and Catholics.


Accounts
LEAD: *
Guinness Import Company, to Mathieu, Goluskin, Donovan &amp; Clarke, for its Moosehead brand beer, for a summer promotional campaign with a budget of $3 million.


Dent Is Silent but Players Rush to Winfield's Defense
LEAD: On a night when Don Mattingly hit his 100th home run at Yankee Stadium and the Yankees swept to a decisive 7-3 victory over the Minnesota Twins, the main questions for Manager Bucky Dent after the game had to do with the man who was not there, Dave Winfield, and the one whose own days might be numbered, himself.


In Pennsylvania, Abortion Foes Triumph in Democratic Primary
LEAD: Gov.
Robert P. Casey of Pennsylvania, an anti-abortion Democrat, today swept past a primary challenger who favors abortion rights to capture the nomination for a second term.


Eating Well
LEAD: FOR food fanatics, spring's warmer weather, longer days, cherry blossoms and azaleas are much less important than tender young spinach leaves, slender stalks of rhubarb, strawberries that are red from top to bottom and asparagus at reasonable prices.


For Bush, Christmas All Year
LEAD: In his first year in office, President Bush received 83 caps, 66 golf balls, 51 neckties, 36 shirts, 25 books about the Constitution, 13 pairs of cowboy boots, 9 Mickey and Minnie Mouse dolls, 6 fishing rods, 3 tins of caviar and 2 ''We the People'' cufflinks.
The Gorbachevs gave him a box of Christmas tree ornaments.


At the Nation's Table
LEAD: JUST as thin-crusted pizzas were a hot snack of the '80s, satays - the grilled meat, fish or vegetables so common in Asia - may be a snack of the '90s.
At least Rick and Ann Yoder, owners of the Wild Ginger, an Asian restaurant that opened here last July, hope so.


History Bleached at State
LEAD: It's hardly a secret that the Central Intelligence Agency helped arrange the 1953 coup in Iran that restored the Shah to his Peacock Throne.
When the deed was done, His Imperial Majesty offered this toast to Kermit Roosevelt, then head of the C.I.A.'s Middle East operations: ''I owe my throne to God, my people, my army - and to you!


Racist Theories Compromise Teaching Ability;   Freedom to Poison
LEAD: To the Editor:


BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Air and Water Technologies Corp., Branchburg, N.J., an environmental treatment and services company, said Compagnie Generale des Eaux, France, would purchase $100 million of Air and Water Class A common stock in a private placement.


Market Place;   The Bitter Fight For Kollmorgen
LEAD: THE struggle for control of the Kollmorgen Corporation, which has been going on for more than a year, may come to a conclusion next week as shareholders decide whether to keep current management or vote in directors from the Vernitron Corporation, a rival maker of electric motors.
It is a fight that all sides may wish had never begun.


Steroid Test Positive
LEAD: A Soviet athlete who finished second in the women's division of the Los Angeles Marathon on March 4, has tested positive for steroid use and will be suspended from competition in the United States for two years, The Athletics Congress announced yesterday.


Fighter Wins 3 Times
LEAD: It's not every fighter who can win a single boxing match three times, but then not every boxer calls himself the Magician.
Dennis Milton does, however, and yesterday, he achieved his third victory in a middleweight bout against Michael (the Silk) Olajide in Albany last Dec. 1.


Insiders of the Outer
LEAD: Plans are afoot for building another beltway around Washington.
It would lie outside the present beltway, so, naturally, it is already being called ''the outer beltway.''


Trusthouse-Bass
LEAD: Trusthouse Forte P.L.C. said it had bought the Crest hotel chain in Britain from Bass P.L.C. for $:300 million, or more than $501 million, in cash.
Trusthouse said the deal involved 43 hotels in Britain.
Profits of the assets being acquired were $:29.9 million in the year that ended on Sept. 30, 1989.


Faster Deportation for Crimes to Be Proposed
LEAD: The Bush Administration will offer legislation on Wednesday to expand the power of the Immigration and Naturalization Service to deport people convicted of crimes, Administration officials said today.


A Correction: Hudson Building Ban
LEAD: A map accompanying an article yesterday about plans for the Hudson River waterfront incorrectly located the areas where real estate development would be banned.


Corrections
LEAD: The Outdoors column in Sports Pages on Friday, about fly fishing in the Catskills, misidentified a family of fly tiers who own a fly shop in Roscoe, N.Y.
They are Walt, Winnie and Mary Dette.


Foreign Passports Tell of a Desperate Hong Kong
LEAD: The term ''pregnancy leave'' is taking on a new meaning here, as shown by a successful Hong Kong Chinese banker who is negotiating an unusual sweetener before he takes a new job.
He wants his employer to pay to send his pregnant wife to Canada to give birth, insuring that their child will be born a


W. B. Mullins, 52, A Founding Official Of the Peace Corps
LEAD: William B. Mullins, a former Peace Corps official who became a foundation executive, died of lung cancer yesterday at his home in Pittsburgh.
He was 52 years old.


STRIKES TESTING CHAMORRO'S RULE
LEAD: Striking civil servants loyal to the opposition Sandinista Front ignored a Government ultimatum ordering them to return to work by 9 A.M. today, confronting the new and impoverished Government of President Violeta Barrios de Chamorro with its first serious political crisis.


Time Unit Closing Magazine
LEAD: Southpoint, a regional general interest magazine, will cease publication with its June issue.


Nintendo Research
LEAD: Nintendo of America Inc. said its parent company in Japan would establish a $3 million fund at the Massachusetts Institute of Technology's Media Laboratory for research into how children learn while they play.
The world's leading maker of video games said the Nintendo Fund would support the work of Seymour Papert, who maintains that traditional teaching methods have become increasingly out of touch with children.


From Citibank, Millions for Schools
LEAD: Citibank announced yesterday that it would spend $20 million over the next 10 years to improve urban schools in a variety of ways, including the development of new approaches to teaching and the promotion of technology in the classroom.


From Texas Rodeo to Winner's Circle
LEAD: After Unbridled worked five furlongs in a nifty 1:00 2/5 seconds yesterday morning at Churchill Downs, Carl Nafzger, the colt's trainer, had some discouraging words for the other horses that will be running in the Preakness Stakes at Pimlico on Saturday.


DIALOGUE: How to Shrink the Deficit;   The Budget Summit: Cut Spending, Raise Taxes
LEAD: The President and leaders of Congress have a splendid opportunity this week to enhance their political popularity.
If they can agree on a credible plan for eliminating the Federal deficit over the next several years, they can strengthen the economy, restore faith in the democratic process and prove cynics wrong.


AIDS Care Deterred
LEAD: To the Editor:


Citicorp Paper Is Down Again
LEAD: Interest rates declined yesterday for the second consecutive week at Citicorp's regular auction of 91-day and 182-day commercial paper.


DIALOGUE: How to Shrink the Deficit;   The Budget Summit: Don't Raise Taxes
LEAD: The brazen cry to raise taxes in 1990 has to be the most shameless assault on Americans' pocketbooks in this century.


Perkin Unit To Remain U.S. Owned
LEAD: In a long-awaited agreement that will keep a vital semiconductor technology under United States ownership, a California company said yesterday that it would acquire a division of the Perkin-Elmer Corporation that makes the sophisticated machines needed to develop the world's most-advanced computer chips.


Losses Widen for T.W.A.
LEAD: Trans World Airlines Inc. said its loss widened to $143 million in the first quarter because of a sharp rise in fuel costs and other operating expenses.


Dow Rises Slightly, to a High of 2,822.45
LEAD: The Dow Jones industrial average seesawed throughout the session yesterday, ending with a small gain and breaking through to another high at 2,822.45.


Chrysler Plans Plant Spending
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation said it planned to spend $190 million on new manufacturing equipment and expansions at plants in Indiana.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   People
LEAD: *
Bernard R. Cammarata has joined Lowe Marschalk as senior vice president and management supervisor.

Jim Henson, Puppeteer, Dies; The Muppets' Creator Was 53
LEAD: Jim Henson, the puppeteer whose Kermit the Frog and other Muppet creatures became the playmates and teachers of millions of youngsters who grew up watching ''Sesame Street'' on television, died early yesterday at New York Hospital.
He was 53 years old.

Killers Are Put to Death in Texas and Missouri
LEAD: A man convicted of killing four people was executed early today in Missouri, while a death-row inmate in Texas who lost a last-minute appeal to the Supreme Court was put to death for slaying his brother-in-law.

LEAD: The renewed appearance of the spurious flag-burning issue before the Supreme Court puts an uncomfortable squeeze on those Americans who want to preserve the Bill of Rights as the guarantor of their liberty.

LEAD: Inflation data that were slightly better than expected failed to generate much enthusiasm in the credit markets yesterday, as prices of most Treasury securities moved lower.

New Futures Contract On Insurance Planned
LEAD: The Chicago Board of Trade said today that it would seek Federal approval to begin trading futures contracts related to health insurance and automobile insurance.
The contract would give insurance companies a mechanism to lock in the price they must pay for reinsurance, which involves spreading their risk by selling policies among other insurers.


Landmark Sets Real Estate Sale
LEAD: The Landmark Land Company said today that it had revised its deal to sell real estate holdings to a California developer after the Government objected to the original proposal.


Want to Buy? The Numbers to Call
LEAD: Setting up the largest real estate company in the world and the largest financial institution in the United States has not been a smooth process for the officials of the Resolution Trust Corporation, which is flooded with hundreds of calls a day from investors seeking information.


Outdoors;   How Hunting Dogs Retrieve Skills
LEAD: rrA club for those interested in honing and preserving the hunting abilities of retrieving dogs is being formed in the New York metropolitan area.
The organization will be affiliated with the North American Hunting Retriever Association, a nonprofit corporation that was formed several years ago by a small band of hunters and dog handlers.


Investor Joins Citibank In Private Bank Group
LEAD: A longtime investor in stocks and bonds, James R. Hocking, has joined Citibank's private banking group.
Mr.
Hocking came to Citibank this week from Templeton International, an investment advisory firm in Fort Lauderdale, Fla.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Mirabella Editor Named
LEAD: Gay Bryant has been named the first editor in chief of the the Murdoch Magazines' publication Mirabella.
Like Julie Lewit-Nirenberg, Mirabella's publisher, Ms.
Bryant will report to Grace Mirabella, the magazine's publication director.
Karen Walden will replace Ms.
Bryant as editor in chief of New Woman magazine.

American Stores' Merger Settlement
LEAD: The American Stores Company, California's largest supermarket chain, said it had agreed to sell most of its Alpha Beta stores to settle a state lawsuit challenging its $2.5 billion takeover of Lucky Stores on antitrust grounds.
The decision follows a United States Supreme Court ruling last month that allowed California to sue the company to overturn the 1988 merger.

LEAD: Gov.
Rafael Hernandez Colon of Puerto Rico accused President Bush today of applying ''heavy-handed political pressure'' to persuade Puerto Ricans to support statehood.


Jobless to Soar in a Free-Market East, C.I.A. Says
LEAD: The Central Intelligence Agency said today that it foresaw soaring unemployment in Eastern Europe as countries there broke up state monopolies and adopted free-market economic principles.


Chip Sales Projections
LEAD: Worldwide chip sales will remain flat in 1990 but will then experience annual growth of at least 10 percent until 1993, a trade group reported today.


TV Project Is Set Up In Europe
LEAD: Thomson S.A., the French electronics group, and Philips N.V., the Dutch electronics company, have agreed to work together in a $3.6 billion effort to develop a European system of high-definition television.


BUSH PRESSES CASE FOR MANAGUA AID
LEAD: Trying to force Congress's hand on aid to Panama and Nicaragua, President Bush said today that delayed action on a relief package compelled him to reject an emergency loan to Nicaragua.
He demanded that lawmakers approve the aid before taking a Memorial Day holiday next week.

Keith Blinn, 72, Dies; Lawyer and Professor

He was 72 years old and lived in Irvine and Coronado, Calif.

LEAD: Scrutiny of a 260-million-year-old skull has convinced scientists at the University of Toronto that a reptile about the size of a modern cat was probably a great-granduncle of the human race.

Playboy to Clothe Nude
LEAD: Playboy Enterprises Inc., whose stock certificates have been graced with the nude image of the February 1971 Playmate since the company went public in 1971, said this week that it would replace the nude figure with a clothed one in a recapitalization plan announced last week.
A spokeswoman, Terri Tomcisin, said Playboy has 14,000 single-share stockholders, many of whom bought the one share just to get the racy certificate.


INSIDE
LEAD:
Bush Pushes for Latin Aid
The President said Congress's delay in voting an aid package had forced him to reject a loan to Nicaragua.
He also continued to resist Democrats' urgings that he address the nation on the budget.
Pages A14 and A15.
Strike Ends in Managua
Nicaragua's new President, Violeta Barrios de Chamorro, settled a strike that had paralyzed virtually all Government services.

HOME IMPROVEMENT
LEAD: IF your house or apartment was built before World War II, chances are that its windows are equipped with counterweights, hidden inside cavities on either side.

LEAD: Many psychiatrists say they are seeing fewer patients and drawing less satisfaction from their work than ever before.
Some are leaving the profession or moving to areas where the competition for patients is less fierce.
And the number of newcomers to the profession is dwindling.

Sammy Davis Jr. Dies at 64; Top Showman Broke Barriers
LEAD: Sammy Davis Jr., a versatile and dynamic singer, dancer and actor who overcame extraordinary obstacles to become a leading American entertainer, died of throat cancer yesterday at his home in Los Angeles.
He was 64 years old and had been in deteriorating health since his release from Cedar-Sinai Medical Center on March 13.

Inmate Attempted Suicide
LEAD: A high school teacher's 17-year-old boyfriend, charged with torturing the woman's small children, tried to kill himself at Rikers Island last weekend, a New York City Correction Department spokeswoman said yesterday.
The youth, Porfirio Borges, was found hanging from a sheet in his cell on Saturday, said the spokeswoman, Ruby Ryles.


A Star, a Survivor
LEAD: A middle-aged man, on hearing recently that Sammy Davis Jr. was near death, remarked, ''I can't imagine a world without Sammy Davis in it.'' Many other Americans, even if they were no particular fans of the entertainer, probably feel the same way, and for humane as well as theatrical reasons.


THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Fallon a Big Winner
LEAD: Fallon McElligott took top honors at the Art Directors Club annual Gold and Silver Awards show Tuesday.
The agency won 13 awards for clients like Hush Puppies, Jim Beam, Porsche and Rolling Stone magazine, which also won big on the editorial side.
Its art director, Fred Woodward, won 17 awards.
BBDO led the television category with six awards.

Bridge
LEAD: Four strong squads battled down to the wire in the Cavendish Team Championship Tuesday night, and victory went to Paul Marston, Steve Burgess, both of Australia, Ed Manfield of Hyattsville, Md., and Kit Woolsey of Kensington, Calif.

LEAD: Walid Howrani, a pianist born in New York, raised in Beirut and trained in Moscow, showed no lack of ambition in his program at Weill Recital Hall on Saturday evening.

Growth Seen in Ireland
LEAD: Ireland's economy seems ready to grow much more quickly in the next 10 years, helped by lower inflation and a decline in emigration, a leading independent study group said today.
The country's 3.5 million people could look forward to an annual economic growth rate of 4 percent throughout the 1990's compared with an average 1.5 percent in the 1980's, the Economic and Social Research Institute said in its latest report.


Strike Ended in Nicaragua; Chamorro Gives Big Raises
LEAD: Government negotiators and striking union leaders announced agreement late tonight on a package of salary increases, job guarantees and other measures to end a weeklong strike by Sandinista-led civil servants that had brought the country's newly elected Government to a virtual standstill.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Peeling Paint
Q.
On three ceilings - a bedroom, the living room and dining room - there is a spot that peels about two years after it is painted.
I have noticed no signs of moisture and there is no staining on these ceilings.
The rest of the ceiling in each case is O.K.
Could these be hot spots, and what can I do to prevent them?

Do Re Mi Fa Sol La Ti Boom
LEAD: THE $500 Yamaha piano keyboard I have been playing can produce 5,050 different types of sounds with its 61 keys.
It can imitate a harpsichord, a guitar, a trumpet, a violin - even a mandolin or a sitar.
It can also mimic a racing car, bird calls, ambulance sirens, waves breaking on the sand and glass breaking on land; and it can shout ''Yeah!

Libya Reports Oil Cut
LEAD: Libya said on Tuesday that it had cut oil output by 100,000 barrels a day, more than the amount requested under this month's OPEC accord.
Delegates of the Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries wanted a reduction of 77,000 barrels a day by Libya in their agreement for total cuts of 1.445 million barrels daily to bring output down to around 22 million barrels.

Large Soviet Crop Seen
LEAD: Weather conditions are favorable for a bumper grain crop in the Soviet Union this year, the Agriculture Department said last week.
It put the 1990 Soviet crop at 215 million metric tons, up from 211.1 million last year.
It would be the largest Soviet harvest since a record 237.4 million tons in 1978.

Money Fund Assets Off
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 507 money market mutual funds decreased by $1.78 billion, to $381.71 billion, for the week that ended Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 160 institutional funds increased by $270.10 million, to $91.75 billion.
The assets of the 245 general-purpose funds were down $640.30 million, to $131.53 billion.

Sinatra Reschedules
LEAD: The four Frank Sinatra concerts at Radio City Music Hall that were postponed because of Sammy Davis Jr.'s death have been rescheduled.
Tickets from May 16 will be honored on June 17, tickets from May 17 will be honored June 14, tickets from May 18 will be honored June 15, and those from May 19 will be honored June 16.


Cafe Scene by Renoir Is Sold for $78.1 Million
LEAD: Pierre Auguste Renoir's sun-dappled cafe scene ''At the Moulin de la Galette,'' from 1876, was sold last night for $78.1 million at Sotheby's, setting a record at auction for Impressionist art.
The price was the second highest for any artwork sold at auction.


Canada Trade Surplus
LEAD: Canada's trade surplus soared in March, powered largely by a strong United States economy that consumed more Canadian goods than in February, the Government said today.
The surplus swelled to $471 million (Canadian), or $402 million (United States), from a revised February surplus of $53 million (Canadian), or $45 million (United States).

LEAD: A Federal appeals court in New York issued an injunction yesterday preventing the Reuters news service from withdrawing from a photo-exchange agreement with United Press International.

LEAD: In a move that could lead to the restoration of one of Wall Street's most famous names, Shearson Lehman Hutton Inc. is examining a plan to reorganize its four operational units into two divisions, Wall Street executives said yesterday.

The air is heavy with smog, as it often is on a hot, still summer day.
The colors of the landscape are the muted grays of the tombstones in the vast cemetery below.

LEAD: Alcan Aluminium Ltd. is offering $150 million in 9.40 percent notes due in 1995 at a price of par through underwriters led by the First Boston Corporation.

It was on the high end of what most dealers had expected the range to be, about 75 to 80 basis points over Treasuries.


Review/Pop;   Taylor Dayne At the Beacon
LEAD: What a trouper Taylor Dayne is!
It was impossible to watch her concert on Tuesday night at the Beacon Theater without thinking about the woman-hours behind the show, from grooming and fashion to music rehearsals to the practiced dances and hand gestures for every instant onstage.
The result is 1990's pop as lab experiment, calculated to a fare-thee-well, strenuous and almost completely uninvolving.

Casper J. Schoener, Reporter, 74
LEAD: Casper J. Schoener, a reporter for the Associated Press for more than 40 years who was better known by his nickname, Joe Schroeder, when he covered City Hall from 1966 to 1981, died of complications from anemia on Wednesday at the Medical Center of Ocean County in Point Pleasant, N.J.
He was 74 years old and lived in Lakewood, N


Japan Trade Surplus Falls
LEAD: The narrowing of Japan's trade surplus, interrupted in March after an 11-month decline, resumed in April, the Finance Ministry announced today.


27,000 Phone Lines Cut Off in Stamford By a Broken Switch
LEAD: The failure of a large central office telephone switch in Stamford, Conn., cut off all but emergency service to a quarter of Stamford's telephone lines for nearly 20 hours yesterday.


Chronicle
LEAD: An official in the Environmental Protection Agency and an outspoken critic of Federal environmental policy, HUGH B. KAUFMAN, has been elected, as a write-in candidate, to the Town Council of Nora, Neb. (pop. 28) He has been working with grass-roots groups in Nebraska that are fighting a proposed low-level nuclear waste plant.

LEAD: The Kroger Company, the nation's second-largest supermarket chain, yesterday named as its next chief executive Joseph A. Pichler, a former business school dean who joined the company in 1986 and helped it through a successful recapitalization.

LEAD: S. Parker Gilbert, who led Morgan Stanley &amp; Company through the greatest period of growth in the firm's history, said yesterday that he would retire as chairman by the end of the year.


Review/Film;   Four Eyes of Blue and an Old Love Rediscovered
LEAD: Think of ''Bird on a Wire'' as ''The Mel and Goldie Movie'' and you'll be much less disappointed than if you walk in expecting the romance-action-comedy it claims to be.
Just a glance at the print ads and subway posters reveals all you need to know about this Mel Gibson-Goldie Hawn film.
Four of the widest, bluest eyes in Hollywood (apparent even in black-and-white photos) stare straight into the camera.

LEAD: The signs of overnight success at Cannes are unmistakable.
Bleary eyes, a hoarse voice and a dazed but happy expression: all these are clear indications that a heretofore undiscovered talent has just been thrust into the international limelight.


G.M. Will Close Factory in Atlanta
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation will shut its Lakewood assembly plant in Atlanta on Aug. 6 and lay off 2,200 workers.
A G.M. spokeswoman, Sharon Hines, said the auto maker would stop making 1990 versions of the Chevrolet Caprice at Lakewood.
Production of the 1991 Caprice began in March in Willow Run,

LEAD: The May Department Stores Company said yesterday that its first-quarter earnings rose 27 percent, while Gap Inc., the specialty apparel retailer, reported its income rose 40.3 percent during the period.

LEAD: The Brooklyn teacher who led his high school class into a Korean-owned grocery store to protest a boycott there requested a transfer from his school yesterday, saying his life and the lives of his family have been threatened.

LEAD: Payne Stewart's swing screams talent, but blaring knickers have gotten him more attention than his golf game.

Broadcasts for China Delayed
LEAD: An organizer of the Goddess of Democracy radio ship indicated today that the project to beam pro-democracy messages to China would be postponed indefinitely.

LEAD: It is late in the Italian first-division season.
Internazionale of Milan, the defending champion, has just beaten the shellshocked goalie for Atalanta for the seventh time in the match.
With the outcome long decided, Milan's coach, Giovanni Trapattoni, sends a rookie out to play and yells to Lothar Matthaus to move from his habitual spot at midfield to the right wing.

LEAD: A 19-year-old white man was acquitted yesterday of killing a 16-year-old black youth who crossed one of the invisible barriers that separate white from black New York when he went to the Bensonhurst section of Brooklyn last Aug. 23.


Mortgage Rates Drop
LEAD: Fixed-rate home mortgages averaged 10.37 percent this week, down from 10.54 percent the previous week, according to a national survey released today by the Federal Home Loan Mortgage Corporation.
On one-year adjustable-rate mortgages, lenders were asking an average initial rate of 8.56 percent this week, down from 8.63 percent.

She was 54 years old.

LEAD:
Pan Am Shuttle for Sale


Protecting Young Eyes
LEAD: Your eyes are protected by sunglasses.
Should your children be wearing them too?
Ophthalmologists say children's eyes need as much or more protection from the sun as adults.
The lenses of children's eyes are clearer and so can absorb more ultraviolet light.
Early exposure to sunlight may lead to retinal damage as well as the development of cataracts later in life.

Platinum Continues to Soar As Supplies Are Threatened
LEAD: Platinum futures prices surged above $500 an ounce yesterday for the first time in two months, amid fear about supplies spurred by racial violence in South Africa and a reported drop in sales of the precious metal by the Soviet Union.


Budget-Deficit Law Is Facing Change
LEAD: One point on which the budget negotiators from the White House and Congress seem headed for agreement is that the Gramm-Rudman-Hollings budget-balancing law will have to be changed.
The $64 billion deficit limit set by the law for the next fiscal year simply cannot be reached, and the across-the-board spending cuts that it requires if that target is missed would be politically, economically and socially devastating.


Phase Out the Philippine Bases
LEAD: If the Philippines truly doesn't want the United States to keep its bases there, the thing to do is simple: Leave.
Maintaining a good relationship and avoiding rancor is more important to American security than holding on to the bases.
But there's a better answer: Leave gradually.

Manure Taints Village's Water
LEAD: Residents have been told to boil their water after a farm tractor accidentally dumped a load of liquid manure into a spring that supplies water to the village, officials said.
The contamination, which was reported Thursday, affected about 350 homes in the Chautauqua County village.
Mayor Homer Bowker said the town was considering legal action against the tractor driver, whose name was not released.

Bridge
LEAD: France and the United States have frequently battled in world championships, and there have also been some semiofficial encounters.
Sixty years ago in Paris a Culbertson foursome played a French team using plafond scoring, a method that preceded contract.
The match was agreed a draw almost at the end, when the scores were almost even and a dispute could not be resolved.

Blockbuster Sees 10% Market Share
LEAD: The Blockbuster Entertainment Corporation, owner of the nation's largest videocassette rental chain, expects to increase its share of the video rental market to 10 percent this year from its current 6 percent to 7 percent share.
The company said at its annual meeting on Wednesday that it planned promotions to sustain its growth, including an eight-week $10 million contest.


U.S. Wins in Reservoir Fight
LEAD: A three-judge Federal appeals panel has upheld the power of the Army Corps of Engineers to regulate the water flow from a 232-mile-long Missouri River reservoir that has been the subject of a bitter interstate dispute.

Called Hydrobelt, it features a balloon-like tube that straps across the body and can be inflated instantly by a carbon dioxide canister.

LEAD: A top painters' union official was arrested in Manhattan on racketeering charges yesterday, one day after his predecessor was killed in what prosecutors called a mob hit.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Guidepost;   T-Bills, Notes and Bonds
LEAD: People looking for a fixed-income investment, perhaps to park a tax refund, can find safety and certain tax advantages in Treasury securities.
There is no risk of default, which is why they pay less interest than other debt securities, and if they are held to maturity there is no need to worry about price fluctuations.


Dinkins Slow to Hire Them, Democrats Say
LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins cut his political teeth in Harlem clubhouses and was a Democratic district leader for many years.
But since he took office on Jan. 1, the Mayor has given party organizations and clubs, even those that supported him, little of the classic currency of politics - jobs.


CONSUMER'S WORLD: Coping;   With Car Stereos
LEAD: Installing stereo gear in an automobile can seem simple, particularly if all you want to do is put in a radio-cassette unit and a pair of speakers.
But it is not, especially if the car has no spaces for the units.

Review/Music;   Exploring Brahms's Dual Nature
LEAD: Brahms seemed to house within one soul the severe parent and the daydreaming child.
The disciplinarian inveighs against the wandering imagination in his music - or is it the other way around?


Dow Is Off 11.80 but Gains 18.33 for Week
LEAD: Stocks ran out of steam yesterday, with the Dow Jones industrial average slipping back 11.80 points, to 2,819.91, after eking out three new highs this week.
The blue-chip barometer gained 18.33 points for the week.

Chinese Aide May Seek U.S. Refuge
LEAD: A senior Chinese official who disagreed with the military crackdown on pro-democracy demonstrators last spring has quietly arrived in the United States, apparently seeking refuge, American officials said yesterday.


RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
HORSE RACING
Charon Wins Black-Eyed Susan
Charon, who suffered her first career defeat last time out, atoned for that loss with an overwhelming 7 1/4-length victory yesterday in the $250,000 Black-Eyed Susan Stakes at Pimlico.
The 3-year-old daughter of Mo Exception and Double Wiggle circled the leaders on the stretch turn and then drew away through the stretch, completing the mile and an eighth in a very quick 1:48 2/5 under Craig Perret.

LEAD: For Doug Risebrough, a former center accustomed to skating forward and backward during 14 seasons as a player in the National Hockey League, yesterday's move within the Calgary Flames' organization was nothing special.

Evolution in Europe;   Germanys Sign Pact Binding Economies
LEAD: East and West Germany's Finance Ministers signed a state treaty today to merge their economies and make the West German mark the sole legal tender in both nations by July 2, in what Chancellor Helmut Kohl of West Germany called ''a first decisive step on the path to unity.''

He was 77 years old and lived in Norman.

Your Money;   Being Too Busy Can Prove Costly
LEAD: Many business and professional people pursue their work so single-mindedly that they have no time to deal with personal finances.
Soon they have the financial equivalent of a neglected garden in fertile soil; weeds - or debts - threaten to take over.
Two-income couples are particularly vulnerable.


Oriole Singles Tie a Record
LEAD: The Baltimore Orioles tied an American League record in the first inning tonight when they hit eight consecutive singles against Bobby Witt of the Texas Rangers.
The Orioles won the game, 13-1.
Baltimore scored seven runs in the inning despite not hitting the ball hard against Witt, who pitched the entire inning, throwing 44 pitches.

Felonies Increase in Subways
LEAD: The New York City Transit Authority said yesterday that the number of felonies committed in the subway system in March had increased by 8.8 percent over last year's level, to 1,454 crimes compared with 1,336 crimes in 1989.
The rise in felonies is mainly due to an 11.5 percent increase in robberies, officials said.

And so it was not farfetched to surmise that they were instead offered as a goodbye.

Dr.
Samuel L. Taylor, a Brooklyn minister who served Presbyterian and Reformed Church congregations for more than two decades, died of cancer on Wednesday at his home in Brooklyn.

Patents: A New Toy And Sailboat At Exhibition;   A Lotion to Ease Pain
LEAD: A Las Vegas chemist, David Roberts, was promoting Stopp, a lotion that he said relieved soreness caused by everything from bumps and bruises to lower back pain and arthritis. ''I go way beyond soothing,'' said Mr.
Roberts, who sells a four-ounce container for $5 through the mail.
He first patented the compound as a hair thickener in 1972 and later discovered that it relieved pain as well.

A holdup yesterday at a convenience store in Greenwich, Conn., under surveillance in an inquiry into a series of robberies, set off a high-speed chase on Interstate 95 that ended when the suspects' car struck a bus shelter on Edison Avenue in the Bronx.
A person in the shelter reportedly suffered a severed leg.

Marlene Hess, a Banking Executive, Is Married to James Zirin, a Lawyer
LEAD: Marlene Hess, a daughter of Mr. and Mrs.
Leon Hess of New York, was married yesterday at her parents' home to James David Zirin, the son of Mr. and Mrs.
Morris G. Zirin of Palm Beach, Fla.
Rabbi Richard S. Chapin performed the ceremony.


HOUSE FOR THE HOMELESS PROVOKES DISPUTE
LEAD: Donna Russell says God led her to open her lakefront house to homeless families, but her neighbors say she is breaking the law.


Texan Hunkers Down After Stumbling on Tongue
LEAD: Just two months ago, Clayton Williams charged out of political obscurity to become the Republican candidate for governor of Texas by winning a landslide primary victory, but these days he is not riding quite so tall in the saddle.

CHRONICLE
LEAD: It was just a routine day yesterday for POPE JOHN PAUL II, who held his usual audiences with visitors to the Vatican and made his usual speeches.
But world leaders stopped to salute him on his 70th birthday, hailing the Polish-born Pope as an inspiration behind the changes in Eastern Europe in the last year.


Man Is Killed on a Subway Train While Trying to Thwart a Robbery
LEAD: A 53-year-old Harlem factory worker saw a fellow passenger being robbed at gunpoint on the J train yesterday morning and came to his aid, saying ''leave that man alone.'' The gunman shot the worker dead.


Auctions' Big Spenders: The Japanese
LEAD: Japanese art buyers dominated the bidding for Impressionist and modern paintings this week at Christie's and Sotheby's auction houses in New York.
The sales were high points of the spring auctions in New York.


U.S. TO EXPAND USE OF AIDS MEDICINES
LEAD: In a move that has been eagerly awaited by advocates for people with AIDS, the Department of Health and Human Services said yesterday that it would formally outline a proposal to make experimental drugs available to people with AIDS who have exhausted conventional treatments.


Cause of Forest Fire Found
LEAD: A local prosecutor said today that a forest fire that left scores of people homeless here last week had been traced to the burning of rubbish by a homeowner, but that the authorities would not press charges against the man.
The Crawford County Prosecutor, John Huss, said he believed that a fire set by the homeowner on March 16 smoldered underground for two months before rekindling.


Interco Plans Revamping
LEAD: Interco Inc. has asked its shareholders and debtholders to approve a restructuring plan that includes filing for protection under Chapter 11 of the Federal Bankruptcy Code.

Waiter With AIDS Wins $60,000 in a Job Bias Case
LEAD: A waiter with AIDS who was dismissed by his employer has been awarded $60,000 in back wages by a jury that found he was the victim of discrimination.


Menem Confounds
LEAD: Some people here are convinced that President Carlos Saul Menem is the one who can at last lever this country out of deep doldrums.
Some don't trust him at all.
But practically all of the dozens of Argentines I've spoken with find him strange, a man they can't pin down.

LEAD: Dalton Prejean was executed in the Louisiana electric chair early today despite protests that he was dying for a crime he committed as a brain-damaged teen-ager.

7 Weeks Late, New York State Has Budget Pact
LEAD: Bringing to a close New York State's longest budget fight ever, legislative leaders today agreed on a new financial plan that raises spending only slightly while calling for the largest tax increase in the state's history.


A G.M. Plant Adjusts To the 'New Brazil'
LEAD: Robert B. Stone, the American who heads the General Motors Corporation's subsidiary here, will not soon forget March 16, when Brazil's new Government announced its radical attack on inflation.


Evolution in Europe;   New Soviet Envoy to U.S.
LEAD: Aleksandr A. Bessmertnykh, a First Deputy Foreign Minister, has been confirmed as Soviet Ambassador to the United States, the official press agency Tass said today.
He replaces Yuri V. Dubinin, who will be ''transferred to other duties,'' Tass reported.
Mr.
Bessmertnykh's appointment was proposed as part of a shuffle of Soviet diplomatic posts in Europe and North America, announced last month.


Veterans of Vietnam With a Rare Cancer Are Eligible for Aid
LEAD: Vietnam War veterans with soft-tissue sarcoma, a rare form of cancer linked to exposure to Agent Orange, will become eligible for disability payments, the Secretary of Veterans Affairs, Edward J. Derwinski, said today.

Fed Voted in March for Tight Rein
LEAD: Federal Reserve policy makers concluded at their March meeting that excessive inflation would continue and decided to maintain high interest rate policies in the face of a moderately growing economy, according to minutes of the meeting released today.

Mathan Monaster, Scriptwriter, 74
LEAD: Nathan (Nate) Monaster, a writer for television and film, died of heart disease on May 12 at Cedars-Sinai Medical Center in Los Angeles.
He was 74 years old and lived in Los Angeles.


Stamford Phones Work Again
LEAD: A balky central office telephone switch in Stamford, Conn., began working again on Thursday night, 19 hours after it abruptly shut down and cut off all but emergency service to 27,000 telephone lines in the Fairfield County city.
The Southern New England Telephone Company said yesterday that it did not know why the computerized switch failed during a programming change or why it later started working again.


Apple Bancorp Gets Annual Meeting Delay
LEAD: The Apple Bancorp won a few months to explore its options when a Delaware court ruled late Thursday that it did not have to hold its annual meeting by mid-June, as its largest shareholder had insisted.


Japonica Step At Allegheny
LEAD: A New York-based investor group seeking control of Allegheny International Inc. said on Thursday that it had acquired 59 percent of the troubled appliance maker's junior debt through a public tender offer.

COMPANY BRIEFS
LEAD: *
Columbia Gas System Inc., Wilmington, Del., a natural gas holding company, said it was offering for sale its Columbia Gas of New York Inc. distribution unit, which has annual sales of $65 million and distributes about 15 billion cubic feet of natural gas a year.


Religion Notes
LEAD: A Prelate Speaks Out Although it is highly unusual for a prelate of the Roman Catholic Church to lambaste the work of his colleagues publicly, Archbishop Rembert G. Weakland of Milwaukee showed little restraint when he analyzed a pastoral letter on women's concerns being drafted by fellow bishops.


Correction
LEAD: An editorial on Wednesday about college football incorrectly described a proposed change in eligibility rules.
The change, if adopted by the National Collegiate Athletic Association, would in the future allow juniors who are not selected in the pro football draft to return to college as players.
But it would not apply to the 20 juniors not selected this year.


U.S. Seizing Savings Unit It Created in '88
LEAD: The Federal Government said today that it would take control of the Southwest Savings Association, a large, troubled Texas institution that regulators had created two years ago.


Patents: A New Toy And Sailboat At Exhibition;   A Better Catamaran
LEAD: John Rosenberger, an art dealer in Centerport, L.I., displayed a 25-foot prototype of an improved catamaran.
Featuring three pontoons - two in the rear and a central one up front -the 92-pound sailboat skims over the water without having a rudder drag below.
In the absence of a rudder, the boat's four-sided frame turns by using cables to pull the pontoons into a banana-like curve.

No Yankee Tampering, Players Union Says
LEAD: The California Angels have no grounds for accusing the Yankees of tampering with Dave Winfield, the players' labor leader said yesterday, because Winfield's trade to the Angels had not been completed at the time tampering was alleged to have taken place.


&gt;Flexible Benefits: A Boon To Couples
LEAD: Couples who work are being confronted with a new puzzle: how to coordinate the different flexible benefit plans offered by their employers.
The goal is to get the right benefits for the family at the lowest total cost without duplicating coverage.

Corrections
LEAD: A music review on Thursday about a program honoring the composer William Schuman at Merkin Concert Hall last Saturday misidentified the pianist who played his ''Variations on Chester.'' She was Lisa Moore, who substituted for Ilana Vered, the artist listed in the program.


House Bill On Cable TV Regulation
LEAD: A draft of a bill that would reregulate the cable television industry was disclosed yesterday to cable industry leaders by the House Energy and Commerce Committee, which is headed by John D. Dingell, the influential Michigan Democrat.

IRAN-CONTRA PANEL OPENS NEW INQUIRY ON REAGAN'S AIDES
LEAD: A new Federal grand jury today began a criminal inquiry into the Iran-contra affair that is expected to center on the activities of mid-level Reagan Administration officials, Government officials said.

He did not shout or push.

With Tiny Margin Between Them, Dominican Foes Agree to Recount
LEAD: With a margin of only about 11,000 votes separating the two leading candidates in Wednesday's presidential elections, the major political parties agreed today to a ballot-by-ballot recount that is expected to take up to 10 days.


Credit Where It's Due
LEAD: To the Editor:


FICTION
LEAD:
CLOVER.
By Dori Sanders. (Algonquin Books of Chapel Hill, $13.95.) In Dori Sanders' striking first novel, Clover, a 10-year-old black girl from a small town in South Carolina, chronicles her bewildering but gradually deepening relationship with her white stepmother following her father's tragic death only hours after the marriage.


The Executive Computer;   Put on Your Data Glove and Goggles and Step
LEAD: The concept of cyberspace, which first gained popular appeal in a 1984 science-fiction novel, is so radical that even today few people agree on its definition.
Some describe cyberspace as an infinite, computer-generated artificial world where humans experience an approximation of reality.
There, geographic distance is irrelevant and participants can see, hear and even touch objects that exist only as computer data - pure information.


For the Politicians, The Prize in 1990 Is Really 1992
LEAD: THE rap on politicians is that they can't seem to think about anything but the next election.
Not fair.
This year they are focusing on the election after the next one.


MADONNA SAUNTERS DOWN TIN PAN ALLEY
LEAD: Madonna throws both fans and skeptics a curve ball with ''I'm Breathless: Music From and Inspired by the Film 'Dick Tracy' '' (Sire/Warner Brothers 26209; all three formats).
Taking a tangent from a career in which she has reshaped a decade's dance music and pop, Madonna has made an album in which 9 out of 12 songs are anachronistic, doo-wacka-doo numbers, mock period pieces intended to echo the quasi-1930's flavor of the forthcoming movie ''Dick Tracy.


Miss Ford Weds E. B. Daeschler
LEAD: The Bethel Chapel in Croton-on-Hudson, N.Y., was the setting yesterday for the marriage of Emily Ewing Ford, a daughter of Enfield Berry Ford of Riverside, Conn., and Margaret Ford Cowan of Ardsley-on-Hudson, N.Y., to Edward Bassett Daeschler, a son of Mr. and Mrs.
Robert John Daeschler of Short Hills, N.J.


THE IRAN-CONTRA COMMITTEES
LEAD: I did not read Seymour Hersh's piece beyond the point where he referred to Arthur Liman's speculation that a Reagan impeachment would have destroyed a chance for arms control with Russia.


News Analysis;   Budget in Albany: Cheers and Fears
LEAD: When New York's long-overdue budget received final approval at 4:01 A.M. today, state lawmakers congratulated themselves for having found a solution to the worst financial problems that the state has seen in more than a decade.
But critics both inside and outside government say they fear that, even though the budget includes the largest tax increase in the state's history, it will not guarantee balanced budgets in coming years.


Finding a Way For Another Kind of Video
LEAD: It's called Off-HOllywood Video: Independently produced feature films, social documentaries, videos of fine and performing arts, or any other category of special-interest programming - much of it educational - that rarely gets into video stores.


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: A chart last Sunday on April 13 with the All About column misstated the 1989 market share of the Church &amp; Dwight Company's Arm &amp; Hammer Dental Care toothpaste.
The product's market share was 3 percent, not 0.8 percent.

LEAD: The right to free speech clashed with Christianideals of ''responsible freedom'' at Wheaton College last week as nine students were disciplined for pieces printed in a student-run alternative newspaper.

Help Afghans Live With - Not Kill - Each Other
LEAD: To the Editor:


NONFICTION
LEAD:
SURVIVING THE HOLOCAUST: The Kovno Ghetto Diary.
By Avraham Tory.
Edited by Martin Gilbert. (Harvard University, $34.95.) When the Germans swept through the Baltic states in the summer of 1941, they left behind scores of ghettos, each with its own ''Elders' Council'' answerable to Gestapo overlords.

Style Makers;   Delah McKay; Jacket Designer
LEAD: When Delah McKay found herself out of work last year, she went back to her first love: designing.
She whipped up a black velvet jacket reversing to an ocelot print and showed it to boutiques in the New York area.
Tallulah, in Woodbury, L.I., took six, and Asena in Manhattan took four.
Both shops sold out in the first week and immediately reordered.

Condos Surging As Resort Choice
LEAD: RENTALS of resort condominium are booming.
What is propelling them is the need of families with two or three children to economize on food by having some meals in and to get enough space while spending a week skiing or visiting Disney World.
Anyone who has crowded a family with two children into a motel room needs no hard sell to know why renting a place with two rooms for sleeping, two baths, two television sets and a kitchen is a step forward.

New Yorkers, etc.
LEAD: There are still some people around who truly believe that such words as ''dear'' and ''darling'' used in greetings and introductions indicate an intimate relationship, or at least a close friendship with the man or woman in question.

But one thing is coming to stand out, and it is less a style than a sense that architecture is going to be asking less of us, whatever form it takes.

Review/Dance;   City Ballet in a Diversity of Concertos
LEAD: The program of works by George Balanchine that the New York City Ballet offered Thursday night at the New York State Theater came close to being an all-concerto night.
Of the four items, only ''The Steadfast Tin Soldier'' was not set to a concerto.
Fortunately, the ballets were so varied that the evening never grew musically or choreographically monotonous.
