Lawns Need Fertilizer, but Not Too Much
LEAD: THE more you feed, the more you mow.
This is an unwritten law that home gardeners are finding to be true.
Sometimes they forget what fertilizer applications will do to their turf and feed generously in early spring.
They reason, after all, that it has been a long winter and the grass needs a boost.

The dark, oak-paneled room is filled, mostly with young musicians who have dropped in after their jobs.
The pianist John Hicks and the bassist Walter Booker, both well-known veterans of the New York club scene, are laying down a surging rhythm under the trumpet of Roy Hargrove, which is tearing its way through an up-tempo blues.

THE TANGY FLAVORS OF MARSEILLES
LEAD: When I visit Marseilles it is for a cure de poisson, for the city is a fish lover's paradise unequaled in France.
At the tip of the Vieux Port, along the weather-beaten Quai des Belges, the city awakens to the familiar cries of the fishmonger.
It's a rough and ancient symphony as fishermen, their wives and their children, begin to set out the daily catch.


Debts Spur Land Auction
LEAD: THE Hamakua Sugar Company, one of Hawaii's biggest sugar companies, is hoping to sell 8,000 acres - almost all of it zoned for agriculture - to help pay off its debts.
It will begin by offering 5,000 acres at two auctions here, on June 28 and Aug. 16, at which it expects to raise $65 million.

Duty-Free Shops
LEAD: To the Editor: To change from a 750 milliliter bottle to a one liter bottle, as you tried to do in the chart accompanying the article on duty-free shops, you must add one-third of the former, not the 25 percent or one-fourth that you reported.
Properly scaling the price to one liter gives $38.40.
To reach the $36 for a bottle of liqueur in midtown Manhattan by adding the 25 percent listed in the footnote to the table, the 750 milliliter would have cost $28.80.

Israel's Kibbutz Guesthouses
LEAD: AMONG Israel's best-kept secrets are the guesthouses of its kibbutzim.
About 25 kibbutz-operated hotels and holiday villages set up by these collective settlements are scattered throughout the country, from the northern Galilee to the Negev, from the Mediterranean to the Jordan River.
They offer visitors a chance to escape the crowded cities and relax in an informal and intimate atmosphere.

It is black bean soup and, untouched, it has grown cold on the tray beside him.

Evening Hours;   At a Round of Benefits, Aristocrats All
LEAD: When the Russian Nobility Association in America held its annual Easter Ball at the Waldorf-Astoria on May 11, vestiges of imperial Russia were everywhere.
There were a good many Romanovs, titles, rows of medals, colorful sashes and men wearing white gloves to dance.
There were a ballet divertissement on Russian fairy tales, a dance orchestra and, late in the evening, a balalaika ensemble that inspired some high-spirited Cossack dancing.

LEAD:
PRACTICALITIES: Marguerite Duras Speaks to Jerome Beaujour.
By Marguerite Duras. (Grove Weidenfeld, $15.95.) Marguerite Duras is probably best known in this country for her autobiographical novel ''The Lover'' and her script for Alain Resnais's film ''Hiroshima Mon Amour.'' Readers will recognize the fragmented, elliptical style of these works in ''Practicalities,'' a collection of transcribed conversations with her friend Jerome Beaujour.

FICTION
LEAD:
MIGRANT SOULS.
By Arturo Islas. (Morrow, $16.95.) In this second novel by Arturo Islas, we meet three generations of a Chicano family as they sink roots in the fictitious Texas border town of Del Sapo.
The Angel family - which also figured in Mr.
Islas' first novel, ''The Rain God'' - wrestles with problems of identity and values: Are they Mexicans or are they Americans of Mexican heritage?

LEAD: Snooks Eaglin and Johnny Adams, two New Orleans blues singers who rarely travel to the North - and two of the greatest blues musicians alive - came to the Lone Star Roadhouse on Monday night to perform and be videotaped (on high-definition television equipment) for a performance collection of the Smithsonian Institution, a project of the Rhythm and Blues Foundation.


PORTS OF CALL
LEAD: There is nothing like watching from the deck of a ship as a longed-for destination takes shape on the horison and then draws steadily closer.
Lights twinkle, the harbor beckons, the anticipation heightens.
The allure of port cities, languorous or bustling, remains undiminished from the days when ships came in under sail.

Whitaker Wins on Decision
LEAD: Pernell Whitaker showed his quickness and ring cunning.
Azumah Nelson showed his age.
As a result, after 12 rounds at Caesars Palace here tonight, the 26-year-old Whitaker scored a unanimous decision over the 31-year-old Nelson to retain his International Boxing Federation and World Boxing Council lightweight titles.

LEAD: For those who relish the thought of dropping in on a Senate debate to observe a bit of history in the making, Washington holds a year-round fascination.
But quite apart from the heady whiff of power and the abundance of museums and historic sites, there is nothing quite like springtime in the nation's capital.

Lawns Need Fertilizer, but Not Too Much
LEAD: THE more you feed, the more you mow.
This is an unwritten law that home gardeners are finding to be true.
Sometimes they forget what fertilizer applications will do to their turf and feed generously in early spring.
They reason, after all, that it has been a long winter and the grass needs a boost.

The novel ''may be morally iffy, but it is great fun,'' Susan Isaacs said here last year.

HOLOCAUST MUSEUM: A TROUBLED START
LEAD: Have the supporters of the museum considered other alternatives to the project?
Surely the victims and survivors of the Holocaust deserve nothing less than a legacy that combines remembrance, regeneration and reform.
Why not establish memorial institutes dedicated to research into the physical, political and economic ills afflicting societies?

Children Learn To Put Things Off By Watching
LEAD: PROCRASTINATION is so common a trait that it seems a natural human tendency - a minor personality flaw and sometimes humorous.
We are entertained by news coverage of dual national events highlighting the ultimate in mass procrastination; each spring hordes of taxpayers wait in lines at the post office to file last-minute returns.

HOW A U.S. MISSILE NEARLY UNDID DEAL
LEAD: An obscure cruise missile with the odd name of Tacit Rainbow almost managed to unravel all the progress that American and Soviet negotiators achieved in their four days of arms control talks in Moscow, a senior Administration official said today.


Corrections
LEAD: An air fare listing in the Travel Watch column on page 21 of the Travel section today includes erroneous entries for the New York-Chicago route.
Pan Am's lowest restricted round-trip fare for the route is $250; its lowest unrestricted fare for the same route is $533.
American, Continental, Northwest, TWA, United and USAir also offer the $250 fare.

LEAD: To the Editor:


Texas Medical Center Offers Builders $1.3 Billion Rx
LEAD: BECAUSE of the collapse of the energy industry, the 10-year commercial building boom that shaped this city's skyline has, since the mid-80's, come to a virtual standstill - except on the 600-acre campus of the Texas Medical Center next to Rice University.


Taking a Mulligan or Two With the Rules of Golf
LEAD: One day I was playing a round of golf with my friend Miles Jaffee, an excellent sailor, skier and tennis player who never bothered to master the art of batting balls through pastures.
After one particularly bad shot, Miles picked up the ball and threw it toward the hole.
His eyes lit up; the thrill of invention was about to replace the agony of defeat.


HARVARD LAW SCHOOL
LEAD: Your article implies that the professors interviewed exert great influence over students.
The next time you choose to investigate Harvard Law School, I suggest you shift your focus from the ivory tower to the campus below.


The Rising Costs of Closing on a Home
LEAD: WHEN Beth and Timothy Dennis went house hunting on Long Island three years ago, about a year after their marriage, they thought their biggest challenge would be scraping together the down payment and making sure their salaries covered monthly mortgage and tax bills.


Bali's Dyed Gringsing Cloth, a 7-Year Wonder
LEAD: IN the pantheon of things black and white and red all over, the Balinese textile called gringsing must certainly be the most obscure.
The double-ikat technique used to make it - that of tying and dyeing the threads of both length and width, warp and weft, before weaving - is done nowhere else in Indonesia.


New Germany; Old Fears
LEAD: By formal agreement concluded Friday, the two Germanys will become one on July 1, barely eight months after the wall's fall.
To most people, what was unthinkable then seems unremarkable now.
Polls indicate that Americans are less concerned about German unification than are the Germans themselves.

Pilgrims Seek Blessing At Lourdes in Litchfield
LEAD: MARLENE POPP, a small gray-haired woman in a pink raincoat, stepped gingerly from the tour bus and gazed at the tall birches that lead to an arched stone gate. ''Isn't this beautiful!'' she said.
Then, hurrying to catch up with her friends, she entered Lourdes in Litchfield, singing ''Ave Maria'' as she went.

LEAD: Amid demands that importing of Canadian caribou be halted, a new herd of caribou has been released in a forest near this northern town.


RUNNING AWAY TO SEA, THE FREIGHTER WAY
LEAD: When you announce to your loved ones that you are hopping a freighter to South America and will be gone for two months and they bid you fond farewell on the eve of your departure, why are you seen skulking around town a week later?
Because just as time and tide wait for no man, freighters don't depart for a ready woman.

For Some Authors, Book Publishers Pay Millions Without a Word
LEAD: NOT so long ago, an author wrote a novel and a publisher paid for it.
Today, in the quest for big-name authors and bigger profits, the order has reversed.
Publishers are now increasingly using multimillion-dollar advances to woo best-selling novelists into signing contracts, sometimes without even a glimmer of what they will be writing about.

Postings: For 28 Eligible Buyers;   Keeping Costs Down
LEAD: Alarmed that housing costs in Suffolk County were driving moderate-income families away, officials in the Town of Southold adopted a new zoning policy in 1986 aimed at cutting the cost of new homes.
It is finally paying off: Ground was broken this month for a project offering eligible families 28 half-acre homesites in Southold Village for $30,000 each.

Albert A. Grobe, 81, WQXR Announcer And Journalist, Dies
LEAD: Albert A. Grobe, who retired in 1973 as chief announcer of WQXR, the radio station of The New York Times, after more than three decades with the station, died yesterday at White Plains Hospital after a long illness.
He was 81 years old and lived in White Plains.


FEMINISM AND THERAPY
LEAD: As a wife, mother, professional nurse and teacher, I say it's time the women's movement supported the importance of the work of women like me.
Instead, many feminists of this revolution have tried to persuade me and my peers to abandon our ''women's work.'' As a result, the exhilaration I felt in my 1970's consciousness-raising groups has turned to ashes.

A Moment for Dusting Off Faded Reputations;
LEAD: Judging by the current spate of exhibitions devoted to the images of little known or long forgotten photographers, one might think that the world was running out of photographs.
But since photography is by nature a prolific medium, and practically anyone can take a picture, some less obvious possibility than a paucity of pictures must be at play.


Question Of the Week;   Do the Yankees Need Dave Winfield?
LEAD: The Yankees definitely need Dave Winfield.
He has had an extremely consistent career in the field and with the bat.
His value has somewhat declined because of his injury, but consistency is something the Yankees need especially since their front office contributes to the team's unsettledness.
Winfield had the ability to help the Yankees in turbulent times if he had been given the chance to play out of his current slump.

Byte-Sized, but Big
LEAD: THE MONITOR (RIGHT) IS 14 feet high.
The keyboard (above) is 25 feet long.
The floppy disk is six feet on a side.
In an era in which the desktop computer stands as a monument to miniaturization, the walk-through computer exhibit being installed at the Computer Museum in Boston is iconoclastic in its dimensions, if more conventionally educational in its purpose.

Pastimes;   Chess
LEAD: Momentum is a mysterious factor, bringing with it an aura of invincibility while it lasts, but liable to plummet back to earth at any moment.
After the 10th round of the Watson, Farley and Williams International Tournament in London, which ended May 3, Patrick Wolff of the United States had won 8 points and it looked as though his steamroller would never stop.

Lawns Need Fertilizer, but Not Too Much
LEAD: THE more you feed, the more you mow.
This is an unwritten law that home gardeners are finding to be true.
Sometimes they forget what fertilizer applications will do to their turf and feed generously in early spring.
They reason, after all, that it has been a long winter and the grass needs a boost.


Review/Theater;   Culture Shock in Hwang's 'F.O.B.'
LEAD: At the end of the first act of David Henry Hwang's ''F.O.B.,'' there is a mirthful eating scene that summarizes the conflict between an American-born young man of Chinese descent and a newly landed immigrant, fresh off the boat (F.O.B.) from China.
The newcomer, played by Dennis Dun, pours a jar of fiery hot sauce over his dinner and eats it as if it were the most savory of delights.


'Tenured Radicals'
LEAD: To the Editor:


Currency;   Ending the Week on an Up Note
LEAD: It was an up week, but just a little, for the dollar.
After falling against the Japanese yen in the beginning of the week, the dollar inched back Thursday and Friday.
It also rose those two days against other major currencies, except for the British pound.
It is not clear if the rally is just a correction after the sharp drop of the week before or rather the start of a new trend.


Out of The Kitchen
LEAD: One person's idea of drudgery is another's inspiration.
Considert his: Many people think that kitchen chores - like cooking and cleaning up - are menial, even demeaning duties, and that aprons are what you wwear to do them in.
But then there are those for whom cooking cloths and clothes kindle deliciously romantic visions of picnics on the grass, barbecues int he backyard or creative repasts stirred up in a kitchen fit for a gourmet.


Summer Squall Wins Preakness
LEAD: Summer Squall avenged his Kentucky Derby loss to Unbridled by scoring a 2 1/4-length victory in the Preakness Stakes today at Pimlico, but there will be no rubber match between the colts in the final leg of the Triple Crown.


Evolution in Europe;   Romanian Campaign Leaves Trail of Violence
LEAD: At the local headquarters of the ruling National Salvation Front, about 30 party workers watched intently today as a videotape of their campaign rally on Thursday was played and replayed.
They were gathering evidence.
The rally ended in violence when counterdemonstrators stormed the speaker's platform.


'Lear' Girds for a Remarkable Episode
LEAD: The P. T. Barnum of the avant-garde, Robert Wilson began his career in theater in the late 60's with a war on language.
In silent epics like ''Deathman Glance'' he ignored it.
In masterpieces like ''Einstein on the Beach'' he deconstructed it.
Now this sworn enemy of speech is rehearsing Shakespeare's ''King Lear,'' one of the greatest arrays of words we have.


Campus Life: Tufts;   It Takes Time, As Well as Credits, To Graduate Here
LEAD: Ari Socolow has completed the 34 courses needed to graduate from Tufts University, and he completed them in six semesters, not the usual eight, making the dean's list last fall and this spring.

Review/Dance;   'Combat' By Jersey Troupe
LEAD: The New Jersey Ballet Company made a pleasant impression on Wednesday night at the Triplex Theater.
A concern for technical accuracy and proper placement was evident throughout the evening.
But the dancers were also aware that ballet is an art of the stage as well as the studio, and they performed with theatrical assurance.

In Search of Capitalism With a Human Face
LEAD: TWO decades ago Communist reformers in Eastern Europe wanted to build a new type of economic system, one that would be a bold mix of Marxism and the free market.
Eager to shun Stalinist repression and stagnation as well as to avoid capitalist evils like unemployment, these idealists dreamed of constructing ''socialism with a human face.


Solace After Bereavement: Counseling Services Grow
LEAD: Nearly every day, Gail Bishop travels through small towns in northern Colorado like a circuit rider, visiting families that have suffered a death in the last year.
She works for a funeral home that not only buries the dead but also helps survivors deal with their grief.

Review/Dance;   Serious Fun Warms Up For The New Season
LEAD: Serious Fun, the performance arts series that has brought experimental music, dance and theater to Lincoln Center for the last three years, will return to Alice Tully Hall July 13 for its fourth season.

Mutual Funds;   Bracing for Tougher Times
LEAD: Once upon a time - more than 120 years ago - a small East Texas river town called Jefferson was thriving as steamships carried cotton and timber down the Red River to the Mississippi and thence to New Orleans.
Then one day, the railroad magnate Jay Gould (no relation to this writer) came to Jefferson.


Installing a Ceiling Fan
LEAD: LARGE-BLADED ceiling fans are more economical to operate than air-conditioners and can add to comfort and energy savings the year round.


Utensil Essentials
LEAD: BY THE TIME I MOVED OUT OF MY New York apartment last year, I had filled 12 large boxes with molds for steamed pudding, terrines for pate en croute, 300 tartlet pans, muffin tins in every shape and size, a set of wedding-cake pans, an arsenal of knives and 15 ice-cream scoops.


Soul-Soothing Ride
LEAD: I HAVE had occasion to ride along the Ocean Parkway from Meadowbrook to Captree almost every week in the last few months.
This is a ride I always enjoy, both as a driver and as a passenger.
It soothes and pacifies to see the sky meet the ocean and the bay.
The variety of colors and shapes, the chance of seeing wildlife, the absence of commercialism and the absence of people are among the attractions.


Hockey Award
LEAD: He has won more games than any other American college hockey coach and now Len Ceglarski, who has a record of 632-309-35 in his 32 years at Clarkson College and Boston College, is getting some recognition.

Brazil

Mr.
Hillis is the 34-year-old creator of the Connection Machine, a futuristic supercomputer that he believes will be the basis for the first teraflop computer.

The building has no air conditioner, and we are sweating under our labors, but somehow we feel purposeful here in this small suburban branch library, where the children's librarian occasionally looks up at us from her heat stupor, nodding in approval.

By Pa and Ma I'm daily told
To marry now's my time,
For though I'm very far from old,
I'm rather in my prime.
They say while we have any sun
We ought to make our hay -
And India has so hot a one,
I'm going to Bombay!
Thomas Hood's famous ditty, ''I'm Going to Bombay,'' embodies just one aspect of the great 19th-century saga of British imperialism.

Art Appreciator
LEAD: Sagging art market?
Not when Ryoei Saito is around.
Shopping at Christie's and Sotheby's last week, the Japanese industrialist paid the highest and the second-highest prices ever paid for a work of art at auction.
First was Vincent van Gogh's ''Portrait of Dr.
Gachet,'' $82.5 million, on Tuesday.
Next was Pierre Auguste Renoir's cafe scene ''At the Moulin de la Galette,'' $78.1 million, on Thursday.

CORRECTIONS
LEAD: An article on April 8 about an entrepreneur's success in starting a magazine for parents misstated, through information supplied by a magazine consultant, the number of magazines that have failed since 1988.
A recent recalculation of figures from the Standard Rate and Data Service, a magazine reference guide, indicated that there were 225 new magazines and 119 that ceased publication.

Data Bank/May 20, 1990


HOLOCAUST MUSEUM: A TROUBLED START
LEAD: As to Henry Kissinger's fear that a national Holocaust museum might constitute ''too high a profile'' for American Jews, I say we must remember that the lessons to be learned from Hitler's reign of terror are not about guilt or apology or remorse but about understanding that this must never again happen to any group of people anywhere, ever.


Review/Music;   Bang on a Can Festival Ends With a Weekend of Browsing
LEAD: The word ''supermarket'' seems an ugly one to place next to the performing arts, but it can be applied admiringly to the finale of the Bang on a Can Festival.
A series of new-music events that began on May 4 at the RAPP Arts Center in the East Village ended with four concerts last Sunday that in essence ran one into the next.


HARVARD LAW SCHOOL
LEAD: It seems ironic that Dean Robert C. Clark, who ''deplored contemporary students' ignorance 'of how one goes about proving something,' '' should use obfuscating language himself in trying to justify corporate law as a career choice. ''Corporate law,'' he says, ''is intensely moral, you know.'' The challenge of it, he says, is ''to devise optimal controls on managerial discretion.


New Lottery for N.B.A.
LEAD: The draft lottery, the annual game the National Basketball Association plays to give the weaker teams a chance to get better, will be held today at the Equitable Center in Manhattan.
At stake will be the order of draft selection for the 11 teams that failed to make the playoffs.

Was This Exhibition Necessary?
LEAD: What must be conceded about ''The Passionate Eye: Impressionist and Other Master Paintings From the E. G. Buhrle Collection,'' at the National Gallery of Art through July 15, is that it includes 85 works of quality and consistency.


Streetscapes: Hampshire House;   A Case of 'Frenzied Financing'
LEAD: THE softening of the real estate market after a decade of dizzying growth has changed the plans and prospects of developers, businesses, institutions and even governments.
Yet a look backward to earlier hard times shows that many troubled projects have managed to survive and prosper.


Hiking With History in the Pyrenees
LEAD: IN 1700, Louis XIV of France observed his grandson's accession to the Spanish throne with satisfaction: ''the Pyrenees have ceased to exist,'' he boasted.
Luckily for those who crave the satisfactions of great massifs, the Sun King's edict left undisturbed this soaring frontier dividing France from the Iberian peninsula.


EAST BERLIN OPENS NAZI FILES TO U.S.
LEAD: The Justice Department has reached agreement with East Germany for access to that country's World War II archives, a move that investigators say could result in important new prosecutions of Nazi war criminals living in the United States.

They chose the prison because they didn't like the kind of people attracted to a college.

Faded Glory of Syracuse
LEAD: ONE can never be sure how people will react to Syracuse, a city that appears hesitant, uncertain of its magnitude and its identity, belonging neither with the big Sicilian ports of Palermo, Catania and Messina nor with the smaller and sleepier provincial capitals like Agrigento and Enna.
Some visitors to Syracuse are fascinated by the evocative atmosphere of faded glory in what was once the greatest and perhaps most beautiful of the Greek cities in the western Mediterranean.

Hotels
LEAD: To the Editor: I read Paul Hoffmann's ''Seven City Hostelries'' (Travel, March 18) with nostalgia.

My husband and I returned many times and stayed in all of the hotels mentioned except the Atrium Hyatt.

Israel Wakes Up to the Big New Wave of Soviet Jews
LEAD: CONFRONTED with the prospect of a great new wave of Soviet Jewish immigration, Israelis are pondering how and whether they can manage an influx that could equal in magnitude those that built a different, less complex Israel four decades ago.

WHY IT TOOK SO LONG
LEAD: I was working as a newspaperman when I was drafted into the Army during the Korean War, and I decided to write a continuing column about it for my paper called This New Army, which was what everybody was calling that same old Army in those days.
I wrote about how unbelievably stupid sergeants and corporals were, how unspeakably dreadful Army food was and how very peculiarly the general behaved when he noticed


A Loner With a Strong Emotional Center
LEAD: Eduard Tubin is one of music's loners.
Estonian by birth, the composer spent the last half of his life in Sweden.
He followed no fashions, belonged to no school.
When he died in 1982, he left a legacy of 10 symphonies, two operas, two ballets and a variety of concertos, cantatas and works in smaller forms.


RJR Nabisco's Disgruntled Bondholders
LEAD: A ticking time bomb with RJR Nabisco Inc.'s name on it is wending its way through Federal court.
It's a lawsuit filed by Metropolitan Life Insurance Company and Jefferson-Pilot Life Insurance Company which, if successful, could force the refinancing of some $5 billion in outstanding RJR Nabisco debt and allow some disgruntled bondholders to get their money back.

Iranians to Shun Mecca Trip
LEAD: Iran's Foreign Ministry said today that Iranian pilgrims would stay away from the annual Muslim pilgrimage to Mecca for the third successive year because of sharp differences with Saudi Arabia.
Iran has boycotted the pilgrimage, called the haj, since 1987, when more than 400 people, mainly Shiite Iranians, were killed in clashes with security forces.

Track
A Title for George Mason: Led by Tony Barton and Patrick O'Connor, George Mason yesterday won the IC4A outdoor championship for the second year in a row, scoring 106 points to 56 for Penn State in second and 49 for Georgetown in third.
The event took place on Yale's Clint Frank Track in New Haven.

Combined billings are $8 million.

In Changing South Africa, 5 Deaths Reveal Unrest
LEAD: The killing of two whites at a gold mine at Welkom, about 140 miles southwest of here, and the slaying of three blacks in an adjoining township have exposed broader racial tensions between blacks and whites in South Africa.
Those tensions are increasingly coming to the surface as a result of the political liberalization under way in the country.


In N.Y.C. Streets Of Terror
LEAD: As the summer of 1990 approaches, the specter of social disorder and violence hangs ominously over every part of New York City.
Rich and poor alike are running out of safe passages.
Neighborhoods once regarded as reasonably secure have turned into combat zones.
It has become dangerous for people to walk in some neighborhoods merely because of the color of their skin.

Review/Ballet;   Joys of 'Cortege Hongrois' With Dreamlike Partners
LEAD: The New York City Ballet saved the best for last on Friday night at the New York State Theater, with a performance of George Balanchine's ''Cortege Hongrois'' that was a delight from beginning to end.
The ballet is not one of Balanchine's most inspired efforts.
Created in homage to Melissa Hayden on her retirement from City Ballet in 1973, it captures something of her boldness and spirit.


Review/Music;   Harry Edison's Brand of Jazz Improvisation
LEAD: Mainstream jazz can be deceptively simple, formally.
The group led by the trumpter Harry (Sweets) Edison on Wednesday night at Condon's (where he played through last night) opened and closed its set with blues tunes and played standards in between.
Solos followed the melody of each piece, just as they do and have in countless jazz culbs across the country.

LEAD: When a high-level American delegation arrives here tonight for talks on Monday on the separatist war in Kashmir, it is likely to find the Government of Prime Minister V. P. Singh preoccupied by its worst domestic political crisis since coming to power in December.

THE MEDIA BUSINESS: Advertising;   Shift at Lintas
LEAD: David N. Martin, who last week sold Hawley Martin Partners in Richmond, of which he is part owner, to Lintas USA, has agreed to become chairman of the Lintas subsidiary Fahlgren &amp; Swink.
He replaces H. Smoot Fahlgren, who remains chief executive.
Mr.
Martin's name will now be on three agencies: Hawley Martin, of which he remains chairman; Fahlgren &amp; Swink, which will be renamed Fahlgren Martin, and the Martin Agency, the Richmond agency he founded in 1965 and left in 1988.

Review/Art;   Effects of Men's Desires On the Lives of Women
LEAD: Karen Finley is the latest artist to be singled out in the continued attacks on the financing policies of the National Endowment for the Arts.
She is a blunt, sometimes eloquent 33-year-old performance artist who sees her art as a vehicle for social change.
She is best known for using her own naked body on stage in an effort to expose and confront male phobias and desires and their effects on the lives of women.

Guilty Plea by Fuji Unit
LEAD: Fuji Medical Systems USA Inc., a unit of Fuji Photo Film of Tokyo, has pleaded guilty to making an illegal corporate contribution to the unsuccessful 1988 re-election campaign of Joseph J. DioGuardi, who was a Republican Congressman from Westchester County.
Federal prosecutors said on Thursday that Fuji Medical, based in Stamford, Conn., had been charged with a one-count misdemeanor for contributing $7,400 to the campaign.

Bell one Sunday put on his uniform with its silver bars and asked to attend the service.

Quotation of the Day
LEAD: ''When I go to P.S. 46 to play basketball, it's this homeless lady up there and people be spitting on her and saying, 'You stink.' So I buy her like a bag of potato chips and she says thank you.
And I feel proud of myself.''
-Damien Mackie, 13, of Brooklyn. [B5:1.]

Corporate Tax Study
LEAD: Many profitable companies are still paying less than 10 percent of their earnings in Federal taxes, although average corporate taxes are higher since the tax overhaul in 1986, Congressional auditors have found.

LEAD: Walter Evers, the founding president of Walter Evers &amp; Company, management consultants, died of leukemia on May 11 at Sharp Memorial Hospital in San Diego.
He was 76 years old and had homes in Cleveland and Coronado, Calif.

Audrey Lawson Wed To Scott L. Kaufman
LEAD: Audrey Ellen Lawson, who is to receive an M.D. from the University of Michigan next month, and Scott Laurence Kaufman, who received a law degree last week from Duke University, were married yesterday at Congregation Beth Achim in Southfield, Mich.
Rabbis Martin Berman and Milton Arm officiated.


Reviews/Music;   Reunion for an Ensemble
LEAD: The Music Project started out in 1976 as a group of young freelancers who wanted to balance their orchestral jobs with chamber music.
For several years, the flexible ensemble of strings, winds and piano had a regular series at Merkin Concert Hall, but as the players grew busier in the mid-1980's, the group drifted apart.


Housing Official Will Lead Board at Savings Agency
LEAD: Peter H. Monroe, an official of the Housing and Urban Development Department, was appointed today to be president of the Oversight Board of the Resolution Trust Corporation, the agency that oversees the savings and loan bailout.


Dollar Rises on Expectation Of Steady Interest Rates
LEAD: The dollar gained ground yesterday in worldwide foreign exchange trading as speculation rose that United States interest rates would be holding steady for the time being.


Hidden Tide Of Taxes Due In New York
LEAD: To the people who rent cars, stay in hotels or buy bottles of soda, the impact of New York State's new tax increases will be apparent immediately.
But consumers will also ultimately pay more for thousands of goods and services under less obvious sections of the $1.4 billion tax plan, business leaders and some lawmakers said today.


Gerber Is Selling Day-Care Centers
LEAD: The Gerber Products Company said it would sell its 115 day-care centers in another divestiture aimed at getting the company back to the basics of baby food.
Fred Schomer, Gerber's executive vice president and chief financial officer, said an affiliate of KD Equities, a New York-based private investment partnership, would buy Gerber Children's Centers Inc.


Karl Meyer, 90, Dies; A Research Biochemist
LEAD: Dr.
Karl Meyer, a research biochemist who specialized in connective tissue diseases, died on Friday at the Dunroven Nursing Home in Cresskill, N.J.
He was 90 years old and lived in Teaneck, N.J.


Mosbacher on World Trade
LEAD: Commerce Secretary Robert A. Mosbacher chided American companies for taking a short-term view of profits and for being slow in taking advantage of new Eastern European markets.


Yemen Ratifies Merger With Marxist South
LEAD: Yemen's Parliament today approved President Ali Abdullah Saleh's plan to proclaim a merger with Southern Yemen on Tuesday, official radio reports in Yemen said.

Oil Rig Count Up by 31
LEAD: The number of working oil and natural gas rigs in the United States rose last week by 31, to a total of 972, Baker Hughes Inc. reported today.
It was the third straight increase.
Previously, the count had declined for several weeks.
This week's count is also well ahead of the 737 total posted a year ago, Baker Hughes said.


Pretoria Looks at Township Changes
LEAD: The South African Government announced today that it is ready to consider alternatives to the racially segregated municipalities that form a conspicuous face of apartheid.


In Albany, Much Unfinished Business
LEAD: New Yorkers can be excused for thinking that the State Legislature had nothing on its agenda this year other than passing a budget.


Toward Even Safer Food for the U.S. Consumer
LEAD: To the Editor:


Evolution in Europe;   Insulting Gorbachev Now Illegal, But It All Depends on the Tone
LEAD: The Soviet Parliament enacted a law today that makes insulting the Soviet President a crime punishable by a prison term, but only if the insults are expressed ''in an indecent way'' - a legal turn of phrase that won support even from civil libertarians.


East German Air Move
LEAD: East Germany's national airline, Interflug, will join the International Air Transport Association on July 1, the group said last week.
Interflug will become the 190th member of the association, which includes most of the world's leading airlines.
The Soviet airline Aeroflot joined last year.
The association recommends fares and standardizes ticketing and other airline procedures.

LEAD: A high school's assistant principal was shot to death and left in a burning school building on Sunday, and a science teacher was charged today with his murder.

He is Harold Ostroff.

LEAD: The opposition Social Democrats signaled today that they would battle Chancellor Helmut Kohl over the treaty on economic union with East Germany, threatening a delay in monetary union and adding another hurdle to the increasingly contentious path to reunification.

Quotas That Never Were
LEAD: President Bush threatens to veto a pending civil rights bill because his Attorney General says it would lead to hiring quotas.
But nobody, including the Attorney General, has produced anything but speculation that it would.
Indeed, the evidence is emphatically to the contrary.


Surgery for McHale
LEAD: The Boston Celtic forward Kevin McHale underwent surgery yesterday to repair ligament damage in his left thumb and was expected to be recovered by next season, the club said.
McHale underwent a procedure at New England Baptist Hospital to repair the radial collateral ligament and was likely to have his hand in a cast for about six weeks.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a front-page article on Sunday about proposed military spending cuts misstated a Bush Adminstration proposal in some copies.
The Administration has proposed cutting military spending by 10 percent over the next five years, not 10 percent a year.


Procter Sees Higher Profit
LEAD: The Procter &amp; Gamble Company expects to enjoy strong sales and income growth in the fiscal year ending June 30, Edwin Artzt, company chairman, said today at a rare meeting with industry analysts.


Chiat/Day Consolidates Operations
LEAD: IN an effort to consolidate its North American operations, Chiat/Day/ Mojo said yesterday that it would sell a majority of its San Francisco office to several agency executives.
Chiat also announced changes in the management of its Canadian division, including the appointment of a new president and the departure of its creative director.


A Little Frog Outleaps Some Large Outsiders
LEAD: After a controversy over whether they should be allowed to compete in the 1990 Jumping Frog Jubilee, three African Goliath frogs fizzled in the competition on Sunday, allowing a California frog to win.


Ohioan Gets High Navy Post
LEAD: The Pentagon today announced the appointment of Ben Rose, a lawyer in Lima, Ohio, and former leader of the Republican minority in the Ohio House of Representatives, as Deputy Assistant Secretary of the Navy for installations and the environment.
Mr.
Rose was a Navy officer from 1961 to 1966, serving on an Atlantic fleet destroyer and later in Vietnam.

F.D.A. Backs A Treatment For Cancer Of Bladder

Rebel Neurologists Say Boxing Can Be Safe
LEAD: THE super middleweight match for new professional boxers at Gleason's Arena in Brooklyn is raucous and bloody, the way the crowd loves it.
Many of the punches glance off the boxers' sweaty bodies, but once in a while a glove hooks through the air and connects solidly with an opponent's head.
As the stunned fighter regains composure, electrified fans jump to their feet with a stream of cheers, jeers and hoots.


Shifts at Chrysler
LEAD: The Chrysler Corporation named Lawrence W. Baker general manager for its Jeep/Eagle division, responsible for marketing, advertising and merchandising.
He switches jobs with Martin R. Levine, who becomes general manager for the Dodge car and truck division.
Chrysler also appointed Ralph A. Sarotte director of multi-brand marketing programs, responsible for media budgeting and corporate advertising.

LEAD:

E.P.A. Draft Report Cites Studies Linking Cancer to Electricity

Ivory Trading Ban Said to Force Factories to Shut
LEAD: Major ivory carving factories in Asia that produced jewelry, figurines and tourist trinkets have virtually closed down since a world ban on ivory trading came into force this year, says an expert in the trade who just finished a survey of the ban.

Edward Steitz, 69, an Authority On the Rules of Basketball, Dies
LEAD: Edward Steitz, an authority on the rules of basketball who helped introduce the 3-point shot to college and international competition, died yesterday morning at the Baystate Medical Center in Springfield, Mass., after suffering cardiac arrest at his home in East Longmeadow, Mass.
Mr.
Steitz, director of athletics emeritus at Springfield College, had served as grand marshal at the school's commencement on Sunday.

LEAD: A multi-media artist filed suit yesterday in Federal District Court in Manhattan charging that a conservative politi-cal-action group in Mississippi had copied his work without authorization, distorting and mutilating it so as to defame him ''as being a mere pornographer and not a serious visual artist.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, a front-page article yesterday about the killing of Palestinians by an apparently deranged Israeli referred inconsistently in some copies to the site of the attack.
It occurred in Rishon le Zion, seven miles south of Tel Aviv, not in the Israeli-occupied Gaza Strip.
Later developments are reported today on page A1.


Contras' Statements in Conflict on Disarming
LEAD: The demobilization of the contra army remained clouded by confusion today amid conflicting declarations about whether guerrilla commanders would fulfill their commitments to disband their army.


Ryan on Disabled List
LEAD: Nolan Ryan of the Texas Rangers, nursing a sore back, was placed on the 15-day disabled list yesterday, retroactive to May 18.


DEBATE IN HOUSE ON CLEAN AIR BILL
LEAD: Vowing not to repeat the six weeks of Senate floor fights over an overhaul of the Clean Air Act, the House of Representatives opened debate on its own version today, and lawmakers said there was wide support for passage.

Fisk's Home Run in 7th Is the Decisive Blow
LEAD: Lance McCullers had thrown two breaking pitches to Carlton Fisk with runners on first and third and the Yankees clinging to a 4-3 lead in the seventh inning last night.
Neither pitch was a strike.


TAX APPEAL LOST BY MORMON COUPLE
LEAD: Resolving a Federal income tax dispute that has divided the lower courts, the Supreme Court ruled unanimously today that Mormon parents may not take a charitable deduction for the money they spend to support their children during the young people's required service as missionaries.


Arafat Seeks to Attend U.N. Council Debate
LEAD: The Palestine Liberation Organization has asked the Bush Administration to allow its leader, Yasir Arafat, to enter the United States to attend a United Nations Security Council debate on the latest violence in the Israeli-occupied territories, Arab and United Nations officials said today.

Free Flights For Investors
LEAD: Australians will gain free air travel if they invest in Compass Holdings Ltd., which hopes to begin Australia's third big domestic airline after deregulation in November.


Dinkins Plans Drug-Fighting Centers at 9 Schools
LEAD: Mayor David N. Dinkins announced plans yesterday to set up community drug prevention centers at nine public schools, to increase health services for pregnant drug abusers and to create a central office to expand and coordinate the city's fragmented anti-drug efforts.


Efforts to Curb Buying By Boesky Recounted
LEAD: A former executive who had worked for Ivan F. Boesky testified yesterday that Mr.
Boesky was so unable to control his appetite for takeover stocks that executives at his New York trading firm felt compelled to lie to him about the firm's capital position.


Minerva Salzman Henkin, Lawyer, 90
LEAD: Minerva Salzman Henkin, a retired New York lawyer who specialized in immigration law, died on May 14 at the Quakertown Community Hospital in Pennsylvania.
She was 90 years old and lived in Haycock Township, Pa.


California: Giant of the Future. . .
LEAD: With California's June 5 primary just two weeks away, national and international attention is turning to America's megastate on the Pacific.
California is in the midst of an unprecedented social experiment with vast ramifications.


Jersey Company to Introduce Fast Chip-Making Machine
LEAD: A semiconductor industry innovator who is highly critical of the United States' strategy for competing with Japanese chip makers will introduce a machine today that he says could dramatically improve this country's ability to keep pace with Japan in the mid-1990's.
The machine is at the center of a debate over whether it is the correct technology for the 1990's.

LEAD:
TENNIS
Maleeva and Paulus Lead Advance
The top two seeded players in the European Open in Geneva, Manuela Maleeva of Bulgaria and Barbara Paulus of Austria, won their first-round matches yesterday.


Muslim Leader of Kashmir Slain; 30 Die as Police Fire on Mourners
LEAD: A hereditary Islamic leader, the most senior and influential opponent of Indian rule in Kashmir, was assassinated in his home in the state's capital today.
When 100,000 angry mourners followed his body through the streets of the city, security forces opened fire, killing at least 30 people and wounding some 200, according to hospital doctors.


Census Units Understaffed, House Panel Is Told
LEAD: An official of the key investigative branch of Congress said yesterday that as of May 9, more than 70 percent of the Census Bureau's district offices in the Atlanta, San Francisco and Dallas areas did not have enough follow-up enumerators.


Foreign Stocks And U.S. Rules
LEAD: The Chicago Mercantile Exchange's president, William Brodsky, says changes are needed on how foreign securities are listed on United States exchanges so that more Japanese companies may trade on the New York Stock Exchange.

Gray Wolf Discounted As a Yellowstone Peril
LEAD: Reintroducing the gray wolf to Yellowstone National Park after more than a 50-year absence would have minimal effect on other wildlife in the park or livestock on surrounding ranches, the National Park Service said in a report issued today.

LEAD: Jose Canseco hit a three-run homer today as the Oakland Athletics beat the Toronto Blue Jays, 4-1, in a game that included a bench-clearing incident.


Review/Opera;   A 17th-Century Rarity, Cesti's 'Dori'
LEAD: Reviving ancient operatic comedies like ''La Dori'' sets up a struggle between archeology and entertainment that can scarcely be avoided.
The Mannes Camerata and its director, translator and adapter, Paul C. Echols, are in the midst of a five-performance run of Antonio Cesti's stage piece.
To make this mid-17th-century rat's nest of love affairs and sexual confusions intelligible for late-20th-century audiences is a job in itself.


A Cheyenne to Head Indian Museum
LEAD: The Smithsonian Institution today named W. Richard West Jr., a member of the Cheyenne-Arapaho tribes of Oklahoma and a Stanford-trained lawyer, as the first director of its National Museum of the American Indian.


Plan Envisions Cleanup Work for Early Release
LEAD: New York City's new Correction Commissioner outlined a plan yesterday for several thousand ''low-risk inmates'' to work toward early release by performing outside work like clearing litter from highways, cleaning subways and building park benches.

LEAD: Kidder, Peabody &amp; Company announced yesterday that it would resume investing its own capital in a form of program trading that has been widely criticized for aggravating price declines in the market.


Bayer-Nova Deal
LEAD: Bayer A.G., the West German chemicals company, agreed to acquire the Polysar Rubber division of the Nova Corporation of Canada for $1.06 billion (United States).
The agreement must be approved by government agencies in the two countries.
The Polysar unit, based in Toronto, has 3,500 employees worldwide.

LEAD: Tele-Communications Inc., the nation's largest cable television company, said yesterday that it was again altering the form of its planned spinoff of assets.
Under the new plan, Tele-Communications said it would spin off part of its assets into a separate business.

The company said its Mother's and Salerno subsidiaries, with combined annual revenue of about $200 million, hold only 5.7 percent of the United States biscuit market.

Supreme Court Roundup;   Law That Created Crime Victims' Fund Is Upheld
LEAD: The Supreme Court today upheld a Federal law requiring people convicted of Federal crimes to pay a ''special assessment'' into a fund for crime victims.
The assessments, ranging from $10 to $200, generate about $125 million a year for the fund set up under the law, the Victims of Crime Act of 1984.

MARKETS

LEAD: The top two seeded male players for the French Open, which starts May 28, are Stefan Edberg of Sweden, the loser in last year's final, and Boris Becker of West Germany.

LEAD: A man accused of poisoning his infant son with sulfuric acid as part of a plot to sue a manufacturer of baby formula has been found guilty of first-degree murder and could face the death penalty.


Visitor From Afar
LEAD: Comet Austin, a visitor from the outer reaches of the solar system, will make its closest approach to the Earth on Friday, when it is expected to come within 22 million miles.
Until its discovery last year, this comet had never been seen before, and astronomers are studying it with keen interest.
Comet Austin is barely visible through binoculars in the early-morning sky.

German Ex-Official Charged
LEAD: East Germany today accused a former top Communist official of squandering Government money, the first formal criminal charges to be brought against a member of the old regime.
The official, 61-year-old Werner Krolikowski, a former Deputy Prime Minister, faces trial in an East Berlin city court on charges of abuse of trust, said Peter Przbylski, a spokesman for the state prosecutor's office.

U.S. Wheat Rise Seen
LEAD: An Agriculture Department report projected on Monday that total United States wheat output would jump to more than 2.69 billion bushels this year, a rise of more than 650 million bushels from the weather-reduced 1989 harvest.
It would be the biggest year-to-year increase on record, resulting in the nation's third-largest wheat harvest, the report said.

LEAD: Sock Shop International P.L.C. will close 58 stores, more than half its British outlets, to try to save the business, its administrators said today.

Closing 58 British stores out of 109 will mean cutting 150 jobs, the administrators said.

LEAD: A judge rebuffed defense pleas today and ordered that Christian Brando remain in jail on a murder charge. ''The court finds there is no basis for setting bail,'' Municipal Judge Rosemary Shumsky said.
The defendant's father, Marlon Brando, sat stony-faced in the front row as William Kunstler, the civil rights lawyer, argued that the shooting of a house guest last week at the actor's home was an accident and that Christian Brando was drunk at the time.

The Swiss company had previously announced its plan to sell C-E Minerals, based in King of Prussia, Pa.
Imetal, based in Paris, is active in building materials, industrial minerals, metal fabricating and international trading.

LEAD: STUCCO is a plaster that differs from conventional wall plaster chiefly in that it contains Portland cement instead of gypsum.

LEAD: Con Edison plans to test its emergency voltage-reduction system today in preparation for the summer season, when electrical demand reaches its peak.

Corrections
LEAD: Picture captions on Monday, about morale in the Teaneck, N.J., police department after the shooting of a black youth by a white officer, misidentified members of the force.
In editions that showed two officers, the one at the top was Ray Talarico and at the bottom Phil Lavigne.
In copies that pictured only one officer, he was Phil Lavigne.


Corrections
LEAD: An article in The Living Section yesterday about mail-order potato chips misstated the address of the Humpty Dumpty Potato Chip Company in some copies.
It is P.O.
Box 2247, South Portland, Me. 04106.

Six Decades of Gun Legislation
LEAD:
1938 - National Firearms Act is passed in reaction to assassination attempt against President-elect Franklin D. Roosevelt in 1933 and in response to gang warfare.
The law regulates interstate commerce in firearms and ammunition and requires licenses for gun manufacturers and dealers.
It prohibits the sale or shipment of firearms to convicted criminals.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
TENNIS
Duncan, Witsken Win
Lawson Duncan and Todd Witsken of the United States won their second-round matches in the Bologna International tournament yesterday.
Duncan upset seventh-seeded Paolo Cane of Italy, 7-5, 6-3, and Witsken downed Martin Strelba of Czechoslovakia, 7-6, 6-1.
Top-seeded Guillermo Perez-Roldan of Argentina led the way into the quarterfinals with a 6-0, 6-0 romp over a French qualifier, Xavier Daufresne.

Striving for What's Hummable
LEAD: One afternoon two years ago, Lynn Ahrens was standing in front of a wall of books at the Barnes &amp; Noble store at Fifth Avenue at 18th Street in Manhattan.
Impulsively, she reached out and plucked at random one book among the hundreds of volumes on the shelves.
Her selection, which was on sale for $1.50, turned out to be a short novel, ''My Love, My Love,'' by Rosa Guy, an author and playwright from Trinidad who now lives in New York and whose work Ms.


Ted Tinling, Designer, Dies at 79; A Combiner of Tennis and Lace
LEAD: Ted Tinling, the British-born couturier who parlayed a pair of lace tennis panties into a tour-de-force fashion career that all but overshadowed his reputation as one of the sport's most astute observers and historians, died yesterday at Evelyn Hospital in Cambridge, England.

LEAD: The MCI Communications Corporation said this week that it had signed a three-year contract for undisclosed terms with the American Red Cross to provide an emergency response telecommunications network.

Astrodecor Revisited
LEAD: To The Home Section:


Flawed Nuclear Arms Repaired Secretly
LEAD: Nuclear arms experts said today that more than 300 nuclear artillery shells deployed in Europe were brought back to this country and secretly repaired over the last 18 months because of design defects that could have led to accidental non-nuclear explosions.


Cookie Maker In Taiwan Sale
LEAD: The nation's third-largest cookie company, Wyndham Foods Inc., has been sold to a huge Taiwan company for $335 million.


Kirov Dancer to Boston
LEAD: Aleksandr Lunev, a leading dancer with the Kirov Ballet of Leningrad, will join the Boston Ballet as a principal for the 1990-91 season.
Mr.
Lunev, who is 35 years old, appeared this month as Siegfried in the Boston company's new production of ''Swan Lake.''


Arpino to Return to the Joffrey Ballet
LEAD: Gerald Arpino will return as artistic director of the Joffrey Ballet, the company said in a statement yesterday.


Charlie Keller, 73, an Outfielder And Slugger for Yanks in the 40's
LEAD: Charlie Keller, who for much of 10 American League baseball seasons from 1939 through 1948 formed with Joe DiMaggio and Tommy Henrich one of the finest outfields in New York Yankee history, died of cancer yesterday at his home in Frederick, Md.
He was 73 years old.


Fielder Hits 17th As Tigers Win, 5-1
LEAD: Cecil Fielder hit his major-league-leading 17th home run tonight, a two-run shot in the third inning, and Tracy Jones also hit a homer as the Detroit Tigers won for the eighth time in their last nine games, defeating the Texas Rangers, 5-1.


Frederick C. Mosher; Government Expert And Teacher Was 76
LEAD: Frederick C. Mosher, a retired professor of government and foreign affairs at the University of Virginia and a former government administrator, died of emphysema on Monday at his home in Charlottesville, Va.
He was 76 years old.


Bensonhurst Witness Held on Drug Charge
LEAD: Gina Feliciano, the young woman who was at the center of the Bensonhurst murder case, was arrested last night for possession of crack, the authorities said.

LEAD: Even as growing numbers of adults discover the value of exercise to whip their bodies into better shape, relieve stress, prevent chronic disease and delay the ravages of age, the youth of America are going to seed.


G.M. Holders Likely to Back Rise in Executive Pensions
LEAD: Despite the debate surrounding a proposed pension increase for executives of General Motors Corporation, the change is likely to be endorsed by shareholders at the company's annual meeting in Detroit tomorrow, even though their approval is not required.


House Moves to Free Nicaragua and Panama Aid
LEAD: The House of Representatives took steps today to make sure the United States could soon provide economic aid to Nicaragua and Panama, despite uncertainty over the future of military aid to El Salvador.

Senate Roll-Call on Assault Weapons
LEAD: Following is the 50-49 roll-call vote by which the Senate today agreed to retain curbs on nine types of semiautomatic assault weapons as part of a larger anti-crime bill.
A yes vote was a vote in favor of reconsidering the provision while a no vote was in favor of maintaining the restrictions as part of the bill.

Rozakis said.

Rozakis' 18-month-old son, Dan, since he was an infant.

European Resignations At Ogilvy &amp; Mather
LEAD: Ogilvy &amp; Mather announced yesterday that Peter Warren and Hans Lange - the chairman and vice chairman of Ogilvy &amp; Mather Europe, respectively - had submitted their resignations.
They will leave Ogilvy in the fall.
The agency said the moves were not related.
Harry Reid will replace Mr.
Warren as chairman.

Cedric Dent keeps the beat.

But there are no instruments in sight.
They are hidden in the voices of the young men of Take 6.

LEAD: Adobe Systems Inc., which supplies software that controls laser printers, said its revenues and earnings in its second quarter would be sharply lower than anticipated, largely because of a decline in sales to Apple Computer Inc., its largest customer.


Celebrations in a 3-State Region
LEAD: The rains of May have transformed the Hudson Valley into an ocean of green -green alfalfa waving in the breeze awaiting its first cutting for hay, green apple leaves, green tips of emerging corn, green leaves of strawberry plants.
But if the soothing sight of pastoral green is not sufficient for visitors, the valley offers a variety of things to do this weekend, ranging from walking on the Appalachian Trail to attending an arts and crafts fair or visiting a bucolic museum.

LEAD: The Edmonton Oilers, in a move that provoked tears and loathing, traded Wayne Gretzky on Aug. 9, 1988.
The date and the deal, of course, changed the Oilers forever.
Tonight, though, the Oilers demonstrated that the change had not necessarily been for the worse.

LEAD: Prices of Treasury securities dipped in thin trading yesterday, as dealers sold securities after an unexpectedly poor auction of $8.5 billion worth of new five-year notes.

Celebrations in a 3-State Region
LEAD: A combination of high-energy activities, tranquil outings and somber commemorations should entice people out of doors in Westchester County over the Memorial Day weekend.

LEAD: The Florio administration today proposed an overhaul of the school-financing law that would transfer tens of millions of dollars in state aid from wealthy suburban districts to middle-class and poor urban schools beginning in the 1991-92 school year.

LEAD: The nation's top health official said today that states should license the sale of cigarettes in the same strict fashion as alcohol and that they should ban cigarette vending machines.


Continental Adds Flight
LEAD: Continental will start flying nonstop from El Paso to Mexico City on July 1, becoming the first major airline to fly directly from the border city into Mexico since the early 1980's.
Travelers now have to go through Dallas, Houston or Los Angeles to get to Mexico City.
Round-trip fares will range from $334 for a seven-day advance purchase for a weekday flight to $337 for a full-fare weekend flight.

Medtronic-Soviets
LEAD: Medtronic Inc., a manufacturer of medical-service products, said it had received an order from the Soviet Union's Ministry of Health for 20,000 Maxima blood oxygenators valued at $6 million.
Medtronic's Maxima membrane oxygenator acts as lungs when a patient's blood is routed outside the body during open-heart surgery.

LEAD: President Mikhail S. Gorbachev said today that Lithuania could be independent in two years if the republic suspended its declaration of independence, Lithuanian officials said tonight.

New G.M. Concept: Thinking Small
LEAD: The General Motors Corporation did not grow into the world's No. 1 auto maker by thinking small or bucking the economies of assembly-line manufacturing.

Ex-Fugitive Pleads Guilty to Bail Jumping
LEAD: Herman B. Ferguson, a former radical in New York City who spent 19 years as a fugitive abroad to avoid prison for conspiring to kill moderate civil rights leaders, pleaded guilty yesterday to bail jumping.


Review/Ballet;   A 'Sleeping Beauty' Not Acted, but Danced
LEAD: The role of Aurora in ''The Sleeping Beauty'' does not lend itself to imaginative acting.
Aurora is a symbol of awakening womanhood and the pretext for one of the classical ballet's most beloved spectacles.
Cheryl Yeager chose not to act the role but to dance it - triumphantly - when American Ballet Theater presented the Petipa-Tchaikovsky classic on Saturday afternoon at the Metropolitan Opera

LEAD: The founder and leader of a Hare Krishna community was indicted by a Federal grand jury today on charges of scheming to murder, kidnap and beat various followers.

LEAD: Dang Viet Chau, a former Deputy Prime Minister of Vietnam, died of a brain hemorrhage on Monday in Hanoi, the official Hanoi radio said.
No age was given.

LEAD: A global broadcasting watchdog has set five basic rules for a sharper, brighter television system of the future, but failed to agree on two crucial standards.


Waste Recycling Executives Indicted in '89 Garbage Fire
LEAD: A grand jury yesterday indicted Hub Recycling Inc. and two affiliated companies in connection with a wide range of environmental and financial crimes relating to the August 1989 garbage fire that buckled parts of Interstate 78 in Newark.

ABC Last in 'Sweep' Rating Despite 'Twin Peaks' Finale
LEAD: The last episode of ABC's widely publicized series ''Twin Peaks'' resolved none of its mysteries Wednesday night, including its future ratings prospects, as the May sweep rating month concluded with an unexpected storyline: vulnerability for NBC and viability for CBS.


A Sound - but Dirty - City Budget
LEAD: The Dinkins administration's new budget for New York City laudably strives to maintain a commitment to compassion despite falling revenues.
There is one glaring lapse: a willingness to sacrifice clean streets.
Otherwise, Mayor David Dinkins offers the State Legislature and City Council an example of reason and responsibility.

LEAD: The New Jersey Symphony Orchestra's concert in the Richardson Auditorium at Princeton University this evening, conducted by Hugh Wolff and featuring a new Viola Concerto by John Harbison, represented a homecoming for the composer.


Japanese Computer Rated The Fastest by One Measure
LEAD: A Japanese supercomputer has for the first time taken the title of the world's fastest single-processor computer, according to a study released yesterday by a researcher at the Oak Ridge National Laboratory, an Energy Department research center.

LEAD: Bond prices for R. H. Macy &amp; Company weakened yesterday on Wall Street speculation that its merchandise shipments might be affected by new credit caution and by a ripple effect from other financially depressed companies.

Corrections
LEAD: An article on Sunday about the California governorship campaign of Attorney General John K. Van de Kamp omitted part of his statement explaining the appearance of contradictions in his position on the death penalty.


Owner of Exco Seeking Bidders
LEAD: British and Commonwealth Holdings P.L.C. said it was seeking buyers for its Exco International P.L.C. subsidiary.
Exco is a financial services firm specializing in wholesale markets, including money brokering and stock lending.
The sale is part of British and Commonwealth's plan to raise $:750 million, or $12.6 million, by selling assets.


Washington Arts Group Gets Director
LEAD: The Washington Project for the Arts has announced the appointment of Marilyn A. Zeitlin, curator at the Contemporary Arts Museum of Houston, as its new director.
She succeeds Jock Reynolds, who resigned in December to head the Addison Gallery of American Art at Phillips Academy in Andover, Mass.


Albanians in No Hurry to Change Their Communist Ways
LEAD: President Ramiz Alia will move gradually in changing an orthodox Stalinist system in a country virtually sealed off to the world for four decades, two of his senior advisers say.

Apple Settlement
LEAD: Apple Computer Inc. agreed to pay $5.6 million to settle two class-action lawsuits filed by stockholders who contended that the company had given misleading information about its future performance.
Apple said it still denied all allegations in the complaints but settled to avoid the expense of further legal proceedings.

LEAD: Last September, Joe Morris broke his right foot in the Giants' final preseason game and sat out the entire season.
Today, when most of the Giants' veterans reported for a minicamp, Morris returned to the field and learned that people had short memories.

LEAD: Stocks weakened a bit yesterday amid signs that inflation is too strong for the Federal Reserve to act to bring down interest rates.

LEAD: The California Wine Commission was voted out of existence today, the victim of a rebellion by the state's small wineries.

LEAD: Frank Viola was invincible for the Mets in his first seven starts this year.

LEAD: Memorial Day weekend in Connecticut promises several untraditional events, including a hot-air balloon regatta in Bristol, a frog-jumping contest in Cornwall and sports-car racing in Lime Rock, as well as such traditional celebrations as a lobster festival in Mystic, train and boat rides in Essex and a parade in Fairfield.

LEAD: The Government today named a team of aerospace companies to do research and development work on a revolutionary aircraft intended to fly between New York and Tokyo in a few hours.

LEAD: The Navy today reopened its investigation into the explosion on the battleship Iowa after an ''unexplained ignition'' of gunpowder bags in a test earlier in the day raised the possibility that the Iowa blast was accidental.

LEAD: Deflating a recent impression that the economy was chugging along quite nicely, the Commerce Department reported yesterday that the sluggish economic growth that had set in last September had continued through the first quarter.

Half Right on China Trade
LEAD: President Bush is right to propose renewing China's trade privileges.
But he would have sent a sounder message if he had expressed outrage over Beijing's continued gross abuse of human rights.
Congress, which has 30 days to review the proposal, again will have to make clear that approving it in no sense approves repression.

That was where I first recorded with Eberhard Weber, and I did a tour with Mike Gibbs, so I was playing a lot in Europe.


GTE Discussions On Unit of Thorn
LEAD: The GTE Corporation said it was negotiating to buy the lighting division of Thorn EMC P.L.C. of Britain to get a larger share of the global lighting market.
Thorn's profits from the company's lighting and Kenwood appliances unit totaled $72 million in the fiscal year that ended on March 31, 1989, on sales of $868 million.


BUSH WITHHOLDING NORMAL TRADE TIES FROM THE SOVIETS
LEAD: President Bush indicated today that he would withhold normal trade status from the Soviet Union as long as the Lithuanian question remained unresolved.
At the same time he confirmed that he was renewing such economic benefits for China despite Beijing's hard-line policies.

LEAD: Graf Bertel Dominique has resigned the advertising account of Paul Stuart Inc., after handling the Madison Avenue clothier for just several weeks.
The agency said it had resigned the $2 million account because of creative differences.

LEAD: A Federal judge in Tampa, Fla., granted a defense motion yesterday that moved the extortion case of Howard Spira to New York.

Holiday on Monday
LEAD: Memorial Day will be celebrated on Monday. Here are holiday schedules.
NEW YORK
Parade: Memorial Day Parade, starting at 10: A.M.
Broadway will be closed from 72d to 86th streets from 9 A.M. to 1 P.M.
Government offices: Federal, State and municipal closed Monday.
Post office: Express Mail and special delivery only Monday; main post office open at 33d Street and Eighth Avenue.

LEAD: Anti-Government protesters rioted in Gabon's two biggest cities on Wednesday, burning public buildings and property belonging to President Omar Bongo and aides, witnesses said today.


How Restoring Books Is (and Is Not) Like Love
LEAD: The characters in Sherry Kramer's ''What a Man Weighs'' are employees in a book conservation laboratory devoted to insuring the continuing life of words in print.
The playwright provides the audience with intriguing details of this profession, raising questions that apply to art as well as literature.

Bank of Boston Is Downgraded
LEAD: The Bank of Boston Corporation's debt ratings were reduced by Moody's Investors Service yesterday because of loan problems and a weak regional economy.
The senior debt was reduced to a speculative-grade, ''junk bond'' category of Ba-1, from the investment grade of Baa-3.


Money Fund Assets Up
LEAD: The assets of the nation's 503 money market mutual funds increased by $94.70 million, to $381.41 billion, for the week that ended on Wednesday, the Investment Company Institute said yesterday.
The assets of the 159 institutional funds increased by $141.40 million, to $92.80 billion.
The assets of the 242 general-purpose funds were down by $750.10 million, to $129.48 billion.


Stanley J. Sarnoff, 72, Cardiologist and Inventor
LEAD: Dr.
Stanley J. Sarnoff, a cardiologist who was an inventor of emergency medical devices, died of heart failure on Wednesday while undergoing surgery at University Hospital in Salt Lake City.
He was 72 years old and lived in Bethesda, Md.

LEAD: Dr.
Eleanor Alexander Jackson, a research scientist in medical bacteriology, died on Tuesday at Lenox Hill Hospital after a short illness.
She was 85 years old and lived in Manhattan.

LEAD: Pierre Andre Rinfret, the almost certain Republican candidate for governor of New York, has little state governmental and political experience but could be an oratorical match for Gov.
Mario M. Cuomo on the stump, many economists and business executives agreed yesterday.


Pennsylvania Ballet Names New Director
LEAD: Christopher d'Amboise, a former principal dancer with the New York City Ballet, has been named artistic director of the Pennsylvania Ballet, effective in August.
Mr. d'Amboise, who is 30 years old, is also the founder, director and choreographer of the Off Center Ballet and a Tony Award-winning Broadway dancer.


Stewart Wins No. 8 as A's Romp, 13-1
LEAD: Dave Stewart became the American League's first eight-game winner this season, and Jose Canseco had four hits, including two home runs, as the Oakland Athletics defeated the Milwaukee Brewers, 13-1.

LEAD: The board of the Joffrey Ballet voted last night to have Gerald Arpino continue as artistic director of the financially troubled company, from which he resigned as director and resident choreographer on May 1.
His resignation was not accepted by the board.


Conviction in Water Pollution
LEAD: In what may be the first conviction of its kind, a Federal jury has found a company in Burlington, Mass., and its president guilty of knowingly violating the nation's Clean Water Act and endangering company employees as a result.

LEAD: The average homeowner will pay $33 more in New York City property taxes, services at the city's branch libraries will be cut and the streets and parks will become dirtier if the $28 billion budget presented yesterday by Mayor David N. Dinkins is adopted.

LEAD: In the Kremlin corridors where the apprentices of the new Soviet politics roam, the question of questions today was why Mikhail S. Gorbachev, the putative master pol, seemed to be almost recklessly courting public rejection.


People or Monsters?
LEAD: As we approach the first anniversary of the Tiananmen Square massacre, China tugs at our understanding and our conscience.
In a world of spreading democracy, how can so vast and talented a nation remain under authoritarian rule?
Is there reason to hope for change?
What should we on the outside do to help?

Carter's proxy solicitation firm when VPI acquired it in 1987.
VPI made the claims in a lawsuit seeking unspecified damages filed in United States District Court in New York.

The Editorial Notebook;   Annapolis and Karen Finley
LEAD: Last Dec. 8, some male Annapolis midshipmen carried a female colleague into a bathroom and handcuffed her to a urinal.
Then, laughing all the while, they photographed her.
She was smiling.
It was either that or cry, which is about the last thing a woman who wants to be accepted in a man's world (there are 400 women and 4,000 men at the academy) would do in public.

Reviews/Film;   Mock Documentaries Drenched in Absurdity
LEAD: Since ''The Cook, the Thief, His Wife and Her Lover'' opened, Peter Greenaway has come to be known as the artist of sex, cannibalism and disputed X ratings.
But long before that, he was making esoteric, witty, little-seen films.
Samuel Beckett, Monty Python, Jorge Luis Borges and musical Minimalism are just a few of the influences that echo through the five shorts, made in the mid- to late 1970's, that open today for a three-week run at the Public Theater under the title ''Tastings of Greenaway.

Review/Art;   Drawings by Masters Visit From Rotterdam
LEAD: Among the harbor cities of Europe, Rotterdam does not have a high profile in the travel industry.

Largely destroyed early in World War II, Rotterdam does not tempt the tourist.


Corrections
LEAD: A chart yesterday recounting 60 years of major Federal firearms legislation omitted one measure.
It was a 1988 Congressional ban on ''plastic'' guns, or firearms consisting of less than 3.7 ounces of steel; it required that all guns be detectable by airport X-ray machines.

LEAD: Following is the roll-call vote of 401 to 21 by which the House of Representatives approved the clean air bill on Wednesday night.
A ''yes'' vote is a vote to approve the bill.
Voting ''yes'' were 246 Democrats and 155 Republicans.
Voting ''no'' were 5 Democrats and 16 Republicans.
Y is a ''yes'' vote.

Prague to Cut Food Subsidies
LEAD: Food prices in Czechoslovakia will rise by almost 25 percent in July when the Government starts withdrawing state subsidies as part of a general revision of prices, Prague announced today.
The head of the Federal Price Bureau, Ladislav Dvorak, told a news conference that $1.7 billion in subsidies would be removed beginning July 9.


Restaurants
LEAD: If you have any doubts that New Yorkers are in a thrifty mood these days, just drop into the teeming dining room of Rose Cafe, an upbeat American restaurant on lower Fifth Avenue that serves single-digit appetizers and main courses that peak at $19.
The success of this six-month-old effort is even more impressive considering it occupies a space that has seen two higher-priced flops in the past three years, Mosaico and 24 Fifth Avenue.

Chin goes public.

UJB, which owns United Jersey Bank, has been hurt by the slowdown in the New Jersey economy, but has remained profitable.

Evolution in Europe;   Serbs to Expel 17 Albanians
LEAD: The Serbian authorities have ordered the expulsion of 17 Albanian refugees accused of provoking ethnic unrest in the troubled province of Kosovo, official news reports say.
The Albanians, mostly the offspring of defectors who escaped Albania's harsh Stalinist rulers after 1945, were given 30 days to leave Yugoslavia and find a new country in which to settle, the official reports said today.

In Africa, the Term 'Tribe' Is Worse Than Useless;   One-Party Democracy
LEAD: To the Editor Your May 6 news article on the political debate over whether Kenya should adopt a multiparty system implies that instituting such a system would assure democracy and respect for human and civil liberties, and that such guarantees would be absent in a one-party state.
Democracy is not a function of political parties but rather a product of effective government policy and programs.


A Many-Faceted Author Is Named Poet Laureate
LEAD: Mark Strand, a poet, a translator of Spanish literature and a short-story writer, was named today the nation's fourth poet laureate.

LEAD: Domino's Pizza Inc., the nation's second-largest pizza maker, which is up for sale, said today that several parties were interested in purchasing it and talks had been held with one potential buyer.


After 2 Near Misses, Phoenix Hits It Big
LEAD: Frustrated by a pair of last-second defeats in Portland, the Phoenix Suns left nothing to chance tonight.
They did not settle for beating the Trail Blazers.
They embarrassed them.
Leading by as many as 46 points in the third quarter, Phoenix waltzed to a 123-89 victory at Veterans Memorial Coliseum in the third game of the Western Conference final.

LEAD: Elvis Presley's stepbrother said at a press conference yesterday that he was convinced the singer committed suicide by taking an overdose of drugs.
A private autopsy after Presley's death in 1977 said the cause of death was a heart attack.

Evolution in Europe;   The Kremlin Takes a Shot
LEAD: The Kremlin's latest proposals to rejuvenate the Soviet economy, unveiled to an incredulous citizenry this week, are widely viewed by Western analysts as too little, too late.
The Government's concept of a ''regulated market economy,'' they believe, will exact much of the political pain of more radical approaches without generating much economic gain.

Corrections
LEAD: Because of an editing error, an article on Wednesday about the effect of the savings and loan bailout on the Federal deficit described effects of accounting differences incorrectly in some copies.
The deficit projected by the Bush Administration for the 1991 fiscal year would reach $199 billion if $61 billion in bailout costs were included in the deficit calculations.


Rose Case Proceeding
LEAD: A required presentencing report in the Pete Rose tax-evasion case was made available yesterday in Cincinnati to prosecutors, Rose and Rose's lawyers.
The parties have 10 days to object to any factual statements in the report.
The report will then go to United States District Judge S. Arthur Spiegel, who will decide the sentence.

LEAD: Attorney General Dick Thornburgh submitted to a polygraph examination during an internal criminal investigation at the Justice Department that led to the reassignment of his two closest aides, senior Bush Administration officials disclosed today.

LEAD: In a cinder-block warehouse near the Long Island village of Stony Brook, bicycle helmets come to die.
The headgear is smashed, split, snapped and yanked, all to determine whether it can be sold bearing a green label that means added safety.

LEAD: Kevin Secor, a junior catcher, hit a grand slam in a five-run first inning and Fordham went on to upset Arkansas, 8-5, today in a first-round game of the Midwest Regional of the National Collegiate Athletic Association tournament.


Review/Jazz;   In the Coltrane Groove
LEAD: Last Saturday's show at the Brooklyn Academy of Music, the Coltrane Legacy, was a good idea on several fronts.
For one thing, John Coltrane's music is rarely played anymore.
The contributions of the saxophonist, who died in 1967, are taken for granted now, and the concert allowed the audience to examine exactly how well arranged his later works were and how carefully he constructed his pieces to evoke certain moods that on records sound deceptively natural and improvised.

LEAD: Ever since containers of Tylenol pain relievers were laced with cyanide in 1982, hundreds of patents have been issued for tamper-proof medicine bottles.
This week a New Jersey inventor, Edward P. Diehl, patented an idea that may be the most unusual yet.

LEAD: The Governor of the state of Jammu and Kashmir, who oversaw the four-month crackdown against Muslim militants here, resigned today and is likely to be replaced by a top security official.
