AND THE WINNING - SCHOOL IS - SMALLER
LEAD: Architecture cannot solve the crisis of the schools, and no one pretends that it can.
But if good buildings cannot guarantee good education, they can play a subtle and powerful role in it.
School is the most nurturing and stable presence some children have in their lives; for many children it is the only positive connection they have to society at large.

LEAD: The women portrayed in ''Stepmothers Fight the 'Evil' Image'' (Long Island Weekly, April 29) contribute precious little to their cause by revealing for publication the intimate problems and anxieties faced by their stepchildren, without the protection of anonymity.

Yes, There Are Other Ways to Prepare Artichokes
LEAD: FOR many Americans there is only one way to serve an artichoke: boiled, with a Hollandaise or vinaigrette sauce.
The notion of cutting off the leaves beforehand and using only the heart or bottom seems wasteful.
But now that large artichokes cost less than $1 each and the medium-sized ones are selling for 20 cents apiece in some stores, it is possible to use them in a variety of ways without feeling guilty.

LEAD: It is my layman's opinion that designers and mechanics will always find more speed with advancing technology.
If you curtail the engines, then the body will evolve for more speed.
They cut the down force this year and still there's more speed.

Medical Care
LEAD: To the Editor: I am writing to thank the Israeli people for saving my husband's life.

As he fell, his head hit a metal object and he was bleeding profusely.

Naturalism at Lehman Gallery
LEAD: ONE of the many fables written and illustrated by Leo Lionni tells of a mouse named Frederick who, like Jiminy Cricket, does not prepare for winter.
Where other mice are collecting food, Frederick is off by himself, gathering, he says, ''sunshine,'' ''colors'' and ''words.'' Come winter, the odd-mouse-out nests with his brethren, sharing their supplies and, when they look to him for a contribution, he has only his food for the soul to offer.


Works in Progress;   The Art of Emulation
LEAD: AN EXAMPLE OF SUSIE RAY'S work is hanging in the British Museum, though Ray doesn't much care for the exhibition's title.
It's called ''Fake?''; her painting is a duplicate of Manet's ''Vase of Peonies.'' Ray, 31 years old, is a copy artist.
In her London gallery - called Susie Ray Originals - she replicates masterworks for collectors not keen on prints.

LEAD: Many American officials and strategic analysts seem to be making the preservation of NATO the principal objective of American policy in Europe.

Evening Hours;   Ways to Warm a Chilly Spring Night
LEAD: The polar bears were cavorting in their glass-encased grotto inthe Central Park Zoo Wednesday night, peering out quizzically at the mariachi players.
The seals were also performing for their supper, while guests at the annual fund-raising dinner of the New York Zoological Society Women's Committee danced with an actor dressed as a gorilla.


213 YEARS AFTER LOAN, UNCLE SAM IS DUNNED
LEAD: More than 200 years ago, a wealthy Pennsylvania merchant named Jacob DeHaven lent $450,000 to the Continental Congress to rescue the troops at Valley Forge.
That loan was apparently never repaid.

Yes, There Are Other Ways to Prepare Artichokes
LEAD: FOR many Americans there is only one way to serve an artichoke: boiled, with a Hollandaise or vinaigrette sauce.
The notion of cutting off the leaves beforehand and using only the heart or bottom seems wasteful.
But now that large artichokes cost less than $1 each and the medium-sized ones are selling for 20 cents apiece in some stores, it is possible to use them in a variety of ways without feeling guilty.

Question Of the Week;   Are Speeds Too Fast At the Indy 500?
LEAD: Too fast relative to what?
A stable 225-m.p.h. car is much safer than an unstable 200-m.p.h. car.
The real question at Indy this year is whether the diffuser plates on the pre-1990 chassis cars are making the cars unstable.
MARK A. MOCKOVAK
Danbury, Conn.

Where Genghis Khan Is In
LEAD: MACHOL SIPPED DEEPLY FROM THE BOWL OF FERMENTED MARE'S milk and pondered democracy.
Machol knew all about horses and sheep and wolves, but now this unfamiliar concept was sweeping Mongolia.
His wife and five children hovered silently in the rear of the gur, the white felt tent that is a herdsman's home, waiting for his judgment.

RESULTS PLUS
LEAD:
Tennis
Spain Beats United States: Conchita Martinez breezed past Lori McNeil, 6-1, 6-1, in the deciding singles match yesterday to give Spain a 3-2 victory over the United States in the Nations Cup, a tournament being played for the first time.
The event was held in Marbella, Spain.
Jennifer Capriati had given the United States a 2-2 tie when she overpowered Arantxa Sanchez Vicario, 6-3, 6-4, in the day's opening match.(AP)

Bulls, Bravery and Bounty in St.-Remy
LEAD: AUG. 15, Le quinze-aout, in France is the Feast of the Assumption, and virtually the entire country is closed that day.
Celebrations are various and splendid; each region has its own version with its own local flavor.
St.-Remy-de-Provence, in the south, produces a robust quinze-aout, a rich mixture of the religious and secular, hearty, salubrious and entirely unique.

New Jersey Transit Searches for Money Beyond the Fare Box
LEAD: New Jersey's mass transit system, among the nation's oldest and largest, has reached a point of no return.
When fares went up 12.5 percent last July, ridership was expected to drop.
But no one figured that so many commuters would get off buses and into their own cars that fare revenues would fall below the year before.

The High Art Of Horror Films Can Cut Deep Into the Psyche
LEAD: I grew up in a family that was nothing like the Addams family except in one respect.
When I was small, I would go with my favorite aunt and uncle and a cousin just my age to drive-in horror movies every week.
Better not to ask whether this was healthy for children under 10.
We loved being scared.
But ''The Premature Burial,'' Roger Corman's cheap, trashy version of Poe, was more frightening than anyone had expected.

Troubled Co-ops
LEAD: To the Editor:


CORRECTIONS
LEAD: The Mutual Funds column on May 6 about proposed changes in rules governing mutual fund fees misstated the tax ramifications of a sale of mutual fund shares.
Investors defer a tax loss if they sell and then buy back the identical shares in a fund within 60 days of the sale.
They do not forfeit the tax loss.


In Moscow's Food Stores, Grumbles, Panic and Then Empty Shelves
LEAD: Moscovites are used to complaining about empty stores, but today their worst exaggerations became a reality as nervous weekend shoppers from within and without the city raided stores, leaving shelves bare.


South Korean Leader Accepts Japanese Emperor's Apology
LEAD: President Roh Tae Woo said today that Japan's expressions of regret for its brutal colonization of Korea were the basis for a new relationship.

LEAD: All artists have personalities and skills that shape their art; no one is equally expert at everything.
Thus artists who attempt to stretch beyond their innate strengths command respect but risk failure.

That would just become a self-fulfilling prophecy.

I'm just sorry that these two bright and engaging men have given us nothing to date but all-talk-no-action domestic policies.

How to Repoint Brickwork

New Yorkers, etc.
LEAD: Even if you are, as Sue Wartur put it, ''something of a sailor,'' how long do you keep the sail from your first little sailboat?
Years, of course, a lot of years.
And then one day you think to yourself, ''It's ridiculous; what am I keeping this for?'' and you get rid of it.
In fact, you're pretty pleased with yourself about finally taking some decisive action.

A Call for Data On Auto Insurance
LEAD: In a letter to the New Jersey editor on April 22, John A. Karanik laid most of the blame for high auto insurance premiums in New Jersey on automobile design, the high incidence of auto theft and the New Jersey driver.
Despite the fact that costs from these sources would primarily fall under comprehensive and collision portions of auto policies (which many motorists have dropped because of the high cost of the legally required liability portion), most insurance industry apologists wheel out these tired arguments.

MORE MEA CULPAS FOR THE ANNUAL REPORT
LEAD: For several years, many of the companies that consider themselves in the vanguard of financial reporting, like Boeing and Chrysler, have been reserving a little-noticed section in their annual reports for something called the ''management report.'' In it, members of top management acknowledge their responsibility for presentation of the numbers in the financial statements, affirm their commitment to maintaining adequate internal controls and sometimes even sign their names for emphasis.

Pastimes;   Around the Garden
LEAD: For This Week: If iris did not bloom well, the rhizomes may need dividing; wait until late June or early July to dig up, separate and replant the rhizomes.
Plant beans, especially limas, and set out seedlings of tomato, pepper and eggplant; be sure the soil is enriched with organic material so it holds moisture; water then mulch the plants to hold moisture in and keep weeds out.

FICTION
LEAD:
ILIAS.
By Jim Sakkas. (Salem House/Harper &amp; Row, $17.95.) The long voyage from Greece to Australia begins hopefully enough for Ilias Verginis, the title character of this first novel by a writer born in Greece who also left his native island to find a new life on the other side of the world.
It is 1928, and Ilias arrives in Melbourne with a simple five-year plan: he will work hard, save money and return home to buy his own fishing boat.

Yes, There Are Other Ways to Prepare Artichokes
LEAD: FOR many Americans there is only one way to serve an artichoke: boiled, with a Hollandaise or vinaigrette sauce.
The notion of cutting off the leaves beforehand and using only the heart or bottom seems wasteful.
But now that large artichokes cost less than $1 each and the medium-sized ones are selling for 20 cents apiece in some stores, it is possible to use them in a variety of ways without feeling guilty.

The Editorial Notebook;   The Errors of Nazi Science
LEAD: Can data obtained by unethical means be permitted in science?
The issue is raised pointedly by Nazi experiments in concentration camps.
Some of these exercises, like Josef Mengele's experiments on twins, were brutish and demented.
Others were brutish but aimed at scientific goals.
A study at Dachau on methods for reviving people numbed by icy water has been cited often in the scientific literature.

Putting Ivan Boesky on Trial
The Mulheren trial is turning into the Boesky trial.
Ivan F. Boesky was forced to testify last week that he kept millions in profits from insider trading, took a tax deduction for half of his $100 million settlement and illegally paid other prisoners to do his laundry.

LEAD: Steffi Graf isn't used to losing, but every young tennis player's life is subject to disruption by a an even younger tennis player.

Campaign to Oust English Is Revived in India
LEAD: Voters in India who have been turning state-level Congress Party governments out of office in a series of elections now find that they are getting more than just new faces.
In several of India's largest states, recently elected governments are declaring war on the English language, reversing the trend toward the spread of English as a common link for a multilingual country.

About Men;   Back at the Ranch
LEAD: A YOUNG BOY MOLTS.
Tender skin falls off, or gets scraped off, and is replaced by a tougher, more permanent crust.
The transition happens in moments, in events.
All of a sudden, something is gone and something else is in its place.
I made a change like that standing in the back of a pickup truck when I was 15.

IN SEARCH OF A MEANINGFUL RELATIONSHIP WITH COMPUTERS
LEAD: Despite its phenomenal penetration into society, the personal computer is only now beginning to mature.
Early personal computers required the user to learn strings of esoteric commands that differed from system to system, which limited their appeal and made them difficult to use.
While that is still largely the case, common standards are beginning to emerge.

Pastimes;   Camera
LEAD: Those who ply their trades at newspapers know only too well what a stylebook is.
It's a comprehensive and usually exhausting compilation of all the rules of spelling, punctuation and usage that a publication tries to follow.
It tells you whether to write ''ten'' as a word or as a number.
It dictates whether ''catalog'' ends with a ''g'' or ''gue.

Design;   Guest Rooms: The Welcome Mat
LEAD: UNPOPULAR GUESTS WHO VISIT THE Connecticut summer house of my old college roommate are shown to the so-called Perry Como suite - a room barely bigger than a shoe box with a signed picture of the singer and a single, rickety old bed that breaks with one toss of a blanket.
How embarrassing for a first-time guest to confess at the breakfast table the next morning that half the lumpy mattress accidentally fell through the rustic wood frame.


Currency Psychology and the Yen
LEAD: It was a milestone of sorts for the Japanese.
The dollar fell below 150 to the yen on Friday, a key psychological break for the Japanese currency.
Although still weak, the yen has risen 5.9 percent against the dollar in three weeks and is at its strongest point since the beginning of March.
If the dollar remains below 150, the yen could gain more momentum as the Japanese switch their hedges, which would mean buying more yen.


Fashion;   The Chic Sneak: Neon Colors and Even Sequins
LEAD: The chichi sneaker may seem a contradiction in terms, but not to dozens of designers and manufacturers who are dusting otherwise mundane canvas shoes with sequins and seed pearls or turning them out in high-voltage neons and dazzling prints.

Q &amp; A
LEAD:
Watching Rose Bowl Parade
Q.
How do you get tickets to view the Tournament of Roses Parade in Pasadena, Calif?
Are there tour companies that will obtain seats on the route? - Florence Wilson, Brockton, Mass.
A.
You can watch the New Year's Day parade for no charge by sitting or standing along much of the parade route.


Pastimes;   Coins
LEAD: One of the more famous collections of ancient coins will be auctioned this summer by Sotheby's.
The first part is scheduled to be sold on June 19th in New York City.
The coins are part of the Nelson Bunker Hunt collection that contains some great scarcity and exceptional preservation.

A lawsuit, filed Thursday in State Supreme Court in Manhattan by the group, the Rent Stabilization Association, alleges that Ellen Gesmer, who was appointed May 8, does not meet a requirement of five years' experience in housing or finance and that her actions as a lawyer show she favors tenants over owners.

Robert B. Meyner Is Dead at 81; Flamboyant New Jersey Governor
LEAD: Robert B. Meyner, who revitalized the Democratic Party in New Jersey and rose to national prominence during two terms as Governor in the 1950's and early 60's, died Sunday at his home in Captiva, Fla., after a long illness.
He was 81 years old and had been in declining health since suffering a stroke in 1986.

LEAD: Ronald J. Grayheck has been elected chief executive of the American National Corporation and its principal subsidiary, the American National Bank and Trust Company of Chicago, which are units of the First Chicago Corporation.


Legal Threat Disrupts Rerun Talks
LEAD: With deadlines next month for resolving a longstanding dispute, negotiations between Hollywood producers and the broadcast networks over financial ownership of television reruns have been thrown into ''turmoil and chaos'' by the producers' threat to seek Federal antitrust charges against the networks, a senior network executive said last week.


Racial Unity and Dissent in Brooklyn
LEAD: Demonstrating for racial harmony, a small group wended its way through Prospect Park in Brooklyn today, handing out ''unity'' buttons and tying blue ribbons to lampposts and trees.


Abundance of Krill
LEAD: The use of high-frequency sound waves to measure the population of krill, a tiny, shrimp-like crustacean that forms a base of the ocean food chain, has yielded less accurate estimates than previously thought because the krill reflect less of the sound than expected, researchers say.
But the research resulted in a correction that allows a correct interpretation of the sound readings.

LEAD: New products are the lifeblood of the food business.
But the large numbers being produced have begun to clog the industry's arteries, creating new strains between manufacturers and supermarket retailers.

LEAD: In a child-abuse case that has sparked an outcry from advocates for battered women, a woman and her former husband have been indicted in the beating death of the woman's 2-year-old son.

LEAD: Saying that charging for directory assistance hurts consumers, New York City's Commissioner of Consumer Affairs has petitioned the state agency that regulates telephone service to forbid independent pay telephones from levying such charges.

LEAD: A thunderstorm's winds toppled stage speakers at a music and arts festival Sunday, injuring 27 people.
Several thousand at the Baton Rouge Fest for All were watching a warm-up band and waiting for a performance by the Temptations when scaffolding about seven feet high on the sides of the two-story-tall stage collapsed.


9 Hurt in Amtrak Wreck
LEAD: An Amtrak passenger train struck a tanker truck loaded with sewage sludge today and 9 people were injured.
None of the injuries were serious, the authorities said.
The accident occurred about noon at a rural crossing between Indiantown and Okeechobee in southeast Florida.
Lieut.
Jim Howell of the Florida Highway Patrol said the truck driver was ticketed for failure to stop at a railroad crossing.

LEAD: IF America eventually decides it can spare the $8 billion or so needed to build the Superconducting Supercollider, the county-size machine might turn out to be a key to the meaning of physical reality, or it might be a dud.

LEAD: The Louisiana House passed a bill today that would lower to $25 the fine against those who assault people who burn the American flag.
The House voted, 54 to 39, to waive the normal aggravated-battery penalties of six months in jail and a $500 fine in cases in which flag-desecrators are attacked.
The bill now goes to the Senate.

LEAD: ROSALIND CREASY has made a reputation as a proponent of edible landscaping, using the yard to grow food for the table.
Her half-acre in this community near Palo Alto looks like a California epiphany: a gorgeous array of colors, textures and decidedly unorthodox plantings.

Toward the Summit;   Arms and Armies: Pacts and Sticking Points
LEAD:
STRATEGIC ARMS REDUCTION TREATY - This treaty would make overall cuts of about 30 percent in the number of Soviet and American long-range nuclear arms.
The agreement would lead to greater cuts in the number of warheads on Soviet ballistic missiles, deemed the most threatening by the United States because of their short flight time and accuracy.

LEAD: IT will be almost a month before summer starts to ripen.
In most parts of the country, tomatoes are still green and stern, herbs are pale and shy, the corn is low, and the charcoal bag is still at significant risk of being drenched by a late spring rain.
But on Memorial Day, summer arrives in spirit, if not in fact.

LEAD: Dissatisfied with the way intricate and elaborate sound tracks came across on the antiquated sound systems in most theaters, Lucasfilm Ltd. seven years ago introduced a system that matched the quality heard on the dubbing stage at the studio.
Now, with a greater percentage of movie revenues coming from home video than from theaters, the company is about to announce home versions that will vastly improve the sound from the typical videocassette or laser disk.

MARKETS
Both the Dow and the S.&amp;P. 500 stock index rose sharply to set new highs.

LEAD: CALF'S liver, which is one of my favorite, budget-priced meats, turns up in countless fine preparations in cuisines of the world.

Cost of Color Ads
LEAD: In its first study of print production costs, the American Association of Advertising Agencies found that color ads are about two and a half times as expensive as black-and-white ones.
In 1989, the average four-color, one-page magazine ad cost $15,660 to produce; the average black-and-white ad cost $6,224.

Topics of The Times;   Sins of the Children
LEAD: Secondhand smoke, it becomes increasingly clear, endangers the second generation.
But which generation is that?
Yes, there's a strong link between smoking by parents and respiratory damage in their children.
But in many families, it's now the young people who are most likely to smoke.
That could be called visiting the sins of the children upon the fathers and mothers.

Oil and Gas Drilling Up
LEAD: The number of United States rigs drilling for oil and gas rose by 29 last week, to a total of 1,001, Baker Hughes Inc. said today.
It was the fourth straight weekly increase.
A year earlier, the count was 749.
The weekly rig count reflects the number of rigs actively exploring for oil and gas, not those producing oil and gas.

Review/Music;   A Farewell From Bach Lives On
LEAD: ''The Art of Fugue'' is Bach at his most abstract and cerebral.
A compendium of contrapuntal techniques demonstrated in 20 increasingly complex fugues and canons, the work was conceived more as a valedictory than as a performance piece.
Bach did not specify instrumentation, but the work is too glorious to live only on paper.

Gorbachev's Last Summit?
LEAD: Mikhail Gorbachev used to defy gravity: his power expanded while his policies failed.
But no longer.
His inability to block the election of Boris Yeltsin as president of the Russian Republic is only one of many setbacks.
Political tension in the Soviet Union is, in fact, so high that the summit meeting this week could be the last one the hero of perestroika attends.


Audio-Video Chain Reports 1989 Loss
LEAD: Wall to Wall Sound and Video Inc. disclosed that it had a net loss of $3.67 million for 1989 and that it was negotiating with creditor banks for waivers of default.
In a filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Wall to Wall blamed increased costs, expansion expenses, inventory adjustments and disappointing sales for its loss.

British Beef Banned by Paris
LEAD: France announced a ban today on all imports of British beef to protect against an outbreak of bovine spongiform encephalopathy, the ''mad cow'' disease that has killed 13,000 head of British cattle.
Agriculture Minister Henri Nallet said the ban would take effect Thursday.
Austria imposed a similar ban Tuesday, and European Community countries have already banned imports of British live cattle more than 6 months old.

Q&amp;A
LEAD:
Stained Tiles
Q.Our building is over 60 years old, and the tile on our bathroom floors is stained and has dried plaster on the surface.
How can we restore the tile?
A.If you want to make the tile look like new again, there isn't much you can do.
You should be able to remove the dried plaster by scraping it off with a razor blade held almost flat against the surface, and you should be able to scrub most of the other stains off with a strong detergent.

LEAD: Despite the nearness in time of the quakes that struck Peru and Romania late Tuesday and early yesterday, one earthquake rarely, if ever, touches off a quake in some other part of the globe, according to Lynne Sykes, an earthquake specialist at Columbia University's Lamont-Doherty Geological Observatory.
